"Michael M." <nixlists at writemoore.net> dijo:

> > So now I'm gonna reinstall them from the same instructions. :)

> Huh ... I wonder if it has something to do with the "...64" part? 

I'm pretty sure that's it. Stuff not quite ready for 64-bit. 

Sadly, after my last response I tried to reinstall the Nvidia driver. No go. The instructions that I bookmarked from last time appeared to work, but when I rebooted I got the same "X won't start" problem. Had to edit xorg.conf with nano again to get the open source driver back. The open source driver works just fine for everything else -- I need it only for playing DVDs. And, having done all the 230 updates that started me on the current problem, I tried playing DVDs with the open source driver again, but same problems as before. Totem launches and then just disappears. So now I have to go figure out how to reinstall the Nvidia driver. But that is not a critical problem, so it can wait until after finals. No time right now to watch movies anyway.

> I'm curious about what advantages you get from running the 64-bit 
> version.  From what I've read, I thought the advantages over 32-bit were 
> limited to mathematical calculations and that it wasn't worth the hassle 
> if you aren't doing a lot of 64-bit calculating.  (Well, that and being 
> able to address way more RAM than I have.)  Are there other benefits 
> that I don't know about, or is it that you're doing these kinds of 
> calculations?

Actually, from everything I have read, it does run generally a little faster than the 32-bit version, although I suspect the difference is pretty trivial. My first reason is because this is my first venture into Linux and I wanted a baptism by fire. Best way to learn software is just doing it, making mistakes, and figuring out how to fix them. Sometimes it's painful, but that way you don't forget the lesson. It's been only a year for me, but I already have a pretty impressive collection of scars.

My second need is to use this computer for my class work in linguistics at PSU. But so far that only requires a GUI word processor with all the bells and whistles. OpenOffice.or 2.0 fills that bill, although there are occasional font issues -- it can't use OTF fonts, but that's also true of the 32-bit Linux version. If I couldn't run OO.org in 64-bit Linux I would be forced to use 32-bit. But since OO.o does run in 64-bit Linux, then running 64-bit helps with my goal of learning Linux. 

There may come a problem this fall when I will need to run Treeform (http://www.ece.ubc.ca/~donaldd/treeform.htm) for drawing syntax trees. I can do syntax trees in OO.o, but it's tedious. Treeform is written in Java, and it is supposed to run on Linux. I "installed" it, but can't figure out how to launch it. No documentation, of course. Most people use Visio on Windows for syntax trees. I tried Kivio, supposedly the Linux equivalent, but it's nowhere near the "equivalent." You can't create your own templates even. I could run Visio under Wine or something, but I don't want MS stuff if I can avoid it. Besides, you can't run Wine in 64-bit yet either.

I noticed on the Ubuntu forums that the release of Dapper Drake is imminent. I've been reading the comments from users of the 64-bit beta, and it looks like it will solve a lot of the above problems.

# from John Jason Jordan
# on Thursday 01 June 2006 07:50 am:

>I can do syntax trees in OO.o, but it's tedious. Treeform is written
> in Java, and it is supposed to run on Linux. I "installed" it, but
> can't figure out how to launch it.

Have you tried Dia?  Maybe also Inkscape (>= 0.43 has connectors.)

But if you really want to graph some serious trees, anything is tedious 
compared to graphviz.  No GUI though, but maybe worth a look if you're 
thinking of getting your 64bits worth.

  http://www.graphviz.org/

The great thing about it is that you can generate the dot language 
programmatically.

Maybe you could write it in Latin?
 
http://search.cpan.org/~dconway/Lingua-Romana-Perligata-0.50/lib/Lingua/Romana/Perligata.pm

Also, install this one: 
http://search.cpan.org/~ingy/HashBang-Lingua-Romana-Perligata-0.10/

So your Latin scripts can start with:

  #!/usr/bin/perligata

--Eric

Not very pretty output either, but it works.

>  http://www.graphviz.org/
>
> The great thing about it is that you can generate the dot language
> programmatically.

There are a couple of Perl modules that handle Graphviz.

The problem with Graphviz is that generating large graphs can be difficult 
to display and even harder to read.  (They start looking like an 
invocation to the Flying Spaghetti Monster.)  I generated one graph that 
turned into a png file large enough that it required a couple of gigs of 
ram to display it properly.  (You can generate the graph as PostScript, 
but then you get to play jigsaw puzzle with the printer output.) Most 
imageviewers choke on a 1,800 x 23,800 pixel png file.

> Maybe you could write it in Latin?
>
> http://search.cpan.org/~dconway/Lingua-Romana-Perligata-0.50/lib/Lingua/Romana/Perligata.pm
>
> Also, install this one:
> http://search.cpan.org/~ingy/HashBang-Lingua-Romana-Perligata-0.10/
>
> So your Latin scripts can start with:
>
>  #!/usr/bin/perligata

Mayan is more fun to print.

Can someone tell me what this message means?
I got it out of the dmesg command.

ABORTED IN=eth0 OUT= MAC=00:0c:6e:a7:e5:66:00:0f:3d:4a:e2:d2:08:00 
SRC=64.5.35.225 DST=192.168.0.100 LEN=40 TOS=0x00 PREC=0x20 TTL=113 
ID=49779 DF PROTO=TCP SPT=80 DPT=4766 SEQ=3349389583 ACK=90362985 
WINDOW=0 RES=0x00 ACK RST URGP=0

I recognize :
eth0 (my ethernet interface)
192.168.0.100 (my LAN address)

$ whois 64.5.35.225

OrgName:    ThePlanet.com Internet Services, Inc.
OrgID:      TPCM
Address:    1333 North Stemmons Freeway
Address:    Suite 110
City:       Dallas
StateProv:  TX
PostalCode: 75207
Country:    US

If this is from outside my LAN, why isn't my D-Link router blocking it?

Thank you.
- TSloth



From drew.wymore at gmail.com  Thu Jun  1 11:27:52 2006
From: drew.wymore at gmail.com (drew wymore)
Date: Thu, 1 Jun 2006 11:27:52 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] What does this log message mean?
In-Reply-To: <447F2BF6.7030407@jblack.org>
References: <447F2BF6.7030407@jblack.org>
Message-ID: <e2aeccd60606011127j7b92deebg5b1106d4933805a6@mail.gmail.com>

It was a response from 64.5.35.225 to your machine based on a request to
port 80 to 64.5.35.225 .. the destination port 4766 wasn't blocked since
there was probably a NAT route entry for this outbound request so it let the
response come back inbound to the machine that requested it.

Drew-

based; I think their DNS and mail servers, but since I run my own it
makes no difference to me.

From m0gely at telestream.com  Thu Jun  1 16:01:32 2006
From: m0gely at telestream.com (m0gely)
Date: Thu, 01 Jun 2006 16:01:32 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] XBOX Linux...
In-Reply-To: <1149124244.447e3e94df48a@xerxes.robinson-west.com>
References: <1149124244.447e3e94df48a@xerxes.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <447F71CC.3010401@telestream.com>

plug_0 at robinson-west.com wrote:
> Has anyone here modified the original XBOX to run Linux?

Eh, it's a 733MHz Celeron.  IMHO this machine is not worth the hassle 
for running Linux.  Much less resistance just getting an older HP or 
something.

> How does 
> Microsoft's XBOX Live online system know that you've altered a unit?

I have not personally subscribed to Live, but from what I have read you 
should not until you're done making the mods, as people have reported 
it's the change in the system that can trigger a ban.

My mod chip has a feature that allows you to run the xbox with the mod 
chip disabled.  Not sure if it can still be detected, but my intention 
was for media.  I don't plan on paying MS for Live.  And you can get 
purely software based mods done, but then I think you remove the ability 
to get back into the stock xbox environment.

> What is a modchip?  Does going the modchip route really allow someone 
> to hide that their XBOX is Linux ready from Microsoft?  How does an 
> ITX form factor Celeron compare to the XBOX as far as: running quietly 
> and taking up very little space?

The xbox is a PC.  Intel CPU, NVIDIA gfx, standard IDE hard drive and 
slightly proprietary DVD drive.  The BIOS however is proprietary, and 
only allows digitally signed code to run.  Copying a DVD game doesn't 
get the digital sig.  This is why you cannot play copied games.

The mod chip is a component you install that allows you to bypass the MS 
BIOS and thus run unsigned code.  You must solder several wires onto the 
motherboard (unless you buy the more expensive solderless adapter) to 
complete the installation.  This is not for the unexperienced person. 
The one I use (Xecuter 3) provides a LED panel and DIP switch that are 
connected to the outside of the box.  The DIP switches allow you to use 
different banks of the BIOS for different firmwares.  This helps in 
testing or when you flash to a new firmware you can switch back if you 
hose the install.

The xbox runs a very stripped Win2K kernel for the underlying OS.  The 
operating environment is called a Dashboard (Windows on top of DOS?). 
This is what most people replace with something new, like XBox Media 
Center (XBMC), but there are others.

However now that you have this ability, you use the xbox's internal hard 
drive to run XBMC and not bother with a DVD each time.  Mine boots up to 
XBMC, but I can still boot stock easily.  This leads to "why not put 
lots more on the hard drive" mentality.  Especially when you realize you 
can get a torrent for several hundred NES, SNES, Genesis, & N64 games 
and just have all that stored on your xbox hdd.  But why stop there 
right?  Install a larger drive and store all your xbox games too and 
bypass the need to get your DVD's out at all.  You may as well put some 
movies on there too eh?  Or just access files over the network via SMB. 
  Maybe you're starting to get the picture.

> Why is XBOX so popular if it's nothing more than a low end PC that has 
> been hardware modified so that it can run the XBOX operating system only?

Because a ~$200 PC can't do all that and play xbox games too.  I dunno. 
  Building a PC to sit under my TV and do what my xbox does would cost 
more than that, and would be butt ugly.  An xbox 360 can't hold a candle 
to mine.  Outside of playing 360 games mine does much more.  The 360 
won't do DivX or XviD, et al.

> Why modify an XBOX to run Linux instead of going with a Micro-ATX
> or ITX form factor PC?  Isn't buying one encouraging the rage over
> these things by giving them resale value?

As I started out saying it's not.  Get a PC.  But I felt I had to give 
some background in why people do this, and what the process is about to 
help make the point.  Knowing why people do this may help you know if 
you want to.

> On the other hand, there must be some reason why there are instructions
> online on how to make these things run Linux.

People waste too much time making everything run some OS.  But to each, 
their own. :)

-- 
- m0gely
http://quake2.telestream.com/
Q2 | Q3A | Counter-strike

On Thu, 1 Jun 2006 09:13:14 -0700
Eric Wilhelm <scratchcomputing at gmail.com> dijo:

> # from John Jason Jordan
> # on Thursday 01 June 2006 07:50 am:
> 
> >I can do syntax trees in OO.o, but it's tedious. Treeform is written
> > in Java, and it is supposed to run on Linux. I "installed" it, but
> > can't figure out how to launch it.
> 
> Have you tried Dia?  Maybe also Inkscape (>= 0.43 has connectors.)

No, those are just vector drawing programs. No real improvement for me
over the Draw function in OO.o. I think I failed to explain what
Treeform does. You click on a tool to draw a specific tree (buttons for
various types of trees) and it automatically draws the tree, puts the
default labels on the nodes, and you're ready to enter the glosses
underneath, for which the text box(es) are empty with a cursor blinking
in them. Then you decide you need another tree branching underneath, so
you put the cursor on the node where you want the branch to connect and
click on the appropriate tree type -- immediately the new tree is
placed in the right position, again, with nodes appropriately named and
input boxes ready for you to type in the glosses.

> But if you really want to graph some serious trees, anything is tedious 
> compared to graphviz.  No GUI though, but maybe worth a look if you're 
> thinking of getting your 64bits worth.

These are not graphs. They are trees. They look sort of like this:

                /|\
               / | \
                   /\

Except they get really involved. For some you need very, very large
pieces of paper, although usually we just do a portion of an utterance
at a time.

> Maybe you could write it in Latin?

Latine hodie non bene loquor. :)

OSCAMP 2006: Free as in Freedom! -- Portland July 24-28, 2006 at OSCON

Please join us for OSCAMP 2006 <http://oscamp.org/OSCAMP>, a free (as in
freedom) un-conference of, for, and by folks who are part of the
Free/Libre/Open
movement <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FLOSS>. You are reading this
invitation <http://oscamp.org/Invitation> because someone wants to see you
at the bazaar!

A grassroots cooperative effort with O'Reilly,
OSCAMP<http://oscamp.org/OSCAMP>seeks to organize the fringe of
activity that has grown up around
OSCON <http://conferences.oreillynet.com/os2006/> during the last several
years so that the entire shindig can rock even more! We are coming together
to network, write code, have fun and learn about the cool things that are
afoot in the movement. Bring your friends and join a good party that's
growing even better!

*When:* July 24-28, 2006
*Where:* PortlandOregon <http://oscamp.org/PortlandOregon> at the Oregon
Convention Center (part of OSCON 2006<http://conferences.oreillynet.com/os2006/>
)
*Format:* OpenSpace <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_Space_Technology>
*Cost:* Free ? but you can call it "Open" if that's your thang [image:
;)]Sources
of Inspiration

Mad props to those who came before us:

   - the free/libre open source software
movement<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FLOSS>,
   which popularized sharing and attribution
   - OpenSpaceTechnology<http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_Space_Technology>,
   a way to get the most out of a gathering of people
   - FooCamp <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foo_Camp>, the first Camp, an
   informal but intensive camp-out at O'Reilly
   - BarCamp <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bar_camp>, the mother of the
   rest of *Camps, invite everyone to share, and leave a trail for others to
   follow

How it Works

OSCAMP is an "open <http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_Space_Technology>"
space for meeting, for learning, for connecting, for writing code ? with no
imposed limits or agendas - only the charge to come and learn and contribute
as much as you can. The agenda is created and modified "on the fly" by the
participants. You can add to the agenda any issue of importance to you. It
will be discussed and addressed to the greatest extent possible. All of the
key points and next steps will be captured online so that the entire
Freedom/Libre/Open community can benefit from our work.

To register, follow the instructions on the
Registration<http://oscamp.org/Registration>page. We don't know
exactly what is going to happen, but we do know that
it's going rock! Come to OSCAMP in Portland ? you'll never be the same!

Warm regards from the CoConveners <http://oscamp.org/CoConveners>,

work in the Freedom/Libre/Open movement.

On Sun, 28 May 2006 17:18:39 -0700
Auke Kok <auke at foo-projects.org> dijo:

OK, until today I was OK with my 60 GB iPod. Right now you couldn't
GIVE me another Apple product.

It has been working fine. OK, occasionally it just stops for no reason
and you have to hit the Pause button to get to to continue. A flaw in
the design -- it always happens when walking, never when it is just
sitting. In other words, there is some kind of a motion detector in the
thing that parks the disk or something when you move it too fast.
Except it is too sensitive.

And then there is the problem of mounting and unmounting, and the ease
with which you can totally hose the database. Not a very robust bit of
software. And if you do hose it you have to use a Windows XP or 2000
SP4 computer to restore it, because the restore utility will not work
on anything else.

But all in all,it worked. Until today, that is, when I grabbed it on my
way out the door to go to the university. It was playing through my
stereo, plugged into its power adaper. I've disconnected it many times
and never a problem. Today, as I went to put it in my shirt pocket I
pressed the bottom button to turn it off. And it wouldn't turn off. I
tried all morning to turn it off. The button appeared to be broken.

So I get to school and decide to take it to the second floor of the
bookstore, which is where I bought it last summer. The clerk there
confirmed that it wouldn't turn off, and suggested I take it to the
Apple store at Pioneer Place, where she said they had iPod technicians.
"Cool," I thought, and planned to walk down there later after a meeting
I needed go to.

So I get to the store, wait around for 15 minutes until my number comes
up. While waiting I pull it out of my pocket and -- lo and behold -- it
is OFF! So I decide I'll stick around to talk to the tech anyway, just
to see if there is a known problem with the off button. Finally I get
to speak to the technician. He plugs it into his computer, fiddles with
his mouse a bit, and then says "I see you have music installed that was
not created with iTunes or from the iTunes store. It looks like it was
created with [curious look on his face] ... 'lame'?

"Uh, yeah," I say. But they all play just fine.

"Yes," he says. "But you see, we cannot support your iPod because there
might be something wrong with your mp3s that could cause a problem with
the iPod software."

"Fine. All I want is for you to check to see if there might be a
problem with the buttons."

"OK," he says, and proceeds to fiddle with the iPod wheel while looking
at his computer screen. "No, everything seems to be working just fine.
Now, while you're here, I see you have the older version of the Apple
software. I can upgrade it for you and it will just take a minute, if
you like."

"OK," I said. Whereupon he took my iPod into the back of the store. A
few minutes later he returned and gave it back to me. I left and
returned to the university. As soon as I was comfortably seated in the
library with some work to do in front of me, I pulled out the iPod so I
could listen to tunes while studying. I turned it on and ... no music.
He wiped out all the songs on my iPod. And he must have done it
delibaretely, not because he reformatted the disk, because my settings
and playlists are intact.

And to reply to myself, there is no SDK for public use on the xbox.  Any 
software you find out there in binary form is illegal.  The xbox with a 
mod chip in it only boots, but does nothing until you get a firmware on 
it.  It's a whole new underground community and a maze of IRC and FTP 
sites to get the actual files.  Get to that stuff once, then it's easy.

it's so freaking cool, to be able to download BBC shows, video podcasts, 
and missed episodes of Lost (in HDTV) then watch it all on my TV 
upstairs when I have time, and with the commercials already ripped out.

On Thu, 1 Jun 2006, John Jason Jordan wrote:
> OK, until today I was OK with my 60 GB iPod. Right now you couldn't GIVE 
> me another Apple product.

I hate to be a dick about this, but, as usual, the problems here were due 
to your own ignorance and not problems with the product (besides the usual 
sort of junk that happens with consumer electronics running complex 
software).

> It has been working fine. OK, occasionally it just stops for no reason 
> and you have to hit the Pause button to get to to continue. A flaw in 
> the design -- it always happens when walking, never when it is just 
> sitting. In other words, there is some kind of a motion detector in the 
> thing that parks the disk or something when you move it too fast. Except 
> it is too sensitive.

There's no motion sensor.  There is, however, a circuit that cuts to pause 
when the headphones are removed.  If your headphone jack is loose or (much 
more likely) you have a short in your headphones, small shifts in the 
position of the thing is triggering the auto-pause mechanism.

I had the same problem and got better headphones and no more problem.

> And then there is the problem of mounting and unmounting, and the ease 
> with which you can totally hose the database. Not a very robust bit of 
> software. And if you do hose it you have to use a Windows XP or 2000 SP4 
> computer to restore it, because the restore utility will not work on 
> anything else.

That's not strictly true, either.  First, there is a utility to update the 
firmware (and reformat the disk) that doesn't require iTunes available 
from Apple.  If you want to do it under Linux, there are perl utilities.

> But all in all,it worked. Until today, that is, when I grabbed it on my 
> way out the door to go to the university. It was playing through my 
> stereo, plugged into its power adaper. I've disconnected it many times 
> and never a problem. Today, as I went to put it in my shirt pocket I 
> pressed the bottom button to turn it off. And it wouldn't turn off. I 
> tried all morning to turn it off. The button appeared to be broken.

Did you try a hard reset?  On my model, you hold down the center button 
and menu button simultaneously for a few seconds and it resets.  That's 
always worked when it's locked up.

> "OK," he says, and proceeds to fiddle with the iPod wheel while looking 
> at his computer screen. "No, everything seems to be working just fine. 
> Now, while you're here, I see you have the older version of the Apple 
> software. I can upgrade it for you and it will just take a minute, if 
> you like."
>
> "OK," I said. Whereupon he took my iPod into the back of the store. A
> few minutes later he returned and gave it back to me. I left and
> returned to the university. As soon as I was comfortably seated in the
> library with some work to do in front of me, I pulled out the iPod so I
> could listen to tunes while studying. I turned it on and ... no music.
> He wiped out all the songs on my iPod. And he must have done it
> delibaretely, not because he reformatted the disk, because my settings
> and playlists are intact.

Do you really think the world is out to get you?  Do you think people 
design products to shut down and wipe your disk out of spite?

I assure you that the kid at the Apple store doesn't care one way or 
another what you do with your iPod.

What happened was a side-effect of updating the firmware and the iTunes 
database.  If you mount your iPod now and compare the file structure to 
what it looks like when you've initialized gtkpod, you'll see what I mean.

On 6/1/06, m0gely <m0gely at telestream.com> wrote:
> And to reply to myself, there is no SDK for public use on the xbox.  Any

> it's so freaking cool, to be able to download BBC shows, video podcasts,
> and missed episodes of Lost (in HDTV) then watch it all on my TV
> upstairs when I have time, and with the commercials already ripped out.

It is entirely possible to install and run Linux on the Xbox with only
a software mod (using the original Mechassault) and still play games
through the dashboard.  It is my understanding this is detectable
through Xbox Live though.  The Xbox Linux web site
(http://www.xbox-linux.org) has more information.

The install is really only worth it if:

a) You already have an Xbox or otherwise want to play (original) Xbox games
b) Want to use digital media in your home entertainment system -AND-
c) Don't want to purchase a separate more up-to-date box to perform b)

It's hard.  And not very exciting.  And all the developers have moved
on to bigger/better/whatever projects.  I installed the software mod
about two years ago and used it for a month or two, then lost
interest.  Currently an iPod fills most of the functionality I thought
the Xbox would be good at.

Jason

On Thu, 1 Jun 2006, Jason R. Martin wrote:
> It's hard.  And not very exciting.  And all the developers have moved on 
> to bigger/better/whatever projects.  I installed the software mod about 
> two years ago and used it for a month or two, then lost interest.

We use our modified XBox every day.  We run XBMC, though.

I think a set-top box with quality TV output for ~$80 is a deal.  I put a 
120GiB disk in mine, but mostly use it to stream video from one of the 
cluster of servers and desktop machines on the local network (shared with 
my neighbors, of course).  We pool our network resources and whatever 
we've downloaded or ripped is made available for everyone at any time. 
Quite convenient.

Furthermore, the interface is simple enough that my non-technical 
roommates can navigate the system and watch videos or listen to music 
whenever they like.

> Currently an iPod fills most of the functionality I thought the Xbox 
> would be good at.

Between XBoxes and the Turtle Beach Audiotron that someone gave me from a 
dumpster, We no longer need to use the iPods as a music source in the main 
rooms.

There are still iPod docks in the kitchen and garage, though.  And, of 
course, they are much handier than an XBox when you're biking around town!

As soon as I get that USB 2.0 turntable, I'll probably ditch all of my 
stereo equipment except for a couple of amplifiers and speakers.  I really 
can't imagine I'll need another CD player besides a CDROM and I haven't 
used a cassette in years.  Hell, even my collection of Minidisc equipment 
goes untouched except for the occassional field recording (which is rarer 
and rarer in my own life and should probably be replaced with an iRiver or 
something in the future).

Anyway, that's how media is done at my place.  And I'm helping all my 
friends get cheap old XBoxes for modding while the gamers all buy up 360s.

>> There's no motion sensor.  There is, however, a circuit that cuts to pause
>> when the headphones are removed.
>
> Sorry, that is not what is causing the problem. It happens with seven or 
> eight different headphones, including the original iPod headphones and 
> two more purchased from Apple. You can't convince me that I have that 
> many bad plugs.

Seems unlikely, but the loose connection could be in the jack (as I 
originally stated).

> Besides, the same headphones work fine on all other equipment.

The issue I'm describing wouldn't effect the performance of the 
headphones.

> Furthermore, this particular problem is pretty well documented on the 
> internet.

Yeah, it's a common thing.  The auto-pause feature is flakey as hell.

Mine was doing it from about the third month of iPod use until about the 
seventh.  Then I got another new set of headphones (I'm always damaging 
the cords in some irreparable way) and no more trouble.

> In either case, it will stop suddenly and hitting the Pause button 
> restarts it every single time, without fail. If it were a headphone 
> connection problem at least some of the time the Pause button would not 
> restart it.

HUH?!?  That doesn't follow at all.

The issue is (in my speculation) that a short or power fluctuation of some 
kind is triggering the auto-pause feature.  Pressing pause again will 
CERTAINLY resume play (even if the headphones are not attached).

>> Did you try a hard reset?  On my model, you hold down the center button 
>> and menu button simultaneously for a few seconds and it resets. 
>> That's always worked when it's locked up.
>
> It's not locked up when it stops playing. Hitting the Pause button makes 
> it continue. No reset is necessary.

Yeah, if you followed the thread of conversation, you'd note that I was 
referring to the trouble you had when the system "wouldn't shut off".  My 
comment wasn't related to the auto-pause events.

I ask again, did you try to do a soft reset when the thing wouldn't shut 
off this afternoon?

>> Do you really think the world is out to get you?  Do you think people 
>> design products to shut down and wipe your disk out of spite?
>
> No, only Apple is out to get me. Actually that is not entirely true. 
> They don't care about me at all.

Well, I'm glad you recognize that much.

> They just want to be sure they get as much money out of me they possibly 
> can.

That's capitalism for you.  Hopefully we'll solve that problem sooner 
rather than later.

> And the kid at the Apple store had only one goal: Get me out of the 
> store so he could wait on the backlog of customers waiting in line.

Not quite.  If he just wanted you out of the store, he wouldn't have 
offered to update your firmware for you.  That didn't get you out of the 
store sooner and didn't result in any further sales that could possibly 
garner him commission.  He did that as a service to you.

And deliberately erasing your music wouldn't make his life easier in any 
way whatsoever.  In fact, it might even make you come back and bitch 
later, which is counterproductive.

> Yeah, I am home from tonight's meeting and I plugged it in and went to 
> mount it. Unfortunately I am unable to mount it. As far as I can tell it 
> no longer has FAT32 file system on it. To verify, I plugged it into my 
> Windows 2000 computer, which told me it was not formatted.

That bites.

You can use an HFS iPod, if you've configured your system for it.  But I 
also have my iPod formatted FAT32 just for universality as portable 
storage.

You kind of can't blame the kid, though.  He probably did the firmware 
update (which reformats the disk -- as you should know) on a Mac (I can't 
imagine he has much choice at The Apple Store).  Definitely make sure you 
let them know you want it "Windows Format".  There's no reason to get 
technical about it.  They'll understand what you mean.

> Well, I have to go back to the university tomorrow, so I'll take it back 
> to the Apple store. How much you wanna bet they will tell me they are 
> unable to format it FAT32 and it's my responsibility?

Well, they MIGHT be able to do it.  But really, you can just download the 
little firmware update utility and run it from the desktop of one of the 
computers at the university library.  (I don't think it needs special 
permissions or to actually "install" to run, so you shouldn't have to 
worry about the security settings of the host computer.)

A nice courtesy might be letting the folks at the store know that you had 
it formatted FAT32 and their update changed that condition.  They should 
definitely know to ask or just note the format and do the right thing.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Jun  2 09:02:48 2006
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri, 2 Jun 2006 09:02:48 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Icon Scaling Help Needed -- RESOLVED
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.63.0606020652010.16296@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.63.0606020652010.16296@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.63.0606020859150.16296@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Fri, 2 Jun 2006, Rich Shepard wrote:

>  There must be something simple that I've missed so a clue would be quite
> helpful. I'm trying to create a simple favicon for our web site, and I
> understand that needs to be 16x16 pixels in size.

   Rod's lesson for today was invaluable. For some reason, 'man winicontoppm'
failed to unbzip2, but a simple 'winicontoppm favicon.ico favicon.ppm'
worked. The GIMP scaled it from 32x32 to 16x16 pixels, and then it was time
to convert back. The syntax for that is different: 'ppmtowinicon -output
favicon.ico favicon.ppm'.

   I wonder how many thousands of other useful gems are buried under the
overburden on my system.

Thanks, Rod!

Rich

depth. The file is 1kb in bulk.

   I'll redo the conversions and see what the color depth is. Stay tuned for
an update ...

From aaron at bavariati.org  Fri Jun  2 11:57:04 2006
From: aaron at bavariati.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Fri, 2 Jun 2006 11:57:04 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Asterisk hardware question
In-Reply-To: <20060602181127.GC24074@merlot.com>
References: <20060602181127.GC24074@merlot.com>
Message-ID: <20060602185704.GD12359@syrinxpc.com>

On Fri, Jun 02, 2006 at 11:11:27AM -0700, Kurt Sussman wrote:
> I'm playing with Asterisk, and have been looking at the Sipura SPA-3000
> and the Digium TDM cards. For the same functionality (1 FXO + 1 FXS,
> which is all I need currently) the Sipura is about half the price. 

And other ATAs are even cheaper than the Sipura, especially if you don't
need WAN-passthrough and suchlike.  Atcom and some others offer ATAs
with 4 FxS ports, or even a mix of FxO and FxS ports, with failover.
(So you can e.g. plug your landline into the FxO, and if the ATA dies,
it cuts the landline through to one of the FxS ports.)

http://www.voip-info.org has a list of ATAs and other line-interface
devices.  Did'ja know there's devices that let you plug a bunch of
digital PBX phones into your Asterisk box?  Swap out old PBX, swap in
new super-powerful VoIP-enabled soft-PBX, leave the phones in place.

> Considering voice quality only, is the Digium card worth the extra
> bucks?

It's just as crappy as any other phone-line interface in my experience,
without the flexibility and reusability of a separate ATA.

> Now considering everything you know to be important about the Asterisk
> analog interface (which will include lots of things I haven't yet
> discovered), what would you buy and why?

An ATA, unless maybe I needed to handle FAXes.  Which should just be
left to a landline anyway; FAXes are used by folks who sign contracts,
run payroll and approve purchases, and thus are Not To Be Meddled With.

> For now, this is a personal project, but some people I know in New
> Orleans are looking for a massive voicemail system (on a budget, of
> course) and I think Asterisk might be a solution for them. If you
> Asterisk experts have any favorite links on setting up secure voicemail
> systems, please feel free to share them!

The aforementioned voip-info.org, and http://www.oreillynet.com/etel/

Asterisk's voicemail system might not be as flexible or powerful as you
might need for a "massive" system, though using multiple Asterisk boxes
with a clustered database backend might help.  There are many other more
flexible software packages.  Also, remember that T1s are way cheaper
inside a CLEC's hosting center (e.g. ELI's facility by the airport) than
backhauled to your office.

Well, I spent an hour on it this morning. Evidently the only way I can
get it back to FAT32 is to use the iPod Updater utility. iTunes will
format an HFS iPod only the first time it is plugged into a Windows
computer. Thereafter it does not see it as a Mac iPod that needs to be
converted. It just doesn't see it at all. I know this because I went to
my Windows 2000 desktop where I downloaded and installed iTunes 6.0
just for this purpose. No way can I get iTunes to see the iPod as long
as it is HFS. 

Then I went to the Apple forums, created a username, and posted my
query there. There have been several replies already, which confirm
that the Updater utility is the only way to get it back to FAT32 now.
And the Updater utility will not install on my Windows 2000 desktop
because it is only SP2. The Updater requires SP4. I've tried and tried
to install SP4 but it always aborts at the last minute. Microsoft has
no idea why. "This cannot happen if your current system is running" is
all their tech support can tell me. Anyone wondering why I want to move
to Linux?

So at this point I have only three options. 1) Go back to the Apple
store and ask them to reformat it "for Windows." 2) See if I can get
the Updater to install on a computer at PSU. 3) See if I can get my
Ubuntu-64 Breezy computer to read/write the HFS file system and just
leave it as a Mac iPod.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Jun  2 12:29:10 2006
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri, 2 Jun 2006 12:29:10 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Icon Scaling Help Needed
In-Reply-To: <000701c68673$ca3c5370$0501010a@billslaptop>
References: <000701c68673$ca3c5370$0501010a@billslaptop>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.63.0606021221570.16296@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Fri, 2 Jun 2006, Bill Ensley wrote:

> Sorry, I was out for a few hours, is this resolved?

Bill,

   Yes, it has. The procedure is .ico through winicontoppm to .ppm. In the
GIMP, change scale from 32x32 to 16x16; save as .png. Run that through
'png2ico filename.ico --colors 16 filename.png', then add the img lines to
the head section of each page as suggested by the png2ico web page.

   I'm sure the rescaling and converstion from .ppm to .png could be done with
ImageMagick, and the whole process scripted.

   So, now the little eye candy favicon is on all pages of my site. That
strangled some of this morning, but now I'm back to writing a couple of
lectures complete with giveaway text and the visuals for the talks.

Thanks,

Rich

I talked to the group last night about Eclipse and the Portland area codecamp coming up.

Here's the link to more information. (This is excerpted from mail from Jason Mauer.)

Portland Code Camp 2.0

pdx.techevents.info/codecamp/2/default.aspx

Howdy campers! Mark off your calendars for this July 22nd and 23rd, because Code Camp is coming back to Portland bigger and better than ever!

It?s actually ?Portland Metro??

This year we?re venturing across the river as our friends in the Couv host our second annual Code Camp. WSU Vancouver has provided their facilities for our use, which are well suited for our needs. Tons of space, great classrooms (all with projectors), a beautiful campus, ample parking? it?s got it all!

The Plans As They Stand

?         Two-day Code Camp like last year (Saturday, Sunday)

?         Saturday evening ? onsite outdoor party with live music, food and fun

?         With the help of contributors, we are hoping to provide free meals for the duration of the camp ? stay tuned

 

Attending

Attendance is free as always but space is limited, so to guarantee your spot you?ll need to register. It?s just one click after creating your account ? register now!

 

Presenting

Session submission is now an automated process. On the right side of the sessions page (which you should check out first to make sure your session idea isn?t a duplicate) there is a link to submit a session. 

 

One feature we?ve added to sessions this year is tagging. Categorize your session with whatever tags you think best describe it, and people can find your session using the same tags on the sessions page.

 

Blogging

Speaking of tagging, if you?re blogging about Portland Code Camp 2.0 (which I hope is the first thing you do after reading this email and registering to attend :), please use the tag ?pdxcodecamp? if you?re into that Technorati sort of thing. Blog about Code Camp and help spread the word!

 

Contributing

Looking for other ways to contribute besides blogging? If you would like to chip in to help make Portland Code Camp 2.0 happen, please email Stuart Celarier, Camp Director.  Time, ideas, effort and money are all appreciated.

 

Techevents.info

The kickoff of Portland Code Camp 2.0 is also the debut of Techevents.info, a site that provides free services for technical events like this one. Since the site is in ?beta? (a la Google) and this Code Camp is its first hosted event, there may be the occasional bug or two. If you run into issues, oddities, bugs, etc. please email me and let me know.

 

This discussion list (the Portland Code Camp Yahoo! group) will be sticking around a little while longer as we get forums and feeds going on the Techevents.info site. In the mean time, keep an ear on the list and an eye on the Portland Code Camp 2.0 site.


 

See you at Code Camp!

 

-Jason

Plesk is nice if not a bit spendy I am a fan of h-sphere and it gets rave
reviews in the web hosting industry as well. You really can't go wrong with
either of them in my opinion. I avoid theplanet like the pluage, they have
severe issues with being on e-mail blackhole lists and other less then
appealing issues.

If the service is absolutely mission critical then price shouldn't be an
option and I would personally go with rackspace in that situation, but you
do get to pay for them ;)

Serverbeach is a great dedicated host, they are extremely reliable and
inexpensive, they also offer plesk, cpanel or ensim with their packages
which start at 99.00 bucks. The one I quickly priced out was 129.00 with
plesk 7.1 plus a 59.00 setup fee bringing to startup total to 208 for the
first month and 129.00 each month after that. if your are unsure as to which
control panel you'd like you can talk to them and they will let you test out
the 3 that they offer.

there are a lot of options out there of course, but I've had great
experiances with both companies.

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Fri Jun  2 22:42:57 2006
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Fri, 2 Jun 2006 22:42:57 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Small Footprint CMS systems
Message-ID: <20060603054257.GA8526@gate.kl-ic.com>


Last night at the general PLUG meeting we had a little bit of
discussion about Content Management Systems (CMS).  Somebody
mentioned the sites http://cmsmatrix.org/ and http://cmswatch.org/
Interesting review sites, and a lot of data.  Thanks for the tip!
Not much size/resource/speed data, though.

I have an opportunity to deploy a very simple CMS for an educational
non-profit locally; there was an offer to host it on a Plone server
last night.  One portion of the sub-site may be maintained by middle
school students, and Plone's granular permission structure and
workflow management would be ideal. 

Also Plone is built on Zope and on Python, and while my heart
belongs to Perl, I suspect Perl and Python and Ruby are all a
little more tolerant of spotty security upgrades than the PHP
that the vast majority of the open source CMS's seem to be 
written on.  Maybe "good" PHP is secure, but how does one judge
the goodness of PHP code in a CMS?

If that Plone server offer doesn't work out, and the site must go
on a low cost virtual server, there will likely not be enough RAM to
run a big footprint CMS like Plone.  I was wondering if there are
any CMS's out there that have the same workflow as Plone, but are
known to have a small memory footprint.  Any suggestions?

Keith

PS - Assuming Apache and mail server and such are loaded, "footprint"
means how much more RAM is gobbled up when the CMS and supporting
tools are loaded, compared to when they are not.  Not a difficult
test, but quantitative (count the megabytes) as compared to "I have
a GByte of RAM and I don't notice it" kinds of non-answers.

> parent=gnu.gcj.runtime.ExtensionClassLoader{urls=[], parent=null}} at
> userInterface.Start.<clinit>() (Unknown Source)

>It's incomprehensible to me. Maybe someone else can figure out what
> went wrong.

Roughly translated:  The main thread of your program took exception to 
not finding a defined class named "sun.misc.Launcher".

Given the gnu.java messages about missing "sun.java" something, I would 
guess that the app may not be compatible with GNU's java (or at least 
that the version you have doesn't have everything it needs yet.)  It's 
possible that you can install that class and be done -- this assumes 
that sun's java classes will run on gnu's java (might work if it's 
turtles all the way down.)

You might have to get sun's Java, but check with the app's faq about jvm 
compatibility.

From sofar at foo-projects.org  Sat Jun  3 09:38:26 2006
From: sofar at foo-projects.org (Auke Kok)
Date: Sat, 03 Jun 2006 09:38:26 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Mounting iPod, gtkpod, and permissions
In-Reply-To: <20060602234513.c07b6492.johnxj@comcast.net>
References: <20060602234513.c07b6492.johnxj@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <4481BB02.5080204@foo-projects.org>

John Jason Jordan wrote:
> I finally managed to get my iPod reformatted with FAT32. iTunes on
> Windows can place files on it. However, I can't find the magic
> combination to get it mounted on Linux with appropriate permissions so
> gtkpod can read and write to it.
> 
> I can mount it and unmount it just fine. But when I try to sync music
> files to it with gtkpod I get various error messages, all indicating
> that writing to or reading from the iPod failed. Sometimes the error
> messages says I don't have permission. The reason I say there are
> various error messages is because I have tried various things and each
> one gives me somewhat different errors. It appears, however, that the
> main problem (probably the only problem) is permissions and ownership.
> I dimly recall going through this before.
> 
> It is /dev/sda2 mounted at /media/iPod.
> 
> Fixing it eludes me. I opened Krusader as root and peered at
> the /media/iPod folder. Originally it said that it was owned by root
> and that no one could read/write to it but root. Now, that doesn't make
> a lot of sense to me. Before the recent disasters at the Apple store I
> was able to read/write to it just fine with gtkpod once I mounted it,
> and that was as just plain ol' user jjj.
> 
> Another issue that confluxes me is that it is now formatted FAT32. I
> thought FAT32 had no ability to handle permissions and ownership.
> 
> Konqueror indicated that root was the owner of /media/iPod. I always
> log in as jjj, so I changed the ownership to jjj. However, that seems
> to be of little or no use.

it's all in the fstab line, the permissions of the mountpoint don't really 
matter, as they will be superposed by the permissions of the root node of the 
mounted filesystem as you mount it (a tad confusing, of course).

here's what my shuffle fstab line says:
/dev/sda1       /media/ishuffle             auto    noauto,user,rw 0 0

for an ordinarly ipod that would become:
/dev/sda2       /media/ishuffle             auto    noauto,user,rw 0 0


I let gtkpod handle the mounting/unmounting, and be done with it.

Auke

# from John Jason Jordan
# on Saturday 03 June 2006 10:35 am:

>I thought XML was XML. Does it
>matter what application created the XML?

And unicode is unicode.  It's just a bit more accessible than everybody 
making up their own binary formats, but that doesn't mean much if 
someone writes you a letter in Swahili.

XML is just a generic data container, so if you don't have a way to 
transform (i.e. via a treeform-specific xslt) to svg, then all you have 
is some data (albeit in a generic container format that's been hyped as 
the bee's knees.)

--Eric

> > need WAN-passthrough and suchlike.  Atcom and some others offer ATAs
> > with 4 FxS ports, or even a mix of FxO and FxS ports, with failover.
>
> Atcom doesn't seem to be as easy to find as the Sipura ATAs; froogle
> finds 33 matches for atcom (including about 8 that are really a book on
> dive travel locations!) where 'sipura spa-3000', a far more restrictive
> search, finds 26 completely relevant listings.
> 
> Is this a brand that you prefer? Where do you buy them?

Naw, it's just an inexpensive Chinese OEM-style critter that's useful if
you plan to sell lots or need something other than a 2-FxS ATA.

> > > Considering voice quality only, is the Digium card worth the extra
> > > bucks?
> > 
> > It's just as crappy as any other phone-line interface in my experience,
> > without the flexibility and reusability of a separate ATA.
> 
> Hmm. How do they get so much money for those cards, then? Maybe I should
> buy a x100p clone and a couple of FXS-only ATAs?

Digiums are low-volume and cheezy, but cheaper than Dialogic and they're
useful if you want it all integrated into one box.

> Yes, I need to handle faxes. My office is small, and I do some small but
> critical amount of faxing. For incoming faxes it looks like Asterisk can
> be configured to receive the doc, convert it to PDF and email it. That's
> very cool. But for the outgoing faxes, I guess I'll need a way to get
> those out. Unless I buy a scanner and plan to email PDFs...

You can assemble a system that way, but the fact is that a plain ol'
landline-connected FAX machine does the job, works even if the system's
down, and makes instant sense to anyone else who tries to use it.  One
of those Multifunction Peripherals covers it and gives you scanning and
color printing, too.

Also, FAX over VoIP is touch-and-go and isn't likely to improve much.

> All I need (as far as I know now) is thousands of extensions (VMboxes)
> with PIN protection, and maybe over-the-phone provisioning. All
> connections can be via SIP, so no analog interfaces will be required. I
> think a box in a colo cabinet would do the job, with a big RAID for
> storage.

Ya just gonna rent a termination number and pay by the minute?  Not a
bad way to do it, and you can rent terminations in other LATAs too, and
even a toll-free number.

> Thanks. This is useful.

Glad to hear it.

> Last night at the general PLUG meeting we had a little bit of
> discussion about Content Management Systems (CMS).  Somebody
> mentioned the sites http://cmsmatrix.org/ and http://cmswatch.org/
> Interesting review sites, and a lot of data.  Thanks for the tip!
> Not much size/resource/speed data, though.
> 
> I have an opportunity to deploy a very simple CMS for an educational
> non-profit locally; there was an offer to host it on a Plone server
> last night.  One portion of the sub-site may be maintained by middle
> school students, and Plone's granular permission structure and
> workflow management would be ideal. 
> 
> Also Plone is built on Zope and on Python, and while my heart
> belongs to Perl, I suspect Perl and Python and Ruby are all a
> little more tolerant of spotty security upgrades than the PHP
> that the vast majority of the open source CMS's seem to be 
> written on.  Maybe "good" PHP is secure, but how does one judge
> the goodness of PHP code in a CMS?
> 
> If that Plone server offer doesn't work out, and the site must go
> on a low cost virtual server, there will likely not be enough RAM to
> run a big footprint CMS like Plone.  I was wondering if there are
> any CMS's out there that have the same workflow as Plone, but are
> known to have a small memory footprint.  Any suggestions?
> 
> Keith
> 
> PS - Assuming Apache and mail server and such are loaded, "footprint"
> means how much more RAM is gobbled up when the CMS and supporting
> tools are loaded, compared to when they are not.  Not a difficult
> test, but quantitative (count the megabytes) as compared to "I have
> a GByte of RAM and I don't notice it" kinds of non-answers.

I am currently running kubuntu 5.10 BreezyBadger Release i386.

Checking https://wiki.kubuntu.org/KubuntuDapperKnownProblems

Look at about mid-page, Upgrading Problems.  It seems the upgrade wipes the 
desktop.  The work-around is:

sudo apt-get install kubuntu-desktop.

But if you look at the bug reports it seems that others had problems with the 
work-around.  And those others knew enough to respond to the requests for more 
information.

If I lost the desktop I would be without a computer, so I could not even get to 
ask a question.

What is a newbie to do? A stable, supported system is what I want, but getting 
it seems hazardous.

From carla at bratgrrl.com  Mon Jun  5 09:48:40 2006

On Monday 05 June 2006 9:04 am, Denis Heidtmann wrote:
> I am currently running kubuntu 5.10 BreezyBadger Release i386.

getting 
> it seems hazardous.

I just upgraded two Breezy systems to Dapper, one AMD-64 and one i386. I 
didn't experience anything like in the bug report. There were a few minor 
glitches, like printing is still fuxx0red but fixable, and some of my personal 
configs got stomped. So be sure your dotfiles and /etc are backed up. 

I did the upgrade the standard Debian way: edited my /etc/apt/sources.list to 
include only official Dapper repositories, did apt-get update, pt-get 
upgrade, and apt-get dist-upgrade. It went smoothly on both systems, even my 
highly-tortured main workstation which I use and abuse in all manner of 
creative ways.

I noticed that none of the sources.list examples in the bug reports included

deb http://kubuntu.org/packages/kde352 breezy main

You need that to get the correct KDE-Kubuntu packages.

I have never had my configs get overwritten by an upgrade in vanilla
debian. If I have made a modification to a system-wide configuration
file, I am notified and given the opportunity to choose the old file,
the new one, view a diff, or spawn a shell to examine the situation
myself. If I have made a modification to a config file in my home
directory, it is silently left as is.

   Well, the libs might have been istalled, but there were apparently many
required pieces missing. I downloaded the latest (2.3.95) fontconfig, built,

had me fooled.

From johnxj at comcast.net  Mon Jun  5 22:33:01 2006
From: johnxj at comcast.net (John Jason Jordan)
Date: Mon, 5 Jun 2006 22:33:01 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Linux and Unicode
Message-ID: <20060605223301.a5c75513.johnxj@comcast.net>

OK, supposedly my Ubuntu-64 Breezy computer is all Unicode compliant
and stuff. At the same time, evidently most of the programs I run on it
are not. The big ones seem to be - OpenOffice.org, Scribus, inter alia,
but some important little ones are messing up bigtime. On the other
hand, maybe the problem is not related to Unicode. I'd like to report
to the developers, but I'm not sure how to state the problem.

Case in point: Over the weekend I edited the tags for a little over 300
classical pieces before restoring them to my iPod. I used EasyTag. The
process went just fine. Except that before actually uploading them to
the iPod I needed to go to the university, which meant I had to close
EasyTag. The edited tags looked fine when I closed it, but when I
reopened it later many with "foreign" characters were badly hosed. You
don't want to know how Antonin Dvo??k's name came out. All I will say
is that I don't think he spelled his name with a copyright symbol. The
weird part is why the tags looked fine when I closed EasyTag, but after
EasyTag reopened the files, it displayed them incorrectly. I mean, if
it couldn't display the character properly, then why did it display
properly when I entered it from the keyboard?

I decided I'd just re-edit the offending tags in gtkpod before syncing
to the iPod. I opened gtkpod, but quickly noticed that I must have set
the "Always automatically screw things up" option to Yes. It took a
while, but I finally managed to get it to delete its database, which I
think was based on the files before I edited them. Then I re-opened all
the files. That was even worse. Everything that was not one of the keys
on an American typewriter came out as a space. Dvo??k came out Dvo  k.
So now we have a different issue -- EasyTag substitutes something else,
and gtkpod just deletes.

What I'm trying to figure out is what is going on. There are different
kinds of problems. Some programs react one way, some another. I read
all I can about Unicode, but the literature about Unicode on the net
does not explain what to do when applications can't take Unicode
characters. At least, I couldn't find it.

Does anyone have any idea what I am talking about?


From heinlein at madboa.com  Tue Jun  6 05:42:30 2006
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue, 6 Jun 2006 05:42:30 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Linux and Unicode
In-Reply-To: <20060605223301.a5c75513.johnxj@comcast.net>
References: <20060605223301.a5c75513.johnxj@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.OSX.4.64.0606060527050.1023@orange.madboa.com>

On Mon, 5 Jun 2006, John Jason Jordan wrote:

> OK, supposedly my Ubuntu-64 Breezy computer is all Unicode compliant 
> and stuff. At the same time, evidently most of the programs I run on 
> it are not. The big ones seem to be - OpenOffice.org, Scribus, inter 
> alia, but some important little ones are messing up bigtime. On the 
> other hand, maybe the problem is not related to Unicode. I'd like to 
> report to the developers, but I'm not sure how to state the problem.
>
> Case in point: Over the weekend I edited the tags for a little over 
> 300 classical pieces before restoring them to my iPod. I used 
> EasyTag. The process went just fine. Except that before actually 
> uploading them to the iPod I needed to go to the university, which 
> meant I had to close EasyTag. The edited tags looked fine when I 
> closed it, but when I reopened it later many with "foreign" 
> characters were badly hosed. [....]

In a terminal window (xterm or whatever you normally use), run the 
locale utility. It'll tell you what language and character set your 
shell environment are using. E.g.,

[/tmp]$ locale
LANG=en_US.UTF-8
LC_CTYPE="en_US.UTF-8"
LC_NUMERIC="en_US.UTF-8"
LC_TIME="en_US.UTF-8"
LC_COLLATE=C
LC_MONETARY="en_US.UTF-8"
LC_MESSAGES="en_US.UTF-8"
LC_PAPER="en_US.UTF-8"
LC_NAME="en_US.UTF-8"
LC_ADDRESS="en_US.UTF-8"
LC_TELEPHONE="en_US.UTF-8"
LC_MEASUREMENT="en_US.UTF-8"
LC_IDENTIFICATION="en_US.UTF-8"
LC_ALL=

If your LC_CTYPE variable doesn't end in '.UTF-8', then you're 
probably not getting full Unicode support. I've got some notes on all 
this online:

   http://www.madboa.com/geek/utf8/

One easy test is to launch EasyTag under temp environment:

   LANG=en_US.UTF-8 easytag

If that does the trick, then you'll want to alter your default shell 
environment.

If you still have troubles, let me know. Debian-based systems use some 
non-obvious tricks -- like relying on /etc/locale.gen -- that might 
need some explanation.

-- Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

Carla Schroder <carla at bratgrrl.com> dijo:

> > I think I know why my system is running sooooo slooooowly now.
> > I am currently burning a dapper cd to do a fresh install.

> That doesn't even make sense, because it's routine Debian maintenance to run 
> apt-get upgrade regularly. I have it in a daily cron job. That's how you get 
> updates and patches without pain, and keep everything current. At what magic 
> point must you stop before running a dist-upgrade? I'm starting to think 
> Ubuntu folks don't understand Debian very well.

A default installation of Ubuntu (since Hoary at least) installs the
"Updates" and "Security Updates" repositories, and whenever something
new shows up in one of them an icon appears on the Gnome panel. A user
who is even generally computer illiterate cannot help but click on it
to see where it came from and what it does, whereupon a window will pop
up telling the user there are updates available and prompting the user
to install them. This accomplishes the same thing as your daily cron
job function, yet the user doesn't even have to know what cron is. It's
features like this that make me love Ubuntu.

i've started a Joomla! site at work. What I found
frustrating was a lack of a 'dummies for mambo/joomla'
or more a basic 'here is how it works', after getting
over the how the pages/data relationships work, i have
been very happy, both with the FOSS modules and one
of the commercial < $50 modules.

for granularity the base install isn't very good, but
there is a module/plug-in that gives what I think you
are looking for.

i have not tried it yet, and i can not compare it to
other CMS's since this is my first.

From m0gely at telestream.com  Tue Jun  6 09:39:36 2006

Date: Tue, 06 Jun 2006 09:39:36 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Data Recovery Services in Portland
In-Reply-To: <00c701c6897f$46ca41f0$0501010a@billslaptop>
References: <00c701c6897f$46ca41f0$0501010a@billslaptop>
Message-ID: <4485AFC8.8000006@telestream.com>

Bill Ensley wrote:
> Did you say they formatted it???
> 
> I'm certain I'll be corrected on this, but isn't that kind of final?

No dude.  If you have a hard drive with sensitive info on it, and you 
want to be 100% sure that information will never be accessed, you 
destroy the drive.  Think drills, hammers, grinders, vice grips, stump 
grinders, whatever.  But those platters shouldn't be in recognizable form.

There are also bootable disks you can download to format the drive in 
such a manner as to make sure everything is really gone, but it never 
ceases to amaze me the the next level of recovery companies are able to 
achieve.

Bill,

For the most part it is final, but not really. You can't just throw a 
live cd in and read the old contents. You have to remove the platters 
from the drive and they have to be read from special readers. I do not 
know of anyone who has this kind of service, though. It is VERY 
expensive, at least it used to be. It is doubtful that this user would 
want to spend the money on getting his files back, since he so easily 
made the decision to format the drive.

> On Fri, 2 Jun 2006 07:10:12 -0700
> "Dan Young" <danielmyoung at gmail.com> dijo:
>
> > > <Regarding TreeForm> ... I can't figure out how to launch it.
>
> > If you can find a somefile.jar file, try:
> >
> > java -jar /path/to/somefile.jar

<snip>

>However, if I try to export as JPG or PNG it gives me an error message that I
> did not allocate enough memory to Java to complete the operation. So one
> solution would be to figure out something to add to the launch command above
> to make it use more RAM (I've got 1.25 GB).

java -Xms=128 -Xmx=256 -jar /path/to/somefile.jar

-Xms is the initial ammount of memory to allocate, -Xmx is the max
size to use (of the heap, for both).

Re: the version of Java you have installed, if it isn't actually a
version of Sun's java, expect very odd behavior.  Most likely you
installed GCJ, which is a great idea, but just isn't there yet. (I'm
not saying you should worry about this right now, but it's worth
keeping in mind.)

--Rogan

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Tue Jun  6 10:21:46 2006
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Tue, 6 Jun 2006 10:21:46 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Viewing OpenOffice.Org Source Code
Message-ID: <20060606172146.GA25651@gate.kl-ic.com>


Is there anyplace to view OpenOffice.Org source code online,
without downloading the source? 

In particular, I want to look at the source for the GammaLN
function in the spreadsheet "calc" or "sc";  for X < 1E-6 or
so, it is unnecessarily inaccurate, and there are negative
values of X where GammaLN should be computable but isn't. 
That should be a quick hack to fix, since there are good ways
to manipulate this function mathematically to ease computation
( what is GammaLN? it computes the natural logarithm of the
gamma function.  What is the gamma function?  See:
  http://mathworld.wolfram.com/GammaFunction.html )

Of course, there is an additional problem, if the calculation
returns the mathematically correct value of GammaLN, but Excel
does not, then some might complain about the difference.  Mostly,
though, Excel just burps up an error when given small or
out-of-range arguments, and failing less often is usually better.

Keith

Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs


From johnxj at comcast.net  Tue Jun  6 10:22:14 2006
From: johnxj at comcast.net (John Jason Jordan)
Date: Tue, 6 Jun 2006 10:22:14 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Linux and Unicode
In-Reply-To: <Pine.OSX.4.64.0606060527050.1023@orange.madboa.com>
References: <20060605223301.a5c75513.johnxj@comcast.net>
	<Pine.OSX.4.64.0606060527050.1023@orange.madboa.com>
Message-ID: <20060606102214.0cc21431.johnxj@comcast.net>

On Tue, 6 Jun 2006 05:42:30 -0700 (PDT)
Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com> dijo:

> In a terminal window (xterm or whatever you normally use), run the 
> locale utility. It'll tell you what language and character set your 
> shell environment are using. E.g.,
>
> If your LC_CTYPE variable doesn't end in '.UTF-8', then you're 
> probably not getting full Unicode support. I've got some notes on all 
> this online:

Thanks for that suggestion. My settings match yours exactly, except for
the COLLATE one, where you changed yours to C and mine is UTF-8, like
all the others. So I guess that is not where the problem lies.

>    http://www.madboa.com/geek/utf8/

Read it, didn't see anything that would help, but haven't taken the
time to go to the other links at the bottom of the page. Will explore
those later.

> One easy test is to launch EasyTag under temp environment:
> 
>    LANG=en_US.UTF-8 easytag
> 
> If that does the trick, then you'll want to alter your default shell 
> environment.

At first it didn't do the trick, but it did result in more information
about what is going on. EasyTag is set up to scan on startup the folder
where I keep my mp3s. (I'm also open to suggestions for other tag
editors, btw.)

So, having launched it with the above command, I scrolled to the files
for Dvo??k pieces, all of which started with Dvo??k. In case that did
not make it through the internet and our mail clients, that's
D,v,o,r-hacek(hex=159),a-acute-accent(hex=E1),k. The filename displayed
correctly, but EasyTag had hosed each instance of his name in the tags.
I selected his name from the filename and copied it to the clipboard,
then pasted it over his name in the tags, so each tag was now correct.
Then I saved all the changed tags. After saving each tag still looked
correct. Then I exited from EasyTag. After exiting I looked at the
terminal window and found the following very interesting error message
(repeated for each tag that I changed):

Updated tag of 'Dvo??k - Symphony #8 (Pe?ek).mp3'

** (easytag:17119): WARNING **: convert_string(): Failed conversion
from charset  'UTF-8' to 'ISO-8859-1'. String 'Dvo\305\231\303\241k -
The Golden Spinning Whe el'. Errcode 1 (Invalid byte sequence in
conversion input).

I deliberately selected this particular error message because on this
one I also had an s-hacek in the conductor's name. It appears that the
terminal window understands the characters. It also appears that
EasyTag was trying to convert UTF-8 to ISO-8859-1, whatever that is.

But in the middle of writing this I decided to reopen EasyTag and see
if I could fix it. Lo and behold, in the Preferences section there was
a checkmark next to "Convert characters to ISO 8859-1 (Recommended)."
Underneath was an option to convert from UTF-8 to whatever I wanted to
enter in a drop-down box. I changed it to convert from UTF-8 to UTF-8.
Then I re-edited the Dvo??k tags and saved them. And then I looked in
the terminal window and voil?! No error messages.

So the problem with EasyTag seems to be resolved. I have gone through
and fixed all the tags (again) and now EasyTag is saving them correctly.

> If you still have troubles, let me know. Debian-based systems use some 
> non-obvious tricks -- like relying on /etc/locale.gen -- that might 
> need some explanation.

The next trick will be to open gtkpod and see what happens when it sees
the files. Gtkpod is a big mystery to me. I know that some of its
features are broken -- e.g., editing tags. You can select in
Preferences to write back any tag edits to the file on disk, but it
does not do so. (Hence needing EasyTag.) More importantly, there is no
documentation and I find it hopelessly unintuitive. I don't understand
what the functions mean or even what is supposed to be displayed in
what window. But at least if it does not see the tags correctly, I'll
try launching it with the LANG= syntax from the command line. 

Thanks for the help. Making progress!

From m0gely at telestream.com  Tue Jun  6 10:46:10 2006
From: m0gely at telestream.com (m0gely)
Date: Tue, 06 Jun 2006 10:46:10 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Data Recovery Services in Portland
In-Reply-To: <4485B098.4010902@rocksolidservice.com>
References: <00c701c6897f$46ca41f0$0501010a@billslaptop>
	<4485B098.4010902@rocksolidservice.com>
Message-ID: <4485BF62.6020104@telestream.com>

Christian Bewley wrote:

> You have to remove the platters 
> from the drive and they have to be read from special readers.

If the drive doesn't power up then maybe.  On a normal functional drive 
that has been formated, even a few times, recovery of the deleted files 
is very easy using software readily available on the net.  Granted, it's 
a tedious task and not for the average joe, but any savvy administrator 
can do this.

Software to properly format the drive doesn't just format it.  It flips 
every bit on the drive several times to ensure the old information is 
not recoverable.  Normal formats do not do this. Even changing the file 
system from say, NTFS to EXT3 leaves things somewhat recoverable.

It should run fine, even with gnome or KDE. How much RAM do you have? 512 is 
great, 256 will work. Do you have a swapfile?

KDE has the nice ksysguard for a graphical view of all your running processes. 
If you don't have KDE, look for something similar. Or run 'ps -ejH' to get 
the command-line view of what's going on. Something is bogging your system 
down.

possible (e.g. after a disk wipe) I've never seen it actually done.

For all practical purposes one pass of writing zeroes is enough to
thwart a data recovery.

likely to be high.

> It has been almost a decade since the actual data save on the disk

> to zero' pattern on the

Good thing none of us are still using or maintaining any hardware and 
software more than a decade old.... I mean, mainframes just get 
replaced every 3 years, just like laptops, right? And nobody would ever 
have the time, or money, to reverse engineer out how to "read" the 
altered data patterns?

In my previous gig this year (!) I was writing snort-compatible IDS 
script algo's for circa 1992 (IIRC) DG/UX 5.4.1 88K *minis* that run 
inside some class B scale networks... the old boxen die much harder 
than the new cheapness, and if a piece of data is worth, oh, several 
million (or billion) dollars, it's not a good idea to underestimate the 
bizarre extremes people would take to reconstruct it.

:-D

Personally, I find a good 7 passes over the platters with a 
sledge-hammer to be quite effective, though safety goggles are a must. 
One can induce randomness of zeros and ones by flipping over the 
platters every pass with the sledgehammer, or, for the extremely 
paranoid, a *magnetized* sledgehammer head might be a good toy.

A sledgehammer also looks pretty darned cool in a server room, but if 
working with buggy OS's, may need to be placed inside a "break glass 
only in case of extreme server frustration" case.

-Bop

Portland, OR 97218

From ianburrell at gmail.com  Wed Jun  7 12:20:59 2006
From: ianburrell at gmail.com (Ian Burrell)
Date: Wed, 7 Jun 2006 12:20:59 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Fontconfig
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.63.0606071121040.2728@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.63.0606071121040.2728@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <d91f09cd0606071220j532e707ct38fd97c03384b8a2@mail.gmail.com>

On 6/7/06, Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> wrote:
>    Anyone here experienced with fontconfig? I installed -2.3.95 last week to
> make the installed fonts visible to The GIMP. Now the display fonts on most
> web pages (firefox-1.5.0.4) and in OO.o are terrible: jagged and difficult to
> read. I suspect that fontconfig has something to do with this, but I don't
> know how or what to do about it. However, uninstalling the application does
> not make the fonts anti-aliased and easy to read.
>
>    When I look at the docs, I get the impression that fontconfig is supposed
> to make all installed fonts available to those applications that cannot find
> them by themselves. This is apparently true for The GIMP. Now all installed
> fonts are available there.
>
>    Running fc-list shows me a huge list of fonts installed all over the place
> (not only /usr/X11R6/lib/X11/fonts/).
>
>    The poor rendition is hard on my eyes. I'd like to get the anti-aliased
> fonts back again. Suggestions wanted.
>

Is anti-aliasing working at all?  It is possible you didn't configure
anti-aliasing support when you built fontconfig.

Did you try rebuilding the font cache?  All the font directories have
a fonts.cache-1 file.  I wouldn't be surprised if the format changed
with the upgrade and the fonts aren't being found.  If the fc-list is
listing lots of fonts, then this may not be the problem.  The command
is fc-cache.

Next, check the fontconfig configuration in /etc/fonts.  You may have
overwritten the old configuration when installing it.

 - Ian

From tim.thorpe at gmail.com  Thu Jun  8 04:32:06 2006
From: tim.thorpe at gmail.com (Tim Thorpe)
Date: Thu, 8 Jun 2006 04:32:06 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Small Footprint CMS systems
In-Reply-To: <9AFECDC22C4D6942BDFFCBDFCDB27A97074ED9C8@cityemail.bit.city>
References: <9AFECDC22C4D6942BDFFCBDFCDB27A97074ED9C8@cityemail.bit.city>
Message-ID: <32c2f9130606080432v267e410fy89b1bbdd76f11135@mail.gmail.com>

I've tried plone in an EDU environment, unless you plan on being committed
long term, or have someone there who is willing to completely learn the
system It's probably best to avoid using it. Don't get me wrong, I love
plone, but it is a major piece of software in my opinion and does need some
TLC from time to time.

I know you want to shy away from bad PHP, but not all PHP is bad ;). Drupal
is a very low overhead CMS that is extremely extensible and easily managed,
it has a sharp learning curve but can be done in probably a month of
consistent use. It also has big words like taxonomy and that is always a
plus for school students (LOL). Another one that I really like to use is
Joomla, they have a great development group and what seems to be a very
stable strategy. both are PHP but to my knowledge neither of them have been
victim to large scale attacks.

> > Last night at the general PLUG meeting we had a little bit of
> > discussion about Content Management Systems (CMS).  Somebody
> > mentioned the sites http://cmsmatrix.org/ and http://cmswatch.org/
> > Interesting review sites, and a lot of data.  Thanks for the tip!
> > Not much size/resource/speed data, though.
> >
> > I have an opportunity to deploy a very simple CMS for an educational
> > non-profit locally; there was an offer to host it on a Plone server
> > last night.  One portion of the sub-site may be maintained by middle
> > school students, and Plone's granular permission structure and
> > workflow management would be ideal.
> >
> > Also Plone is built on Zope and on Python, and while my heart
> > belongs to Perl, I suspect Perl and Python and Ruby are all a
> > little more tolerant of spotty security upgrades than the PHP
> > that the vast majority of the open source CMS's seem to be
> > written on.  Maybe "good" PHP is secure, but how does one judge
> > the goodness of PHP code in a CMS?
> >
> > If that Plone server offer doesn't work out, and the site must go
> > on a low cost virtual server, there will likely not be enough RAM to
> > run a big footprint CMS like Plone.  I was wondering if there are
> > any CMS's out there that have the same workflow as Plone, but are
> > known to have a small memory footprint.  Any suggestions?
> >
> > Keith
> >
> > PS - Assuming Apache and mail server and such are loaded, "footprint"
> > means how much more RAM is gobbled up when the CMS and supporting
> > tools are loaded, compared to when they are not.  Not a difficult
> > test, but quantitative (count the megabytes) as compared to "I have
> > a GByte of RAM and I don't notice it" kinds of non-answers.
> >

From tim.thorpe at gmail.com  Thu Jun  8 04:46:31 2006
From: tim.thorpe at gmail.com (Tim Thorpe)
Date: Thu, 8 Jun 2006 04:46:31 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Data Recovery Services in Portland
In-Reply-To: <a18c5f3c9b3af0a066f9db75fb6006b9@opus1.com>
References: <00c701c6897f$46ca41f0$0501010a@billslaptop>
	<4485AFC8.8000006@telestream.com> <24484-40995@sneakemail.com>
	<448649E7.30901@dimstar.net> <44865DD7.1050502@foo-projects.org>
	<ca5165530606062319k53677ad0i4577f111a87faba4@mail.gmail.com>
	<a18c5f3c9b3af0a066f9db75fb6006b9@opus1.com>
Message-ID: <32c2f9130606080446v35bd5392ia1daa9d785c3364d@mail.gmail.com>

there is a lot of software out there that will allow you to recover some
files from formatted media, but if your really serious about it your best
bet is to get the professionals involved. Give http://www.ontrack.com/ a
look they have been able to do amazing things and have software available
that is able to undelete almost anything but you will pay for the pleasure.
Don't use the drive, if they have they are probably SOL, don't install the
ontrack software on to the same drive you're trying to recover, you will
just make things worse.

Moral of the story is don't format without backing up data ;).

GL.

On 6/7/06, Ronald Chmara <ron at opus1.com> wrote:
>
> On Jun 6, 2006, at 11:19 PM, Larry Brigman wrote:
> > On 6/6/06, Auke Kok <sofar at foo-projects.org> wrote:
> >> Russ Johnson wrote:
> >> > Steve Bonds wrote:
> >> >> Although I've heard rumors that such levels of data recovery are
> >> >> possible (e.g. after a disk wipe) I've never seen it actually done.
> >> >> Have you?
> >> > Yes. I used to work just outside the data recovery lab at Symantec.
> >> I've
> >> > also seen floppy disks reassembled after being cut with scissors.
> >> > I've even recovered data off hard drives, with shareware tools from
> >> > download.com, after the Windows 98 drive was nuked and paved with
> >> linux.
> >> >> For all practical purposes one pass of writing zeroes is enough to
> >> >> thwart a data recovery.
> >> > Obviously you've never realized why the DOD requires 7 passes of a
> >> data
> >> > scrambler for "secret" data, and more for "top secret".
> >> and as a matter of fact, writing all zeroes (or any regular pattern)
> >> is making
> >> it *very* easy to recover the data ;^)
> > It has been almost a decade since the actual data save on the disk
> > resembles the data
> > you want.  It all gets encoded to ensure that you have a 'non-return
> > to zero' pattern on the
> > disk.
>
> Good thing none of us are still using or maintaining any hardware and
> software more than a decade old.... I mean, mainframes just get
> replaced every 3 years, just like laptops, right? And nobody would ever
> have the time, or money, to reverse engineer out how to "read" the
> altered data patterns?
>
> In my previous gig this year (!) I was writing snort-compatible IDS
> script algo's for circa 1992 (IIRC) DG/UX 5.4.1 88K *minis* that run
> inside some class B scale networks... the old boxen die much harder
> than the new cheapness, and if a piece of data is worth, oh, several
> million (or billion) dollars, it's not a good idea to underestimate the
> bizarre extremes people would take to reconstruct it.
>
> :-D
>
> Personally, I find a good 7 passes over the platters with a
> sledge-hammer to be quite effective, though safety goggles are a must.
> One can induce randomness of zeros and ones by flipping over the
> platters every pass with the sledgehammer, or, for the extremely
> paranoid, a *magnetized* sledgehammer head might be a good toy.
>
> A sledgehammer also looks pretty darned cool in a server room, but if
> working with buggy OS's, may need to be placed inside a "break glass
> only in case of extreme server frustration" case.
>
> -Bop

I'm coming in late, but have you looked at Moodle? (moodle.org). It's
Apache/PHP/MySQL based and there's a packaged version for Windows with
EasyPHP if that's the way you want to go. The Moodle folks are *very*
security-conscious and I'm pretty sure if you use a stable and secure
Apache, PHP and MySQL underneath, you should be OK. I love it -- I use
it for two of my web sites.

From plancashire at ci.portland.or.us  Thu Jun  8 08:18:28 2006
