just a extra 5 cents

Joomla! is a spin off of Mambo. I found out quite a few
people have heard of Mambo but not Joomla!. There was
a split for some reason and the core developers of Mambo
forked and created Joomla!.

I'm not say Joomla! may be your best choice for a simple
CMS, but once you get over the learning curve and lack of
basic "how/why/etc" docs, it is quite powerful. That
power/capability comes with a pretty high price.

So far it is the only one I have any experience with

before). Its php, from what I've seem secure and its a small group of core
developers who listen to the community which is nice. It would force (if

From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Fri Jun  2 11:59:17 2006
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (plug_0 at robinson-west.com)
Date: Fri,  2 Jun 2006 11:59:17 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Squid Slackware 10.1 resolved...
Message-ID: <1149274757.44808a855b726@xerxes.robinson-west.com>

After breaking the fork in watch_child, it became clear in gdb 
that the permissions on squid's log directory were causing the 
abort.

Nowhere in the installation docs do I recall seeing a mention that
failing to set the correct permissions on the log directory will
make squid abort.

So if anyone out there is abandoning Slackware 10.1 thinking that
squid won't run on it, fix the ownership and permissions on it's 
log directory.  On my system, the ownership has to be set to 
squid.root mode 755.

I encourage the team that puts out the 2.5-STABLE14 source release of
squid to add a warning about permission problems before the first 
fork in the next release.  It would be so helpful if squid would 
dump a warning to /var/log/messages that the permissions on it's log 
directory are causing the abort.  The error message signal 6, abort,
isn't meaningful enough for a troubleshooter to figure out what is
wrong quickly.

Another thing for the squid team, where are the configure options 
documented in the source code?

Regards,

Michael C. Robinson

From heinlein at madboa.com  Thu Jun  8 15:26:49 2006
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu, 8 Jun 2006 15:26:49 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Dansguardian on slackware 10.1...
In-Reply-To: <1149286062.4480b6ae2828f@xerxes.robinson-west.com>
References: <1149286062.4480b6ae2828f@xerxes.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.OSX.4.64.0606081508251.7329@arrowhead.galois.com>

On Fri, 2 Jun 2006, plug_0 at robinson-west.com wrote:

> Redhat, Suse, Debian, MacOSX, ... aren't these all system V init 
> style systems?

To the extent that OS X uses a standard Unix init style, it's BSD, not 
SysV.

Apple, however, is moving as much init functionality as possible into 
the darwin SystemStarter utility. The launchd(8) man rather explictly 
notes, "At some point in the future, we hope to completely phase out 
the use of rc."

> I'm trying to install dansguardian from source on slackware shoving 
> all it's files under /opt.  When I try dansguardian, it neither 
> crashes nor starts.

To me, this looks like your problem has nothing to do with init style. 
I know nothing about dansguardian, but I assume you've installed and 
configured a proxy (squid/tinyproxy), right? Is the proxy working? Do 
you get a help screen if you type "dansguardian -h"? Have you tried 
running dansguardian under strace?

-- 
Paul Heinlein <> heinlein at madboa.com <> www.madboa.com

> I'm looking at Asterisk as a replacement for mgetty-voice.  The Fedora

> Regards,

I'm far from expert, but I've implemented some Asterisk systems and written a 
small bale of howtos. The short answers are:

- you don't need anything other than ordinary PC hardware and some kind of IP 
phone. For cheep testing and even production use, get some decent-quality USB 
telephone headsets. Then you don't even need a soundcard.
-your server will run Asterisk, and the clients can use the XTen Lite 
softphone. It's free and it's very nice.
- you don't need a modem at all, and I hope you're not thinking of trying to 
run VoIP over dialup, because that's not enough bandwidth. You need broadband 
Internet for IP telephony
-Asterisk is so flexible you can implement it just about any way you want to

The howto series is here  http://www.voipplanet.com/asterisk/
The series starts out with Asterisk at Home, which is now called Trixbox. It is a 
great iPBX bundle, but there is not a clear relationship between its 
graphical configuration managers and the underlying config files, so I'm 
moving the series to plain-vanilla Asterisk.

Carla

From sofar at foo-projects.org  Thu Jun  8 15:38:58 2006
From: sofar at foo-projects.org (Auke Kok)
Date: Thu, 08 Jun 2006 15:38:58 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Possible hack attempt on my server
In-Reply-To: <004801c68b4a$325aa580$0501010a@billslaptop>
References: <004801c68b4a$325aa580$0501010a@billslaptop>
Message-ID: <4488A702.60600@foo-projects.org>

Bill Ensley wrote:
> This list won't allow me to attach the file.
> 
> They didn't actually manage to get in, they just
> Used my uploader to upload the file.
> 
> I just wanted to know if anyone knows what it is.
> 
> I did find it elsewhere on the internet it is called
> 
> Bab.php


if it's the one linked #1 on google for "bab.php" then sure, it's dangerous. 
It's basically a swiss knife backdoor that -once activated- tries a bunch of 
known vulnerabilities and sets up show for you. It doesn't try any rootkitish 
type of things but most zombie networks don't care about root - only about 
getting a network connection up to establish a connection.

( http://www.neurotransmitter.net/wiki/tiki-download_file.php?fileId=15 )

Having one of these on your webserver is not the end - the script may not have 
been activated or used yet (only uploaded), but you should carefully monitor 
network connections and integrity of your network tools. A good Audit is required.

Auke

John Jason Jordan wrote:
> I meant to ask before, wouldn't it be easier/cheaper just to get a
> plain ol' turntable, plug it into the computer input jacks, and use
> software to convert the input to something electronic? Or does such
> software not exist?

Such software exists and is common, but you also have to apply an eq 
curve to the phono output (which you can do in software too), unless 
your soundcard happens to have a phono input, which seems unlikely. 
Routing the audio through your regular stereo that has a phono input and 
a line output might be easier.

--Brent

From rsteff at comcast.net  Thu Jun  8 19:42:30 2006
From: rsteff at comcast.net (Richard C. Steffens)

John Jason Jordan wrote:

> I meant to ask before, wouldn't it be easier/cheaper just to get a
> plain ol' turntable, plug it into the computer input jacks, and use
> software to convert the input to something electronic? Or does such
> software not exist?

As Brent said in his reply, the kind of signal the cartridge on the 
turntable puts out must be considered. There are (or where, anyway) 
ceramic cartridges which could be connected to Aux ports, but the better 
cartridges are magnetic and need a proper "Phono" input. The USB 
turntable has three options, USB, line level audio, and phono cartridge 
level audio. In analog mode it can be plugged into the line in jack on a 
computer sound card, or it can be used with a stereo system that has 
phono jacks.

I used to do this with a Dual 12-mumble-mumble, until it died. Having it 
repaired is not cost effective -- I've done it once already, and expect 
it would need doing again, periodically. Also, I haven't upgraded my 
stereo equipment since the late 1970's or early 1980's, and while the 
old Kenwood amp/pre-amp works well, it's not as convenient to use with a 
computer. With the USB turntable, I'll be able to record an LP on one 
computer while working on another at the same desk. There are too many 
pieces involved with running through the old Dual turntable. Having the 
Audacity software listening to the turntable will make the process 
smoother, too.

I did make good recordings with the old setup, though. I plugged the 
line out of the stereo amp into the line in of my Creative Labs sound 
card and ran gramofile on my 200 MHz RH 7.0 machine. After recording, I 
ran the clean up filters supplied with gramofile and then converted the 
.wav file to .mp3 with bladeenc. Both of these programs are run from the 
command line. I'll be interested to see how Audacity handles the 
process. It would be nice if it can record an LP, clean it up, and 
convert it to .mp3 with flipping the platter over being the only thing I 
have to do besides hit start. I realize that I'll have to do some 
tweaking of record levels and such up front, though.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Thu Jun  8 20:41:16 2006
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Thu, 8 Jun 2006 20:41:16 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] CSS Color Quirk -- VIEWING ANGLE
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.63.0606061216370.22745@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <011b01c6899b$d4bb03c0$0501010a@billslaptop>
	<Pine.LNX.4.63.0606061212150.22745@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	<Pine.LNX.4.63.0606061216370.22745@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20060609034116.GA22937@gate.kl-ic.com>

On Tue, Jun 06, 2006 at 12:17:54PM -0700, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Tue, 6 Jun 2006, Rich Shepard wrote:
> >>Does it change when you change your viewing angle?
> > No.
>   Er, ... when I duck down, the viewing angle changes and so does the
> apparent color. Sonofagun! Haven't seen this one before -- literally.

This is something to consider when buying any kind of LCD flat panel;
monitor/TV/laptop/DVDplayer.  LCDs are not isotropic - there are 
tradeoffs between contrast and speed and viewing angle, both in the
horizontal and vertical direction (separately for each).  A monitor
that is good for video games is probably lousy for page proofing.

That said, if you are designing a website, you should probably design
it to look good on a monitor that is lousier than your clients will 
be using.  That restricts size, colors, and animation.  My friends
that design professional webpages have 4 or 5 monitors in front of
them, so they can see as many versions of lousy as possible.

Keith

In reference to your earlier post, Dick, my understanding is that the USB 
turntables that were available were not USB2.0 and the new ones will be.

I'm kind of holding out for that.

The rest of this is a long explanation of my home audio needs.  I'll be 
shocked if anyone reads it, but I'm desperate to avoid writing a paper on 
group cohomology.

On Thu, 8 Jun 2006, Richard C. Steffens wrote:
> John Jason Jordan wrote:
>> I meant to ask before, wouldn't it be easier/cheaper just to get a 
>> plain ol' turntable, plug it into the computer input jacks, and use 
>> software to convert the input to something electronic? Or does such 
>> software not exist?

Of course, you can do that.  However, I'm looking to minimize hardware 
while still maintaining flexibility of format.  So I will be replacing my 
nice direct-drive Gemini turntable with something that can be used to rip 
audio digitally.  I believe that the AD converter in the turntable will be 
high quality and I won't have to worry about analog signal going through 
cables and minijack ports.

In the end, I'm hoping to just output to amplified speakers from general 
purpose computers while still maintaining my modest collection of vinyl 
(there are a handful of CDs and cassettes I'll keep for completism, but 
none of the cassettes contain anything I don't also have on CD, so access 
to the data is not important).

I would love to find a PC minidisc drive, but they've gone with the auk, 
methinks.  I guess the other option is to get a nice digital recorder to 
replace my portable minidisc recorder.  Fuck.

> I used to do this with a Dual 12-mumble-mumble, until it died. Having it 
> repaired is not cost effective -- I've done it once already, and expect 
> it would need doing again, periodically.

Yeah, when I finally got sick of the belts slipping on my old cruddy 
turntable, I set out to buy a new one.  I was kind of shocked to find that 
there's no such thing as an inexpensive turntable these days.  There are 
nice ones and outrageously nice ones.  Turns out the things are marketted 
only to DJs and audiophiles.  I went to a DJ shop and ended up spending a 
few hundred dollars about seven years ago.  The quality is quite good, but 
my needs are changing.

I'm trying to simplify my life (and prepare for the move to grad school 
living conditions) by divesting myself of material things.  I've come to 
find that I don't really use any of my VHS cassettes, DVDs, CDs, or 
cassettes anymore.  I play audio in five locations:  The living room, my 
bedroom, the TV room, the kitchen, and my bicycle garage.

In the living room, I have a complete stereo system with the one 
turntable, the CD, cassette, and minidisc decks, a radio tuner, and a 
Turtle Beach Audiotron which mounts shared filesystems on my house 
computer network and accesses audio found there for playback.  The only 
things that aren't just collecting dust are the audiotron and the 
turntable.

My bedroom has my personal computer conected to bookshelf stereo system 
that houses an MD deck, CD player, and radio tuner.  This particular 
bookshelf system does have a phono connection as well as digital 
input/output.  [Holy crap, I might be able to just use this as my 
interface point and ditch everything else and not by the USB turntable.  I 
didn't even think about that until doing this dumb inventory and actually 
checking the capabilities of all the equipment.  I think I just made 
myself very happy -- assuming I can get the digital audio to play nice 
with my sound card's i/o.]

The TV room is where I keep my modified XBox which mounts the shared 
network filesystems and plays the audio found there.

The garage and kitchen both have amplified speakers connected to iPod 
docks.  Since my iPod contains all of the audio on my personal computer's 
shared system, this gives us most of what's on the network (everything 
except the stuff on the neighbors' shared filesystems which are part of 
our local network) and also gives me good opportunity to charge my iPod 
without thinking about it.

So, yeah.  I just need some means of putting my vinyl, CDs, and MDs on the 
network or the iPod.  Direct playback from those storage media is neither 
necessary nor desirable.

> There are too many pieces involved with running through the old Dual 
> turntable. Having the Audacity software listening to the turntable will 
> make the process smoother, too.

I heard from a friend who went through the process of digitizing his vinyl 
that there was some feedback and noise introduced by running the turntable 
(with a rather sensitive magnetic cartridge) near the computer systems. 
He went through the trouble of setting up the turntable far away and then 
running straight, high-quality analog lines into his fancy soundcard.

> I did make good recordings with the old setup, though. I plugged the 
> line out of the stereo amp into the line in of my Creative Labs sound

> process. It would be nice if it can record an LP, clean it up, and 
> convert it to .mp3 with flipping the platter over being the only thing I 
> have to do besides hit start. I realize that I'll have to do some 
> tweaking of record levels and such up front, though.

And you'll probably end up manually applying the track cuts.

I gotta say, I ripped my entire CD collection (only about 500 discs) in 
one weekend (with fairly meticulous metadata entry and cross-checking, 
though there are still a handful of errors that I find now and again).  I 
think the vinyl will take much longer even though I have a tenth as many 
discs.

I guess instead of looking into the USB turntable, my next step will be 
trying to get the digital input from the bookshelf system into the 
soundcard on my PC.

Interestingly, I bought this bookshelf system in the first place because 
it has a PS/2 keyboard port for titling minidiscs.  How badass is that?  I 
was disappointed to learn that the keyboard couldn't be used as a general 
purpose editting console, though.  Seems like it would have been just as 
easy to define the function keys to do some or all of the things that the 
remote control keys do.

I found gramofile to be somewhat good about finding track cuts. I didn't 
have to manually apply all of them, but did have to on about 1/4 of 
them. I could tell by the count of tracks it came up with whether I'd 
need to or not, and then look at the longer ones to finish the process. 
At first, I thought I'd be ignoring track cuts, since most of the music 
I have is classical and I normally wouldn't be interested in some 
interior track by itself. But, I found there were times it was something 
I wanted.

I'd be interested in your file organization philosophy. I have my 
collection organized in directories according to genre first, then 
within the genre by composer, and within the composer by album. I use 
mpg123 for playback and it will work with a play list file, so for each 
album I have a .lst file with the individual tracks listed in the order 
they appear. Most of the tracks have a leading track number with leading 
zeros on those with more than nine tracks, but some just have names. The 
.lst file allows the unnumbered tracks to be played in the desired order.

for mgetty-voice that works better.  I don't want to buy an answering 
machine, I'd rather have my messages be lan accessible.  Asterisk
doesn't seem to be intended for building public switched telephone 
network answering systems.  For those who have a fax line, it makes 
sense to play a message in case a customer/etc. mistakes it for their 
voice line.  I've been watching what is said about Asterisk.  Clearly,
a traditional POTS line for faxing is repeatedly being recommened over
a VoIP line.  With all this pressure towards having a POTS line,
why isn't there more effort to improve vgetty?  None of the current
documentation seems to address configuring vgetty properly to detect 
being hung up on.  When someone doesn't want to leave a message, they 
are more than likely to just hang up.  If the phone company wouldn't
use such a high pitched ear splitting recording, this problem wouldn't
be so annoying.

Regards,

Michael C. Robinson

Subject: [PLUG] Apache auth requirements based on Content-Type?
Message-ID: <Pine.OSX.4.64.0606091127290.7645@arrowhead.galois.com>

I've got a wiki on a public web server. It currently requires HTTP 
Digest authentication to access any content.

The wiki provides RSS feeds, and some users would like to be able to 
access those without authentication. Some aggregators, it seems, don't 
have secure ways to store and use username/password data.

The only safe way I can imagine to implement this would be to get 
Apache to remove authentication and authorization requirements when a 
document's Content-Type header is set to 'application/rss+xml'.

Does anyone know if that sort of thing is possible? If so, any clues 
would be welcome.

I have an Xbox that runs linux. I do not use xbox live. I prefer the free
alternatives like xbconnect or better yet xlink kai. There are two main
flavors of mods, softmod and hardmods. A mod chip simply adds an alternative
BOIS to your system, which you can enable or disable. If you boot with the
retail BIOS, you can still login to xbox live and play without issues. On
older xboxs you can simply replace the retail BIOS with a hacked BIOS, but
this will ruin your xobx for xbox live. For me xbox live does not matter, so
I replaced the retail BIOS with a hacked one. The reason I am using an xbox
with linux is because it is a cheap ($75 - $100) computer with TV out, and I
am using the xbox for a remote frontend for MythTV. It works great and is
easy to setup. I have even posted a torrent file for the xebian distribution
that I am using with MythTV installed and mostly configured. The beauty of
the xbox is that they are all the same (bassically) and that you can just
take a linux dist from one to another an it runs with little tweaking.
-- 
Rob Anderson
riznob at gmail.com

From: bsr at spek.org (Brent Rieck)

Subject: [PLUG] google firefox sync..

Bill Ensley wrote:
> Until Google caves and gives ALL
> 
> Of your precious stored bookmarks, cookies, etc, and even your currently
> open tabs
> 
> To the Government.

http://www.google.com/tools/firefox/browsersync/faq.html#q10

What's the point of encrypting my information?

By encrypting your information, it will be transmitted to and stored on 
Google's servers in a format that is nearly impossible to interpret 
without the PIN. That means that without the PIN, no one, not even 
Google, will be able to read your data. Therefore, it's important to 
choose a good PIN (at least 8 characters including both numbers and 
letters) that's hard to guess and to keep your PIN safe. Note that 
encrypting all of your browser settings may affect the performance of 
Google Browser Sync and Firefox.

Considering that the NSA is directly tapping AT&T's network, having my 
browser configuration, history, and bookmarks stored in an encrypted 
format on Google's servers doesn't particularly concern me.

--Brent

I've always assumed that this (collapsing multiple slashes together)
was a feature.  I certainly appreciate the fact that I can type
something like: "ls ./whatsit//whatever" and have it work.

Things like this happen when you use both tab completion and !'s, like this:

ls ./whatsit/       # (tab completion puts the final '/' on.)
ls !:1/whatever # (while I stick the '/' in, just to keep from
confusing myself.)

which resolves to:

ls ./whatsit//whatever

Ali

Not quite.  There is definitely something "unique" about bash:

Newton:~ jrmartin$ cd /
Newton:/ jrmartin$ cd //
Newton:// jrmartin$ cd ///
Newton:/ jrmartin$ cd ////
Newton:/ jrmartin$ cd /
Newton:/ jrmartin$ cd ///
Newton:/ jrmartin$ cd //
Newton:// jrmartin$ csh
[Newton://] jrmartin% pwd
/
[Newton://] jrmartin% cd
[Newton:~] jrmartin% cd /
[Newton:/] jrmartin% cd //
[Newton:/] jrmartin% cd ///
[Newton:/] jrmartin% cd ////
[Newton:/] jrmartin% cd //
[Newton:/] jrmartin% cd
[Newton:~] jrmartin% exit
exit
Newton:// jrmartin$ cd
Newton:~ jrmartin$ tcsh
[Newton:~] jrmartin% cd //
[Newton:/] jrmartin% exit
exit
Newton:~ jrmartin$ cd //
Newton:// jrmartin$ tcsh
[Newton://] jrmartin% exit
exit
Newton:// jrmartin$

This is a Mac, BTW.  Notice the command prompt differences.  Only
double slashes ("//") is affected.

On 6/9/06, Robert Jeffrey Miesen <bobby_miesen at yahoo.com> wrote:
>
> Hi.
>
>         I was navigating my system today and instead of typing in "cd /",
> I typed
> in "cd //". Much to my suprise, I went to a directory called '//'. It's
> contents seem to be the same as that of the root directory, but I find the
> two backslashes to be quite weird. Can anybody replicate this behavior on
> their system and/or tell me more about this "Double-root" directory?
>
>         Thanks in advance.


It's supposed to work that way.  It's sort of a convenience or "feature" ;-)

Try 'ls -l //home//username', for example.  Same as 'ls -l /home/username'.
Kind of a nice feature when you're trying to concatenate strings in a shell
script and don't want to create three or four constants for the same meaning
-- "home", "home/",  "/home" and "/home/" -- when just plain HOME="/home/"
will get things done.

On Fri, 09 Jun 2006 08:51:58 -0700
Wil Cooley <wcooley at nakedape.cc> dijo:

> On Tue, 2006-06-06 at 10:22 -0700, John Jason Jordan wrote:
> > So the problem with EasyTag seems to be resolved. I have gone through
> > and fixed all the tags (again) and now EasyTag is saving them correctly.

> Have you actually copied them to your iPod?  Do they display correctly
> there?  It's possible that the reason EasyTag recommended converting to
> ISO-8895-1 is that portable players might not be as likely to support
> Unicode.  But who knows?  My Treo+PocketTunes does Unicode just fine.

Yep. The iPod understands the Unicode tags and displays them properly.
And so does gtkpod now. And I have gtkpod a bit better understood now,
too. (Hint to gtkpod people: DOCU-effing-MENTATION!!!)

Part of the problem was my hopeless confusion about how to use gtkpod.
There were these two selections on the left, iPod and Local. I never
new why stuff appeared in one and not the other sort of randomly. I
finally figured out that gtkpod creates its own databases, independent
of the iTunes database on the iPod. "Local" means that gtkpod will
build a database of stuff I have on my computer, because it thinks I
want to use it to play music. And "iPod" means it will build a database
of stuff that is (or is about to be) on the iPod. What I had been doing
all this time was ignoring those two items because I had no idea what
they meant. So when I would Add Files sometimes one would be selected,
sometimes the other.

And then, because some of the tags were encoded incorrectly, due to the
UTF-8 problem with EasyTag, I re-added some of them after I fixed them
with gtkpod's editing tool. But then I discovered that gtkpod has a bug
-- the option to save tag edits back to the file on disk does not work.
It did fix the file on the iPod, however. Since it wasn't saving the
tag edits to the file, I stopped using gtkpod for editing tags. But by
that time my iPod was a total mess. I had duplicates all over the
place, many with wrong tags, some of the ones that weren't duplicated
also had wrong tags. I started going using gtkpod to go through the
list and try to clean them up and finally decided that 317 files was
going to take forever.

That's the point when I decided to use EasyTag for all of them and
forget about gtkpod's editing mis-capabilities. And once I got EasyTag
working properly with Unicode I went through all 317 files on disk and
fixed all the tags. (Problem is that classical music usually has no
tags at all, and when it does, they are not what I want.) Then I
plugged in my pocket drive and copied the whole folder of mp3s to it
for backup, in anticipation of what I was planning on doing to the iPod.

So once I got all the tags properly edited and the backups made, I
launched gtkpod without the iPod mounted. Then I deleted both gtkpod's
Local and its iPod databases. (This is time-consuming, you can't Select
All and hit the delete button -- they have to be deleted one at a time.)
Finally, with both databases empty I closed gtkpod, mounted the iPod,
and restarted gtkpod. Then I told gtkpod to read the iPod, which it
happily did, displaying the mess on the iPod. Doing this recreates the
iPod database in gtkpod. So then I proceeded to delete every last file
from the (new) iPod database. And then I hit Sync, which removed all
the files from the iPod. (This was scary; now you see why I was careful
to back up my new good files first.)

After Sync finished and my iPod was empty I shut down gtkpod, unmounted
the iPod, unplugged it, and verified that all music files were gone.
Then I plugged it back in, remounted it, re-opened gtkpod, and (making
sure the iPod button was selected, not Local), I told gtkpod to add all
the files from my [now perfectly tagged] mp3 collection. That took it a
while (14 GB). When it finished I told it to Sync. That took even
longer. But when it was done my iPod was all tidy and has all the music
on it with all the tags properly coded.

All is well in iPodlandia. iPodlandites are happy people now. (But
we're never going near an Apple store again.)

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sun Jun 11 08:52:13 2006
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sun, 11 Jun 2006 08:52:13 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] Web Site Display Issues Resolved
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.63.0606110822290.19250@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

   Although I cannot view my web site in IE, I believe that the header images
being displayed as rectangles instead of ellipses has been resolved. The help
came from Norway on a CSS discussion mail list. On the slim chance that there
are other folks here as naive as I was about graphic formats and how they're
displayed by various web browsers, I'll share what I learned.

   I never knew that transparency was not an all-or-nothing state (except in
politics, of course), but it isn't. With .jpg and RGB color .png images, the
transparency is dithered. IE can't handle this so it ignores the transparency
bits and displays the images as rectangles.

   Both .gif and 8-bit (indexed) .png images have transparency as a single, on
or off bit. IE apparently knows how to interpret the single bit so the images
(ellipses, in my case) display correctly. The .gif, of course, has jagged
edges to the curved lines, and it will also reduce colors to 4. I'm not sure
how to use The GIMP to produce 8-bit, 16-color .png files. I'm sure it's in
the color convert dialog box, but I still have to learn just how to do this.
Almost certainly, ImageMagick can do this, but 'identify' doesn't tell me
what I need to know about color depth and I don't know what component tool
will do the conversion properly.

   Anyway, I was sent transformed copies of the two problem images, and I've
put those up on the production web server. I hope that resolves the issue and
that folks using IE can see the site as I designed it and focus on the
content.

   FWIW, I'm pickled tink that a couple of folks on the CSS discussion list
told me that they think the site layout is very well done, particularly in
strict compliance with xhtml-1.0 and css-2.0. As an amateur such response is
nice. But credit where it's due: I was given very good, practical advice from
a denizen of this list with a profitable web-based business. Thanks, RP.

Rich

--

> > open tabs

> > To the Government.
>
> http://www.google.com/tools/firefox/browsersync/faq.html#q10
>
> What's the point of encrypting my information?
>
> By encrypting your information, it will be transmitted to and stored on
> Google's servers in a format that is nearly impossible to interpret
> without the PIN. That means that without the PIN, no one, not even
> Google, will be able to read your data. Therefore, it's important to
> choose a good PIN (at least 8 characters including both numbers and
> letters) that's hard to guess and to keep your PIN safe. Note that
> encrypting all of your browser settings may affect the performance of
> Google Browser Sync and Firefox.
>
> Considering that the NSA is directly tapping AT&T's network, having my
> browser configuration, history, and bookmarks stored in an encrypted
> format on Google's servers doesn't particularly concern me.

Charlie Schluting wrote:
> Carla Schroder wrote:
>   
>> I just upgraded two Breezy systems to Dapper, one AMD-64 and one i386. I 
>> didn't experience anything like in the bug report. There were a few minor 
>> glitches, like printing is still fuxx0red but fixable, and some of my personal 
>> configs got stomped. So be sure your dotfiles and /etc are backed up. 
>>     
>
>
> That's a serious problem with many Linux packaging systems. One of the
> main reasons I still say it isn't "enterprise ready."
>
> Does anyone know if this is expected with debian? Or is it a result of
> some ubuntu weirdness?
>
> -Charlie
>   


Well, I run Debian Sid (unstable), so there's really nothing to upgrade 
to.  But I've read many messages from users on the Debian mailing lists 
saying that they've upgraded their stable systems without problems -- 
that is, upgrading from an older stable release (like Woody) to the 
current stable release (Sarge), which would be more-or-less the 
equivalent of upgrading from Breezy to Dapper.  OTOH, apparently there 
is a lot of pain for people who run testing when it comes to releases.  
Many users' testing systems were completely broken when Sarge became 
stable and was replaced by Etch.  Supposedly, the devs are going to try 
to figure out how to smooth that transition next time around, when Etch 
becomes stable sometime later this century.  :-)

I'm becoming convinced that the way Arch Linux does it is best -- just 
track current, and there's no need to "upgrade" because you're always 
current.  This is somewhat akin to running Debian Sid.  The downside to 
these is that any given update could hose your system, so it's not 
really appropriate for the production ("enterprise-ready") systems.  But 
it removes the pain of needing to upgrade between releases.

--

From sofar at foo-projects.org  Mon Jun 12 08:31:35 2006
From: sofar at foo-projects.org (Auke Kok)
Date: Mon, 12 Jun 2006 08:31:35 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] automatic firewall rules adder?
In-Reply-To: <f4468cae0606120819h1e597418tcf0f688a54f7be3c@mail.gmail.com>
References: <448D8433.6070506@spek.org>
	<f4468cae0606120819h1e597418tcf0f688a54f7be3c@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <448D88D7.3030505@foo-projects.org>

Eli Stair wrote:
> I've got a few methods of doing that (though currently on a system
> that's being moved) I'll post some scripts/configs when it gets where
> its' going if this is still needed.

(note: this is not the only solution that was discussed before.)

A bit whacked together (but very stable) is my personal solution based on a 
small syslog replacement I wrote together with a few perl scripts:

you'll need some of these scripts:
   http://foo-projects.org/~sofar/scripts/ipblock.tar.bz2

and the logging daemon is here:
   http://lard.foo-projects.org/

the logging daemon replaces syslogd. You'll have to setup some rules to 
trigger a blocking script. I use something like this:

====== lard.conf snipplets:
# block people trying to log in with bad passwords
command "/usr/sbin/block-ip-from"
     log auth,authpriv.*
     match "sshd.*Failed password for (?:invalid|root|nobody|sshd|sys|operator)"

# smtp-log-based blocking: this blocks:
# 1) people using bad HELO/EHLO conversations
# 2) anyone listed in my selection of dnsbls
# 3) broken mailers
command "/usr/sbin/block-ip-from"
     log mail.info
     match "Service unavailable; .* blocked using"
     match "Helo command rejected"
     match "Improper use of SMTP command pipelining"
======

You can vary the blocking rules of course, using something that has a bit more 
leniency than blocking on the first try. Lard is just a very simple approach 
to this. People have written logtail-implementations which adds another layer 
on top of the syslog daemon etc. As complex as you want it ;^)

Cheers,

Auke

   What printcap file is smbd seeking and not finding? There's nothing in

From jonscully at gmail.com  Mon Jun 12 09:30:53 2006

	<53107f6e0606120851l4f37595dy6118ce4da697eb3@mail.gmail.com>
	<448D92C3.5090701@spek.org>
Message-ID: <53107f6e0606120930q2e58592bg728826f576ddca11@mail.gmail.com>

On 6/12/06, Brent Rieck <bsr at spek.org> wrote:
>
> I was thinking about that.. when does the size of this list become a
> problem?  Dozens, hundreds, thousands, or millions of entries?


Hard to say.  Would depend on the system.  However, the IP blocker has to
run through the list for each attempted contact of port 22.  If the log file
shows five new IPs per night (pretty average, here), within five nights,
that's 25 IPs to walk through for each access, and so on.  Each attacker
will typically run through many attempts (apache, admin, john, nobody, root,
etc.), for each target.

Besides (for me), the point of port-knocking isn't so much to block IPs as
it is to keep the log files un-cluttered ;)

From raanders at acm.org  Mon Jun 12 09:36:38 2006
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Mon, 12 Jun 2006 09:36:38 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] automatic firewall rules adder?

Message-ID: <448D9816.4030409@acm.org>

Brent Rieck wrote:
> Hello,
>   I seem recall somebody here mentioning a program that would scan your 
> log files for failed login attempts via ssh and then add those IP 
> addresses to your firewall rules.  Was I dreaming?  Or does such a 
> program already exists?

There are two that I am familiar with.  Denyhosts.py: monitors a log 
file ( secure, messages, etc. ) via a crontab call therefore can only 
check every minute and looks for repeated failed attempts to ssh in in a 
selected time period.  If found the IP is placed in /etc/hosts.deny 
which sshd uses.

The other is 'fut'.  I still haven't taken the time to get it running on 
a system so I'm not positive on how it works exactly but it appears to 
be more real time.  It is attached to a named pipe and watches for ssh 
floods and puts the IP in an iptables rule for several minutes then 
removes it.
    As it is written in perl it will be easier for me to hack so wins 
another few points.


Rod

From pmvw at wbcable.net  Mon Jun 12 17:58:49 2006
From: pmvw at wbcable.net (Piet van Weel)
Date: Mon, 12 Jun 2006 17:58:49 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Off Topic: Helping ultra-newbie (with Windows)?
In-Reply-To: <20060612203020.43838.qmail@web52709.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20060612203020.43838.qmail@web52709.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <448E0DC9.6030607@wbcable.net>

Jon LeVitre wrote:
> I was thinking of sending him a CD with the latest OpenOffice, Firefox,
> AdAware, Spybot S&D, etc.  Is there anything else I should put on it?
> (anti-viris software, perhaps?)
>   

Hmmm... Interesting question...

The first thing to do is to get all the Microsoft updates.
http://update.microsoft.com
(Including the annoying Authentication, but hey you paid for it!)

Then I generally load the following on Windows boxes:
ccleaner   (http://www.ccleaner.com)
Avast anti-virus  (http://www.avast.com) (Free Registration & Updates)
AdAware (http://www.lavasoftusa.com)
Spybot S&D (http://www.safer-networking.org/en/index.html)
Firefox (http://www.mozilla.org)
Thunderbird (http://www.mozilla.org/thunderbird)
Open Office (http://www.openoffice.org)
SmartFTP (http://www.smartftp.com)
Trillian IM (http://www.ceruleanstudios.com)

Make sure you do the setup on all these programs.
Programs such as Avast and Spybot are MULTI-STAGE configurations.
Make sure you guide him through the correct setup. :)

Piet van Weel

"Eric Biggs" <eric.biggs at hotmail.com> dijo:

> I'm new and have questions that I think can only be answered by people here,

In cooperation with Free Geek we have Clinics at the Free Geek facility
on the third Sunday of each month. That means this coming Sunday, June
18. Mostly people bring their computers to get help with Linux.
Sometimes they haven't installed Linux yet and want help doing so. But
you are welcome to come to the Clinic even if you have not yet
installed Linux and are not yet ready to do so. You don't necessarily
even have to bring your computer. Feel free to show up, wander around,
look at people who have Linux on their computers, talk to newbies and
old hands, ask questions, and generally hang around and soak up stuff.
I'll be there too. And even though I'm relatively new to Linux, I
promise to answer any questions that I know the answer to. And I bring
cookies.

On Mon, 12 Jun 2006, Jon LeVitre wrote:
> Other than buying him a copy of Windows for Dummies (and telling him the 
> title is a joke), does anybody have any advice?

My advice is that you ask this question in an appropriate forum.

Not only is this question off-topic, but you dismissed bringing it back 
into topic out of hand and with tacit acceptance of some pretty bad FUD.

If you can't talk your dad through installing GNU/Linux, find someone who 
will go to his house and do it for him.  He's never had a computer before, 
so he's not going to be all fudged up with other people's paradigms.  If 
you think that'll be "too hard", then please don't try to talk about 
GNU/Linux with other people because you're giving them all a terrible 
impression.

Any further talk of Winders should AT LEAST go to plug-talk.

J.

Since you asked, my distro suggestion is Ubuntu, which is a variant of

ps: Be prepared.  People can feel *very* strongly about their Linux
choices and suggestions, which isn't that surprising, since there is
so much to choose.  Also, if at first you are frustrated by linux,
remember that you have enough control to remedy the sources of your
frustration.  (although, that freedom can at times be frustrating...)

I'll second John's advice to come to the Linux Clinic at FreeGeek next
weekend.  There you can find Linux in action, talk to experts, and
take home an Ubuntu Live CD to try out, which allows you to use Linux
for a while without modifying your existing installation.

The software you listed is primarily Windows software, which will not
easily run under Linux.  Perhaps this is an opportunity for you to
explore other open-source software, such as OpenOffice.org and Mozilla
Firefox, both which are available for Windows as well as Linux.

What you do *not* want to do is blindly install Linux for the first
time without any preparation, because you will lose all your existing
data.  Come to the clinic, we'll help you understand what you're
getting into and help you get started.

Jason

On Mon, Jun 12, 2006 at 07:32:20PM -0700, Jason R. Martin wrote:
> Looks like the PLUG FAQ needs to be updated:
> 
> http://www.pdxlinux.org/faq.html#clinic
> 
> The main site shows the correct location.

I try to put "page last modified" dates at the bottom of all my
webpages (I don't always remember!).  It seems neighborly to let
readers know the last time a human being reviewed the information,
so they can estimate its validity.  

Pages that have information about stuff that can change should
be dated.  Not filesystem dates;  pages can be touched or moved
without actually changing!  If a page is changed in haste
without changing the date, well, perhaps the date represents the
last time someone actually thought about what they were doing!

Perhaps we need to (1) put dates on pages, and (2) develop some
informal system of spreading out the work of maintaining pages
to interested members.  Then pages can have a change date AND
a person responsible!

Keith

> Keith,

>       <!--#config timefmt="%c" -->
>       This file last modified <!--#echo var="LAST_MODIFIED" -->

I think Keith was trying to distinguish substantive edits from a 
file's timestamp. The LAST_MODIFIED variable will be altered any time 
a file touched, regardless of whether its content was altered.

IMO, there's a fine line between significant and insignificant 
changes. Correcting typos or updating HTML tags isn't so significant 
to me, but adding/removing/correcting textual information (even a 
small amount) is significant.

I hadn't thought about differentiating between modification and review 
dates. I can see the benefit of adding a last-reviewed date to a page 
that's significant but rarely updated. Hmm.

From ali.corbin at gmail.com  Tue Jun 13 09:34:52 2006
From: ali.corbin at gmail.com (Ali Corbin)

On 6/13/06, Eric Biggs <eric.biggs at hotmail.com> wrote:
...
> My motivation for learning C++ is kind of to add to my repitoire of
> languages, though I don't know any computer languages yet.  I am a classical
> (koine) Greek student as well as classical Hebrew (not Paleo-Hebrew) and I'm
> going to be switching my major (eventually) to applied linguistics.  I was
> "looking down the road" and considered being familar with computaional
> linguistics and thought to myself, "self, you should learn a computer
> language."  It seems that in this field C++ is dominate.

There's a bit of overlap between human languages and computer
languages.  But I find computer languages a whole heck of a lot easier
to learn.  The grammar is a lot simpler, and there are no silly
exceptions that you have to memorize.

With that said, you should know that there are at present two major
types of computer languages.  Procedural languages like C, in which
the programs are laid out like a string of sentences, and
object-oriented languages like Java, in which programs  are laid out
more like a collection of rooms, each of which contains a shorter set
of sentences.  (How's that for a mixed metaphor?)

The two types of languages take two different mindsets.  OO languages
are a lot newer than procedural ones, and it was a bit of a struggle
for some programers to make the switch.  I don't know which type would
be better for someone like you.

(C++, although billed as an OO language, can actually be used as a
procedural one.  So you can have it both ways.)

> Those that replied to my posts did some kind of inserting of my posts into
> their replies...(does that make sense?)  With a view of ettiquette, I
> presume I should follow suit...but, alas...I am ignorant.  Therefore, How do
> I correctly reply on this list?

Most of us use mailing programs that automatically quote the original
whenever we make a reply.   Saving the context means that you don't
have to remember what the original question was.   Your mailer might
have an option some where to turn this behavior on.

Ali

It is general list-etiquette to quote an email with your replies either
underneith the original message, or splitting the original message into
seperate reply sections, as I have done. In hotmail you can turn on the
"show original message in reply message" in Options>Mail>Message Replies
(also, the Begin each line with ">" option isn't bad as well).

> In one e-mail I am recieving what seems to be the entire day of list
> activities.  Is this the *digest* option?  I am looking to receive all the
> postings of this list as individual e-mails (I'm on other lists, though my
> activity on them is simply observational, and that is what I'm used to).
> Would this second approach be the *digest* option?

Yes that is the digest option. Digest is like a newsletter of the days
activities, when you aren't using digest it will send you lots of
individual messages. You can change your options at the
http://lists.pdxlinux.org/mailman/listinfo/plug page.


Good luck, thanks for posting :)

From creswick at gmail.com  Tue Jun 13 09:44:04 2006
From: creswick at gmail.com (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Tue, 13 Jun 2006 09:44:04 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] new guy with questions
In-Reply-To: <BAY122-F2140A0156EB75348F0A24D848C0@phx.gbl>
References: <BAY122-F2140A0156EB75348F0A24D848C0@phx.gbl>
Message-ID: <c834ec80606130944v4e3072eatc8c8d04621e3feb3@mail.gmail.com>

On 6/13/06, Eric Biggs <eric.biggs at hotmail.com> wrote:>
> My motivation for learning C++ is kind of to add to my repitoire of
> languages, though I don't know any computer languages yet.  I am a classical
> (koine) Greek student as well as classical Hebrew (not Paleo-Hebrew) and I'm
> going to be switching my major (eventually) to applied linguistics.  I was
> "looking down the road" and considered being familar with computaional
> linguistics and thought to myself, "self, you should learn a computer
> language."  It seems that in this field C++ is dominate.

Let's see if I can do this without starting a language war...

C++ is a predominant language, but it may not be the best language to
start with.  If you want to learn to program because you'd like to be
able to create useful little programs for your own use, I would
suggest starting with a scripting language (perl, python and ruby are
common choices.  It is also good to know a little bash, since you can
run into a fair bit of that when using/configuring linux if you dig
into the details.).  These are "High-level" languages -- they provide
more of an abstraction between you and the computer.

If you are interested in the gory details about how computers "work"
-- how values are stored, how memory is managed, etc.. then C is a
good language.  In C you will be forced to manually manage your own
memory (at least at first -- there are tools that will do some of this
for you, but none work all the time.)  C doesn't abstract very much
from the internal hardware.

If you are interested in the theory of computer languages, then a
functional language may be more to your liking, although they tend to
have less support for real-world applications.  Haskell is probably
the most extreme example of a language like this -- it has a very
solid theoretical basis, and it is used for a great deal of research
in language theory and other areas, but it doesn't have a very solid
platform of libraries and tools for doing application development.
Lisp (my personal favorite language) is, in my humble opinion, an
extremely elegant language, and it is somewhat easier to use for real
apps than Haskell (Emacs, one of the most well-known "text editors"
was written in a dialect of lisp).  OCaml has rave reviews, and
reportedly a very strong platform of utilities and libraries for
application development.  (I've never used OCaml, so I can't speak
for/against it personally).  All these functional languages are pretty
high-level.

> Those that replied to my posts did some kind of inserting of my posts into
> their replies...(does that make sense?)  With a view of ettiquette, I
> presume I should follow suit...but, alas...I am ignorant.  Therefore, How do
> I correctly reply on this list?

Most people try to reply in-line, as I have done.  The general idea is
that each email should read a bit like a conversation, and ideally
each email should stand alone.  Hopefully someone reading this message
without having read the history of this discussion (the rest of the
thread) will still understand what is going on.

The common alternative to replying in-line is called top posting --
the entire reply is posted above the message that is being replied to.
 I think of this as "jeopardy style", you have no idea what the poster
is talking about / agreeing with / swearing at until you read their
entire message.  A fair number of us regard top posting as extremely
annoying, since it only seems to benefit the top-poster.  Generally,
just use common sense -- if your reply doesn't apply to any portion of
the message you are replying to, perhaps it belongs in a new thread,
not a reply.

> In one e-mail I am recieving what seems to be the entire day of list
> activities.  Is this the *digest* option?  I am looking to receive all the
> postings of this list as individual e-mails (I'm on other lists, though my
> activity on them is simply observational, and that is what I'm used to).
> Would this second approach be the *digest* option?

Yep, that's the digest.

> Lastly...Thank you all for the replies.

Thanks for considering list etiquette, and presenting good questions!

--Rogan

>

On Tue, 13 Jun 2006, Rogan Creswick wrote:

> Let's see if I can do this without starting a language war...

My annotations are definitely intended to keep to this spirit...

> If you are interested in the theory of computer languages, then a 
> functional language may be more to your liking, although they tend 
> to have less support for real-world applications.  Haskell is 
> probably the most extreme example of a language like this -- it has 
> a very solid theoretical basis, and it is used for a great deal of 
> research in language theory and other areas, but it doesn't have a 
> very solid platform of libraries and tools for doing application 
> development.

Functional languages like Haskell are, admittedly, the minority's 
choice for application development -- but you'll find them in solid 
use at Intel, AT&T, Ericsson, Microsoft, and various smaller companies 
(like my employer :-).

It's interesting to note that the prime maintainers of the x86/Linux 
version of ghc, the predominant Haskell compiler, are Microsoft 
employees.

Paul Heinlein <> heinlein at madboa.com <> www.madboa.com

Hmm, I hadn't considered lisp.

Now in the normal course of events, I wouldn't inflict lisp on
anybody, because it's too, well, in a word, weird.

But remembering the linguistics texts that I tried to wade through in
college, I realized that to a linguist, lisp might make perfect sense.

It's also perfectly geared toward twiddling text, so that you might
even find that it can do things that will help you with that language
stuff.

(Another, more "normal" language that's good with text twiddling is
perl.  It's what I used most recently on a quick and dirty translation
script.)

Correct-a-mundo!  And John Jason Jordan may be there.  He's a linguistics
student at PSU, and may have some tips on working with other languages.

> My motivation for learning C++ is kind of to add to my repitoire of 
> languages, though I don't know any computer languages yet.  I am a 
> classical (koine) Greek student as well as classical Hebrew (not 
> Paleo-Hebrew) and I'm going to be switching my major (eventually) to 
> applied linguistics.  I was "looking down the road" and considered being 
> familar with computaional linguistics and thought to myself, "self, you 
> should learn a computer language."  It seems that in this field C++ is

Indeed.  There are many computer languages, and in my opinion, C++ is
like English: it may be a chaotic mishmash of different languages and
world-models, but it *is* dominant in many areas, and brutally effective
when used with skill.

Programming is an expressive art independent of language.  There are
other languages that are easier to learn first.  I might recommend Python
or Ruby; there are good books and local groups that can help you learn.

> Those that replied to my posts did some kind of inserting of my posts into 
> their replies...

It's called bottom-posting, and has been the traditional style for
electronic communications these past few decades.  Questions and such are
quoted and indented, responses are placed below them.

Top-posting (and the email virus) has come into vogue with the advent of
Microsoft Outlook on Windows, much to the consternation of us old-
timers, who prefer to converse rather than exchange broadsides.  <grin>

Thank you for noticing, and for asking.  Your humility and knack for
observation is rare and most valuable.

From m0gely at telestream.com  Tue Jun 13 12:12:11 2006
From: m0gely at telestream.com (m0gely)
Date: Tue, 13 Jun 2006 12:12:11 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] LCD monitor recommendations
In-Reply-To: <20060613182200.GA4863@einstein.seansdomain.org>
References: <20060613182200.GA4863@einstein.seansdomain.org>
Message-ID: <448F0E0B.1090405@telestream.com>

sean.whitney at gmail.com wrote:
> 2) I would like to get at least a 19" LCD monitor.  But I'm not quite
> sure how big a 19" wide screen is?  Is it really give you the same
> screen size as a 19" CRT?

LCD's are actual size in the diagonal. So they have a bigger screen size 
than their CRT counterparts.

> 1) Which manufacturers <snip>

<snip>

> 3) Which characteristics are the most important <snip>

I would suggest going to BestBuy or Fry's, as they have several displays 
there you can actually look at and see.  Then just buy online the model 
you like if you prefer.  There are no tricks to them or frills that set 
one above the rest.  Just get one that's easy on the eyes, and that runs 
at a resolution you're comfy with.  Some have telescoping stands for 
height adjustment.  Other than that, go with a brand name you can trust 
that has a good warranty.  I like Mitsubishi and Samsung, but I can't 
give you a good reason why.

> 4) How do you determine which screen resolutions are "native" as opposed
> to "non-native"?

CRT's can run many screen resolutions and not degrade in quality.  If 
you have an old laptop around that has an 800x600 display, set it to 
640x480.  The screen (especially text) looks like crap.  New displays 
don't suffer with this phenomenon as badly, but to get that crisp and 
clear experience you want, you need to run at the 'native' resolution of 
the display.  There is only *one* native resolution.  This will be 
stated on the box or shelf label.  Your 21" Sun was probably 20" 
viewable, so a 19" LCD is only an inch shy of that.  Look for one that 
will run the same resolution you ran on your Sun.

> 5) Are there new wide screen resolutions that won't be supported by my
> U5 and linux nvidia card?

I doubt it.  This sort of thing is very hackable anyway.

-- 
- m0gely
http://quake2.telestream.com/
Q2 | Q3A | Counter-strike

This has to be some great advice.  Go to the local retailers and let 
them know what you've found elsewhere, including online, at Best Buy, 
Fry's, etc.

It's bad enough that computer components are invariably made overseas 
and we can't support our local economies by purchasing local 
electronics, like we could with say, clothing, food, etc., but at least 
try to support the local establishments.

By purchasing locally you can make a difference.

have a 17" widescreen notebook and it's perfect for what I do.  I would 
look at a widescreen if you can afford it.  The way the real estate is 
laid out lends itself to more productivity.

have to pay for it in installments, you can just put a payment on your

degrade but still work like analog does.

thing.

Quoting "Michael M." <nixlists at writemoore.net>:

> John Jason Jordan wrote:
> >
> >

> > how to edit the grub boot menu from the command line. 
> >
> > How do you guys ever learn all this stuff?
> >   
> 
> 
> The information on working with with GRUB in the Linux Cookbook (Carla's 
> book) is really excellent.  The information about LiLo is probably just 
> as good, but I don't use LiLo so I skipped that part.

If you hose your root, /usr, /var, etc. partitions, the problem isn't getting
grub to work.  I've figured out how to network boot, which grub by the way
supports.  Alternatives to going the etherboot/PXE, nfs. tftp-server, dhcp
route include using a tomsrootboot disk or one of the many rescue cd's.
One thing I'd like to experiment with is moving grub off of the main hard
drive onto like a usb memory stick and the boot from that.  This way if
the hard drive dies, you still have grub and are free of having to fish
around for a rescue disk.

As far as X won't start, permissions being set wrong is a very common cause
of this problem.  It may be that you can fix it.

Good Luck,

Michael Robinson

> Can I distribute a subnet's time server via dhcp?
>
>
Yes.  If you're using ISC's, in your /etc/dhcpd.conf file, add (globally or
otherwise):
option ntp-servers              192.168.0.1;

However, I can't tell you if / how this will affect Windows XP.  Am assuming
it will play nice with and honor most DHCP servers.


From creswick at gmail.com  Tue Jun 13 15:32:02 2006
From: creswick at gmail.com (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Tue, 13 Jun 2006 15:32:02 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Re: new guy with questions
In-Reply-To: <BAY122-F149E5AEE9D817ABC3304B1848C0@phx.gbl>
References: <BAY122-F149E5AEE9D817ABC3304B1848C0@phx.gbl>
Message-ID: <c834ec80606131532y11fe97w2381e8bdce1cb7cf@mail.gmail.com>

On 6/13/06, Eric Biggs <eric.biggs at hotmail.com> wrote:
> My understanding of computer languages is not that extensive.  I kind of
> thought that in computer languages there were "high", "assemby" and
> "mechanical," where a compiler was necessary to *interpret* from a
> high-level language to a mechanical one enabling the computer to understand
> the human.  Therefore, I was under the impression that most of the
> programming that was done would have to utilize an High-level language.  I
> also thought that assembly languages were one step removed from a mechanical
> one, again not being utilized as often.

Your understanding is correct, but amongst the "high-level" languages
(by which I mean anything less intense than Assembly, and say, more
intense than Excel or Hypercard) there are also many differences in
how much attention to you must pay to low-level details.  Generally,
the most obvious distinction between these languages is in memory
management.

In C, you must manage all the memory you use on your own -- if you
need storage for a bunch of numbers, first you have to figure out how
many numbers you will have, then you must figure out how much space
each number needs (this can differ depending on what computer the
program is run on, by the way), then you can make a call to a memory
allocation routine.  That allocation routine may or may not allocate
enough space, so you need to check for that before you use the memory.
 Finally, you can store your numbers.   If you've heard the term
"buffer overflow" in the context of security patches, or viriuses,
this is where they happen.  If you make a mistake with the memory
allocation in C, you may never notice -- everything *might* work just
fine, but one day somone may find out that under certain circumstances
your program allows anyone to overwrite the administrator password (or
something like that) because you didn't allocate memory correctly.
This is a very real problem, although it is much less of a problem
with Linux than it is with windows (because user space programs just
don't have access to things like the admin password).

The current hot Object-Oriented (OO) languages, such as Java and C#,
prevent problems like this by doing the memory management stuff for
you.  Generally speaking they do a very good job, but you might be
able to get a faster program by doing it yourself. (Emphasis on
might--it depends on many, many factors, especially since I'm not
talking about specific languages.)  C++ provides a bit of a mix
between the two -- I don't know c++ that well, but in my limited
experience with it I've found that at times I need to manage memory on
my own, and at other times it's done for me--while this is due in
large part to my ignorance of c++, both situations *are* possible,
which means that sooner or later you will have to deal with them both
if you use C++.

Having said that, regardless of the language you use, if you program
very much you will eventually need to know how memory management
works, even if you don't want to do it yourself.  (A good essay on
this can be found here:
http://www.joelonsoftware.com/articles/LeakyAbstractions.html)

> >If you are interested in the theory of computer languages, then a
> >functional language may be more to your liking...
>
> Again, my knowledge (which can easily be incorrect) only recognizes the
> three categories....What is implied with a "functional language?"

There are many different programming paradigms, so far this thread has
mentioned three of them: Object-oriented, procedural and functional.
There are many more, contraint-based, data-flow, event-based,
logic-based, constraint-logic... etc.  The three mentioned are by far
the most common, although it is extremely difficult to classify any
single language into one paradigm.  Java is generally regarded as OO,
c is considered procedural, lisp and haskell are considered
functional.  OCaml claims to be OO/functional+some other stuff. (I say
claims only because I don't know from personal experience.)

Procedural languages are like recipies in a standard cookbook, a bunch
of instructions are listed in order.  A more complex program will
break things up -- like cooking a 7-course meal, each course might be
one recipe, but in the end it's just a list of instructions.  (Ok, ok,
in the end, *every* language is just a list of instructions, but since
we're talking about programming languages, I'm ignoring the
assembly-level details.)

Object-Oriented languages provide mechanisims for combining data and
logic in a way that can be more easily re-used.  With a procedural
language there generally aren't a lot of ties between the data and the
logic that manages that data, so you have to pass around the data and
the logic separately.  OO offers a solution to that by letting you
combine data and logic into reusable objects.  If procedures in
procedural languages are like recipes, Objects are like frozen dinners
-- the recipe and the food is combined.

Functional programs are more like mathematical proofs.  The core ideal
in a functional language is that everything is a function, and data is
never changed.  Therefore, if you want the some bit of data (say the
date) you call a function that returns the date, rather than accessing
a variable that already has the date stored in it.  This means that
you never need to worry about storage, or updating variables, or a
bunch of other things.  As long as every function knows exactly how to
do what it does, at any time, then things will work.  (As an aside,
this is a good thing to aim for in *any* language.)  One of the most
amazing things about functional languages is that functions are
treated as first-class citizens -- that is, they can be passed around
just like varibales and values in a procedural language!

So, if you need a function that does a very specific thing, you can
write another function that *creates* that function when the program
is run, and then you can run the created function later.  You can do
some of this with Object oriented languages, but functional languages
generally make it easier.

Finally, you can program in any paradigm in pretty much any language.
It's possible to write functional C, and you can write procedural
lisp.  Many paradigms aren't mutually exclusive either --
Object-Oriented languages involve lots of procedural elements, and as
I eluded to above, they have some functional aspects as well.
Regardless of the language, if you do any work with interfaces you
will need to use some sort of event-based paradigm.


--Rogan

From ianburrell at gmail.com  Tue Jun 13 15:40:49 2006
From: ianburrell at gmail.com (Ian Burrell)
Date: Tue, 13 Jun 2006 15:40:49 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] NTP
In-Reply-To: <1150063664.448c943060548@xerxes.robinson-west.com>
References: <1150063664.448c943060548@xerxes.robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <d91f09cd0606131540m2397dbfej957575aded6178a1@mail.gmail.com>

On 6/11/06, plug_0 at robinson-west.com <plug_0 at robinson-west.com> wrote:
> I want to  set up an always on host that synchrnonises to a remote ntp
> server as a local ntp server for the rest of my network.  How do I do
> this?
>

If you have only a few Linux machines, it isn't a big advantage having
a local time server.  I have one because I need a machine to act as an
bridge.  You will need to run ntpd on all the Linux machines anyway
and can point them to the ISP, distro, or pool.ntp.org servers.  If
you have a big server farm, then having a local time server can be
important.

Install ntpd. On Debian, it is ntp-server package.  On Fedora, ntp
package.  Edit /etc/ntp.conf to set the servers.  I use the
pool.ntp.org servers:

server 0.us.pool.ntp.org
server 1.us.pool.ntp.org
server 2.us.pool.ntp.org

Then, open up access to local clients:

restrict 192.168.1.0  mask  255.255.255.0 nomodify

Then point the clients to the server.

server 192.168.1.10

 - Ian

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Tue Jun 13 16:41:56 2006
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Tue, 13 Jun 2006 16:41:56 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] LCD monitor recommendations
In-Reply-To: <20060613182200.GA4863@einstein.seansdomain.org>
References: <20060613182200.GA4863@einstein.seansdomain.org>
Message-ID: <20060613234156.GC29032@gate.kl-ic.com>

On Tue, Jun 13, 2006 at 11:22:00AM -0700, sean.whitney at gmail.com wrote:
> Well this morning my nice 21" Sun dual input monitor died.  So I'm in
> the market for a slightly smaller LCD monitor and I'm looking for
> recommendation

You've already heard others talk about driving LCD monitors at their
native resolution.  That is part of their specs, and not hard to 
find out.  Most 19 inchers are 1280x960, but some are 1600x1200 .

This can be a problem if you like filling the screen with two
80-character-across Xterms;  the native resolutions at which this
works are 1012+ (6px/char) , 1332+ (8 pix/char) , 1652/10 , and
so forth.  1024 works great, 1280 loses 7 characters or else makes
the windows too small, 1600 loses 6 characters, etc.  I suppose the
best answer is to get a Really Big Monitor, so it doesn't matter
if you aren't using all the screen space for your xterms.

> 1) my current monitor has 2 inputs one for standard VGA and another for
> the older Sun Ultra video inputs.  I am planning on getting an adapter
> and hooking it up to a vga switch box.

I have a Sun-to-VGA converter, feeding a VGA video switch, so this is
a workable solution ... for a CRT.  But see below for an LCD.

> 2) ...

> 3) I'm really not interested in any of the new interface standards.  15
> pin VGA is fine for me.

Buzzz.  Sorry, wrong answer.  I made the same assumption when I bought 
a Viewsonic VA912B 19inch LCD for my wife's office.  I even carefully
constructed a CD of test images (and put them on my USB key, too) and
went around to the various stores looking at the different monitors. 
I did most of the looking and got the most cooperation from CompUSA
in Tigard.  Then I called Enu, and went off to buy the one they
claimed to have in stock.  Oops, it was reserved by another customer. 
I spent an hour going there, and then (pissed off) going back to
CompUSA where I made the purchase.  

Then I got the LCD home, and tried the test images with the builtin
video from the Shuttle mini-ATX computer I was putting together for
her.

Yikes!!!!  (this is the "wrong answer" part...)

The HD15 VGA video put out by the computer had enough time wander to
seriously screw up the image quality of the VA912B .  Unlike a CRT,
the pixels of an LCD are discrete horizontally, and so the LCD monitor
circuitry must sample the signal coming in and compute an average
video value to stuff into the pixel.  Now imagine a checkerboard
array of black and white pixels (like the "grey" image in the back
of an X display).  As the sampling point moves over this video signal,
it will see alternating black and white sine wave (the edges don't
stay sharp, sigh).  It is supposed to find the middle of the black
pixel and then the middle of the white pixel and sample at the
center point.  But if the sampling is a bit off, it will sample
over at the edge of the pixel, and the level will be a bit off. 
During the next screen pass, the timing may have shifted by a
nanosecond or so, and the sample will occur elsewhere - a
different video level.

What all this does is give you NASTY moire patterns on the LCD -
really nauseating.  Okay, so you think you can live without alternating
pixel checkerboards?  You get the same effect if you put up an Xterm
with a row of "m" characters across;  the vertical bars and spaces
of the character are one pixel wide on my display.  Xterms with
6 pixel character spacings are really nauseating to look at, and I
spend a LOT of time looking at those.

Next I tried a different VGA video card plugged into the Shuttle's
single PCI slot.  It STILL looked like crap.  So why didn't I see
that in the store?  Still a mystery, but I think there are some
tricks the Shuttles play with the system clock, purposely drifting
it to reduce narrowband radio interference.  Your mileage may
definitely vary.

The solution?  The LCD monitor also had a DVI input.  I found a DVI
video card (also at CompUSA, also after looking at the little stores
and failing to find a PCI compatable card that would fit the single
PCI slot of the little computer) and hooked that up instead.  Moire
went away.  It looks good.  BTW, the mini-ATX computer is running 
SUSE 10, which found the ATI video card and the Viewsonic monitor
with no problems.

Consider, if you will, the differences between SUN native resolution
and the LCD native resolution.  I'm not sure how adjustable the SUN
video is,  but when I use the SUN into a CRT I rely on the multisync
of the CRT to make things right.  Now we are adding sampling, in both
the X /and/ Y directions.  We are also adding the Sun to VGA interface
box, and also the video switch, which will add time jitter to the video.
I imagine the video result will look like the dogs breakfast.

So, I strongly suggest you get a DVI video card for the Linux PC,
and drive a dual-input monitor directly.  You can connect the HD15
VGA cable off the SUN to the monitor as well, and use the monitor
itself to do the switching (check the manual to make sure you can
do this).  The Sun will look like crap, but at least the Linux box
will look OK.  For quality images off the Sun, well, that is why X
is designed to work over networks!

The moire patterns with the Viewsonic may be specific to the 
Viewsonic and the particular video output of the Shuttle; but the
VA912B was one of the best looking in the store, the rest looked
pretty bad with some of the test images /on their computer/,  driving
a video splitter and a bunch of monitors together through their
VGA analog ports.  

You really do need to test these LCD monitors, ideally with the
video sources and types of displays you plan to drive them with. 
You can look at the set I used at
   http://www.keithl.com/monitortest/test.html
(I took out a few with private stuff on them).
These were mostly so my wife could see what it looked like;  
women are wired with more color processing than men, so bring 
along a female when deciding what the colors should look like.

Note also, as I mentioned a few days ago to Rich, there are 
tradeoffs between viewing angle and contrast and response 
speed.  Fast monitors may have lower contrast, and look bad
off-axis.  The worst direction is off axis into the corners,
the "boss looking over your shoulder" direction.  If you will be
using your LCD for color proofs to show your boss, that is quite
different than an LCD for looking at videos or playing games.

Get a good return and refund policy!  Your setup has enough risks
that you may go through a few monitors before you find one that
really works.

And yes, it would be nice to buy locally.  If you can work with
a local shop with demo monitors in the store, and they will let
you drag your whole setup in for some tests, that would be perfect.
We don't have a store that does that out here in Beaverton;  they
either don't have the monitors in stock, or they don't have a
place you can set up your own machines.   There are probably
places in Portland that do, and if we had not been trying to get
this done on one Saturday afternoon, we might have gone to them.

In the interim, Free Geek probably has a big heap of Sun 19 inch
monitors that they will give you for 10 bucks or so (my guess,
they want them OUTA THERE).  You can use that while you shop,
then take it back to Free Geek in a couple of weeks, and pay
another $10 to have the damn thing recycled.  You are going
to Free Geek to recycle your current dead 19 incher, anyway.

At the end of the selection and upgrade process, LCD monitors
are much nicer looking and more environmentally friendly than
the big hot glass CRTs.  When my 19 inchers die, I will replace
them with LCD monitors.

I think I just wrote a magazine article ...

Keith

> I would suggest going to BestBuy or Fry's, as they have several displays

> height adjustment.  Other than that, go with a brand name you can trust 
> that has a good warranty.  I like Mitsubishi and Samsung, but I can't 
> give you a good reason why.

Be sure you know the dead pixel policy.  Generally, dead pixels are not 
considered a defect and are not covered under the warranty.  You may 
want to buy from a local store which has a no-questions-asked 30-day 
return policy so you can return it if there are dead pixels.

Philips has a zero-dead-pixel policy on certain models; they call it 
their "Perfect Panel" warranty.

http://www.consumer.philips.com/consumer/catalog/catalog.jsp?activeCategory=MONITORS_PC_PERIPHERALS_GR_US_PROFESSIONAL&fhquery=fh_location%3D%2F%2Fprofessional%2Fen_US%2Fcategories%3Ccatalog_us_professional%2Fcategories%3Cmonitors_pc_peripherals_gr_us_professional%2Fcategories%3Clcd_monitors_ca_us_professional%2Ffh_att_prof_features%3E%7Bfh_val_PH_FEA_F300009223%7D&clickEventData=fh_location%3D%2F%2Fprofessional%2Fen_US%2Fcategories%3Ccatalog_us_professional%2Fcategories%3Cmonitors_pc_peripherals_gr_us_professional%2Fcategories%3Clcd_monitors_ca_us_professional%2Ffh_att_prof_features%3E%7Bfh_val_PH_FEA_F300009223%7D&fredhopperpage=index.jsp&language=en&country=US&catalogType=PROFESSIONAL&proxybuster=01NPND2WS2SIZJ0RMRESHQVHKFSEKI5P

I don't have one, so I can't comment on quality.

Does anyone else know of any manufacturers with zero-dead-pixel policies?

On 6/13/06, harry <lamsokvr at xprt.net> wrote:
> HI
>
> Got DSL stuff today...
>
> Got a cisco 687 router...
>
> Do I need a cross over to connect that to my hub??
>
> I got instructions on a Windows disk..
>
> Not much help

depends on your hub or switch.
Newer switches have auto sensing such that you
don't need a cross-over.
Older hubs that have a uplink port don't need a cross-over if you use
the uplink port.
A hub or switch that has neither will need the cross-over cable.

Denis Heidtmann wrote:

> I have Dual 1019 which has served very well, but it has a rumble or a low
> frequency resonance.  It is inaudible, but it takes up considerable dynamic
> range.  I have been unable to isolate the cause.
> 
> On rim-drive Duals the part that wears out is the idler.  They are no 
> longer
> manufactured, and replacement idlers cost in the $60-$70 range.  If your 
> Dual
> has a good idler, and you are considering selling the machine, I would 
> like to
> talk to you.

Mine is a 1216. Amazon told us that the new turntable has shipped, so 
once we get it and give it a try, I'll decide if I want to let go of the 
old turntable. I have thought of trying to replace the underside with 
something else, like a direct drive, but I'm also aware that the motors 
in these things are a little special, as in having more stability in 
their speed, so that's probably not going to happen -- certainly not 
anytime soon.

> I would also like to get some advice on using gramofile--I found the 
> documentation confusing.  But Audacity does not have the automatic 
> scratch removal capability that gramofile is said to have.

I think I always just used the default filter. As I recall (it's been a 
year or more since I recorded anything), when I tried selecting 
something else, I ran into trouble. It did take a bit of getting used to 
the user interface, but it seemed to work fine.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Jun 15 16:10:09 2006
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)

Subject: [PLUG] Help with ~/.emacs
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.63.0606151606110.29912@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

   I have most file modes colored as I'd like them in emacs, but the newly
added .ris is not what I want. The colors were set for a white background
rather than a black background in emacs.

   Below is my .emacs file. The colors I'd like to see with .ris files are on
lines 172-174. But, the ris.el file's call at the bottom overrides these
colors.

   Those of you who use emacs as your OS can most likely see the conflict

Richard B. Shepard, Ph.D.               |    The Environmental Permitting
Applied Ecosystem Services, Inc.(TM)    |            Accelerator
<http://www.appl-ecosys.com>     Voice: 503-667-4517      Fax: 503-667-8863
