;; emacs for 21.4 on Slackware 10.2

;; Are we running XEmacs or Emacs?
(defvar running-xemacs (string-match "XEmacs\\|Lucid" emacs-version))

;; Set up the keyboard so the delete key on both the regular keyboard
;; and the keypad delete the character under the cursor and to the right
;; under X, instead of the default, backspace behavior.
;;(global-set-key [delete] 'delete-char)
;;(global-set-key [kp-delete] 'delete-char)

;; Turn on font-lock mode for Emacs
(cond ((not running-xemacs)
        (global-font-lock-mode t)
))

;; Visual feedback on selections
(setq-default transient-mark-mode t)

;; Always end a file with a newline
(setq require-final-newline t)

;; Stop at the end of the file, not just add lines
(setq next-line-add-newlines nil)

;; Enable wheelmouse support by default
(cond (window-system
        (mwheel-install)
))

;; Set tab spacing for Python files
(setq py-indent-offset 2)

(setq initial-frame-alist '(
     (minibuffer . t)
     (width . 81)
     (height . 50)
                            )
)

(setq default-frame-alist '(
     (minibuffer . t)
     (width . 81)
     (height . 50)
     (border-color . "red")
                            )
)

(cond (window-system
    (setq default-frame-alist
      '((foreground-color . "white")
        (background-color . "black")
        (mouse-color      . "Orchid")
        (cursor-color     . "Orchid")
        (icon-type        . t)      ; gnu picture as Emacs icon
        (icon-name        . nil)    ; use frame title
        (set-default-font
                      "-b&h-lucidatypewriter-medium-*-*-sans-12-*-*-*-*-*-iso8859-1")
        (add-to-list 'default-frame-alist
              '(font . "-b&h-lucidatypewriter-medium-*-*-sans-12-*-*-*-*-*-iso8859-1"))
    ))
    (setq frame-title-format "%b")      ; set frame title to buffer name
    (setq  icon-title-format "%b")      ; set  icon title to buffer name
  ))

(custom-set-variables
   ;; custom-set-variables was added by Custom -- don't edit or cut/paste it!
   ;; Your init file should contain only one such instance.
  '(case-fold-search t)
  '(column-number-mode t)
  '(comment-column 32 t)
  '(current-language-environment "ASCII")
  '(global-font-lock-mode t nil (font-lock))
  '(save-place t nil (saveplace))
  '(show-paren-mode t nil (paren))
  '(text-mode-hook (quote (turn-on-auto-fill text-mode-hook-identify)))
  '(tool-bar-mode nil nil (tool-bar))
  '(transient-mark-mode t))
  (setq default-major-mode 'text-mode)
  (add-hook 'text-mode-hook 'turn-on-auto-fill)
  (setq-default transient-mark-mode t)
  ;(require 'tex-site)
  (require 'ps-print)
  (global-font-lock-mode t)
  (setq font-lock-maximum-decoration t)

  (cond (window-system
    (setq font-lock-face-attributes
  ;              face                     fg        bg  bf  it  ul
      '((font-lock-comment-face       "GreenYellow" nil  t   t  nil)
        (font-lock-string-face        "wheat"   nil nil  t  nil)
        (font-lock-keyword-face       "purple"      nil  t  nil nil)
        (font-lock-type-face          "MediumVioletRed" nil  t  nil nil)
        (font-lock-function-name-face "DarkOliveGreen4"       nil  t  nil
nil)
        (font-lock-variable-name-face "DodgerBlue"       nil  t  nil nil)
        (font-lock-reference-face     "SeaGreen"        nil nil  t   t ))
      font-lock-maximum-decoration t
      font-lock-support-mode 'lazy-lock-mode
      font-lock-verbose nil
      lazy-lock-stealth-verbose nil
    )
    (if (fboundp 'global-font-lock-mode)
        (global-font-lock-mode t)
        (add-hook 'find-file-hooks 'turn-on-font-lock))
  ))

  ;; kludge until colors work correctly:
  (make-face 'rbs-comment-face)
  (set-face-foreground 'rbs-comment-face "wheat")
  (set-face-background 'rbs-comment-face "black")

  (make-face 'rbs-string-face)
  (set-face-foreground 'rbs-string-face "LightPink1")
  (set-face-background 'rbs-comment-face "black")

  (make-face 'rbs-keyword-face)
  (set-face-foreground 'rbs-keyword-face "khaki1")
  (set-face-background 'rbs-keyword-face "black")

  (make-face 'rbs-type-face)
  (set-face-foreground 'rbs-type-face "Goldenrod1")
  (set-face-background 'rbs-type-face "black")

  (make-face 'rbs-function-name-face)
  (set-face-foreground 'rbs-function-name-face "PaleGreen1")
  (set-face-background 'rbs-function-name-face "black")

  (make-face 'rbs-variable-name-face)
  (set-face-foreground 'rbs-variable-name-face "turquoise2")
  (set-face-background 'rbs-variable-name-face "black")

(make-face 'rbs-reference-face)
  (set-face-foreground 'rbs-reference-face "Magenta2")
  (set-face-background 'rbs-reference-face "black")

  (make-face 'rbs-constant-face)
  (set-face-foreground 'rbs-constant-face "IndianRed2")
  (set-face-background 'rbs-constant-face "black")

  ; let the new face be the font face
  (setq font-lock-comment-face 'rbs-comment-face)
  (setq font-lock-string-face 'rbs-string-face)
  (setq font-lock-keyword-face 'rbs-keyword-face)
  (setq font-lock-type-face 'rbs-type-face)
  (setq font-lock-function-name-face 'rbs-function-name-face)
  (setq font-lock-variable-name-face 'rbs-variable-name-face)
  (setq font-lock-reference-face 'rbs-reference-face)
  (setq font-lock-constant-face 'rbs-constant-face)

  ;; for C code:
  (global-set-key "%" 'match-paren)
  (global-set-key [f5] 'goto-line)

  (defun match-paren (arg)
  "Go to the matching parenthesis if on parenthesis otherwise insert %."
        (interactive "p")
        (cond ((looking-at "\\s\(") (forward-list 1) (backward-char 1))
              ((looking-at "\\s\)") (forward-char 1) (backward-list 1))
              ((looking-at "\\s\{") (forward-list 1) (backward-char 1))
              ((looking-at "\\s\}") (forward-char 1) (backward-list 1))
              ((looking-at "\\s\[") (forward-list 1) (backward-char 1))
              ((looking-at "\\s\]") (forward-char 1) (backward-list 1))
              (t (self-insert-command (or arg 1)))))

  '(tool-bar-mode nil nil (tool-bar))
(custom-set-faces
   ;; custom-set-faces was added by Custom -- don't edit or cut/paste it!
   ;; Your init file should contain only one such instance.
  '(default ((t (:stipple nil :background "black" :foreground "white" :inverse-video nil :box nil :strike-through nil :overline nil :underline nil :slant normal :weight normal :height 135 :width normal :family "adobe-courier"))))
  '(font-lock-comment-face ((((class color) (background dark)) (:foreground "wheat"))))
  '(ris-main-face ((t (:foreground "wheat"))))
  '(ris-tag-face ((t (:foreground "light blue"))))
  '(ris-tyer-tag-face ((t (:foreground "yellow")))))

;; Python stuff
(setq load-path (cons "~/development/python/python-mode" load-path))
(autoload 'python-mode "python-mode" "Python editing mode." t)

(setq auto-mode-alist
      (cons '("\\.py$" . python-mode)
       auto-mode-alist))

(setq interpreter-mode-alist
      (cons '("python" . python-mode)
       interpreter-mode-alist))

;; RIS for RefDB
;; Turn on syntax coloring
(cond ((fboundp 'global-font-lock-mode)
   ;; Turn on font-lock in all modes that support it
   (global-font-lock-mode t)
   ;; maximum colors
     (setq font-lock-maximum-decoration t)))

;; ris mode
(autoload 'ris-mode "ris" "Major mode for RIS bibliography files." t)
(or (assoc "\\.ris$" auto-mode-alist)
   (setq auto-mode-alist (cons '("\\.ris$" . ris-mode)
     auto-mode-alist)))

I took a peek at ris.el, and it looks like ris sets up its own color scheme:

(set-face-foreground 'ris-main-face "maroon")
(set-face-foreground 'ris-main-ltd-face "dark orchid")
(set-face-foreground 'ris-tag-face "blue")
(set-face-foreground 'ris-tyer-tag-face "red")
(set-face-foreground 'ris-author-face "sea green")
(set-face-foreground 'ris-pubyear-face "IndianRed2")
(set-face-foreground 'ris-reprint-face "deep pink")

I'd try setting these variables to the colors that you want.  (And
I'll bet that you'll have to set them after loading ris.el.)

Ali

Auke,

   I was looking for xpcom, not libxpcom so I didn't find it. I had to make
symlinks to all the libs in /usr/lib/firefox-1.5.0.4 to /usr/lib before it
would compile.

   After reonfiguring and rebuilding the make install failed because the
script could not find mozilla; well, firefox is installed, not mozilla.
install.sh says to do it manually in this case.

   Then I copied all /usr/lib/firefox-1.5.0.4/*.so to ~/.mozilla/plugins, and
make symlinks from all /usr/lib/firefox-1.5.0.4/*.xpt to
/usr/lib/mozilla/plugins/.

when I start firefox and try to watch a video stream of the World Cup. Any
idea what I've not yet done?

From rsteff at comcast.net  Fri Jun 16 17:30:54 2006
From: rsteff at comcast.net (Richard C. Steffens)
Date: Fri, 16 Jun 2006 17:30:54 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Ion USB Turntable
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.63.0606130612330.5491@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <4488ADA8.7080302@comcast.net>	<20060608182903.941ad22c.johnxj@comcast.net>	<4488E016.2050306@comcast.net>
	<448E37F0.6010909@dslnorthwest.net>
	<Pine.LNX.4.63.0606130612330.5491@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <44934D3E.8010806@comcast.net>

The turntable arrived. I was surprised to find that the platter is
plastic, and doesn't weigh very much. But, we'll see if that matters. It
assembled easily and the instructions for balancing the tone arm are
clear. You can download the instruction manual from the Ion website. Go 
to: http://www.ion-audio.com/ then click on "Support" and find pdf's for 
the iTTUSB Turntable and Software Installation Guides.

The supplied Audacity software is for either Win or Mac, so I tried it
on my laptop first. Installation was simple, as was recording. Exporting
to MP3 required going out on the web and finding lame_enc.dll (I don't
recall the URL, but it was the first one Google presented when searching
for lame_enc.dll.)

Next, I loaded Audacity on this machine (SuSE 9.1). YaST put an icon for
it in <Green Button> - Multimedia - Media Editing. The version YaST gave
me is 1.2.0. The one supplied on the CD is 1.2.3. I've read a review
that talks about 1.2.4, so I'll have to go get it and give it a try.

(Still with version 1.2.0 and 1.2.3):
Configuration is supposed to be in two steps. First, you're supposed to,
"Click on Microphone in the drop down menu and select 'Stereo Mix.'" My
Win version does not have that drop down box. My Linux version does have
the box with several options, non of which mention USB or Stereo Mix.

The rest of the configuration is done from a Preferences entry on the
File menu (both Win & Linux versions). In the Win version, under the
Audio I/O tab, there is an option for recording from a USB device (in my
case it says USB Audio CODEC, the documentation says it might say
something else depending on the installation, but that the initials USB
should be in the list entry). The other two options are MS Sound Mapper
- Input, and Realtek HD Audio input. The Linux version does not have the
USB option, only /dev/dsp.

So, I guess before I go further, I should go get the 1.2.4 version for
Linux and install it.

...Hours later...

According to README.txt, in order to compile Audacity, I have to have 
wxWidgets installed. I'm still waiting for that compile to finish. I 
guessed which version to use (x11) -- the README file does not say. I 
have the GTK version, but ./configure for Audacity says that's not the 
one it wants.

Meanwhile, I have recorded Side one of Days of Future Passed, by The 
Moody Blues, exported it to MP3, copied it to my RH 7.0 system and 
played it through the living room stereo. Other than  few scratches, it 
sounds pretty good. I'll need to spend some more time with the filters 
in Audacity to see what they can do.

Assuming the two compiles finish sometime this evening, I'll try the 
newer version of Audacity on this machine and report on the USB 
functionality. The turntable itself seems to work well.

One thing to watch is to be sure the correct speed is selected. The 
first recording I made was of an old Stereo demo record from the 1960's. 
I didn't notice that somehow the 45RPM button was selected. Not to 
worry. The Audacity software has a feature to convert the speed from 45 
to 33-1/3, as well as several other options. They discourage it if you 
are fussy about the sound quality. It seemed to be OK on the one I did, 
although I have yet to listen to it on the living room system.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens

> I have those working on Breezy, but I did it by installing Frefox 32 +
> Flash in a chroot environment. I can help you get that set up at the

> to do. From reading the Ubuntu user forums it appears that it may be
> possible to get these working in Dapper without a chroot envirnoment.

> > What do I need to bring other than my computer (monitor, keyboard, mouse)?  (I 
> > would prefer not to lug the monitor.)

The issue I ran into with the upgrade from Breezy to Dapper (5.1 to 6.1)
was an older libflashplugin.so in one of the plugin directories.  If I
recall correctly, it was a libflash4 when it should have been a
libflash7.  I found the correct one on my system, removed the symlink to
libflash4 and created one to libflash7.  Restarting Firefox, Flash from
youtube.com and other sites then worked.

Adam

> There are monitors at Free Geek that you can borrow. However, I don't
> know what resolution they support. I have never even seen one at Free
> Geek in operation, so I can't even guess what they will run. I would
> definitely recommend bringing the rest, at least. Mouse and keyboard
> are not hard to truck around, so it's worth the trouble of hauling them
> to Free Geek so as not to run into problems. Waerst thou me I would

From johnxj at comcast.net  Sat Jun 17 17:21:40 2006
From: johnxj at comcast.net (John Jason Jordan)
Date: Sat, 17 Jun 2006 17:21:40 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] I should have known better
Message-ID: <20060617172140.2443fe59.johnxj@comcast.net>

Than to try to install Dapper by myself. Was going to at the Clinic
tomorrow. But Friday I handed in the last paper and then participated
in the year-end parties to celebrate. And this morning I just couldn't
wait. I had to try out Dapper.

Previously I had burned the 64-bit DVD, so I put it in the drive and
restarted. Turns out it is not just an install DVD, it is also a live
DVD. So it just booted up Dapper-64. So I played with it for awhile,
checking out what worked and what didn't. Turns out everything that
didn't work in Breezy-64 still doesn't work in Dapper-64 -- Flash,
Acroread 7, RealPlayer, Totem. (Totem at least stays up now; but it
still won't play a DVD.) I also noted that Synaptic listed far fewer
applications, even though it seemed to have all the repositories. But
the repositories all have different names, so who knows? 

At the last Clinic I replaced my 60 GB 4200 rpm hard disk with a shiny
new 80 GB 7200 rpm hard disk. When I formatted the new hard disk I
created a 60 GB partition for Ubuntu and left the remainder unused. It
was my plan to use that 20 GB to do a trial install of Dapper-64 later
after it was released. So after playing with the live DVD for a bit I
decided to do exactly that. The live DVD places a big icon on the
desktop that says "Install" on it in big letters. I clicked on it, and
a window popped up offering to install Dapper. 

By default it wanted to install it on the entire hard disk and reformat
it in the process. It took a bit of clicking around, but I finally
found the unused 20 GB. I told it to create HD3 on it and make it 8 GB,
and to install Dapper-64 on it. It proceeded to create the partition
and format it. I watched the progress meter and it definitely stopped
formatting at 8 GB (an important fact, as we shall see later). After it
finished the installation I restarted. Previously there were no boot
options, because the only OS on the computer was Breezy-64. When I
turned the computer on it always just booted by itself unattended. But
now I got a list of choices:

Ubuntu, kernel 2.6.15-25-amd64-generic
Ubuntu, kernel 2.6.15-25-amd64-generic recovery mode
Ubuntu, kernel 2.6.15-23-amd64-generic
Ubuntu, kernel 2.6.15-23-amd64-generic recovery mode
Ubuntu memtest
Other operating systems
Ubuntu, kernel 2.6.12-10-amd64-generic default (on /dev/hda2)
Ubuntu, kernel 2.6.12-10-amd64-generic default (on /dev/hda2) rec. mode 
Ubuntu, kernel 2.6.12-9-amd64-generic default (on /dev/hda2)
Ubuntu, kernel 2.6.12-9-amd64-generic default (on /dev/hda2) rec. mode 
(plus another set but I must not have written it down -- I know
       there were six here) 
Ubuntu memtest

So I let it just go ahead and run the one on the top. It booted up just
fine, except, of course, it lacked anything but the default
applications and settings. I played around with it for a bit, installed
a couple applications, checked out Totem again and noted it still
wouldn't play a DVD. I had been reading the Dapper-64 forum and I knew
that there was a new script to install all kinds of stuff, called
Automatix. So I downloaded it and tried it out (the script works only
on Dapper). Supposedly it will install Flash, Acroread 7, RealPlayer,
and the Mozilla plugins so they will work in Firefox-64. There were
several other choices on the menu, and I selected some of them,
including the nVidia proprietary drivers. (The open source nv driver
was what kept Totem from playing DVDs before on Breezy -- it worked
there after I installed the nVidia drivers.) The script finished, and
said I'd need to restart, so I shut down and restarted.

This time during the boot process it stopped and announced that the
filesystem had been mounted 30 times and a forced fsck was required. (I
had noted previously that it had said it had only a couple mounts left
before this would happen.) I let it proceed. And then it stopped the
fsck and announced that the drive had errors, and asked if I wanted it
to fix them. I told it to go ahead. I have no idea what it means, but
it found several messed up inodes. It said it fixed all of them. And
then it proceeded to finish booting.

When it came back up the first thing I noted was the nVidia
splashscreen. Then it gave me the login window. During the installation
it had asked for a username, so I had given it jjj and a password.
After logging in I tried Totem, and it happily started playing a DVD.
Then I tried Firefox, but no Acroread plugin, no Flash. From a command
line I tried to launch Acroread and RealPlayer, but they wouldn't
launch. 

To check out whether they were installed I fired up Nautilus and looked
at the filesystem. Wait ... what's this "chroot" folder? I clicked on
Home and there was my alternate username jxj ... then I clicked on my
jjj folder and ... wait ... here are all my files ... why are all my
files here on this new 8 GB partition? ... pause while the gears in the
upper story turn ... OMFG!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Nooooooooooo!!!!!!!!!!!!!

The sumbitch installed itself on top of my Breezy installation. 

And I don't mean an Upgrade. It was a complete new install. All my
programs gone. All my settings gone. Hundreds and hundreds of personal
settings. Aaaaaaaaaaaargh!!!!!!!!!!!

OK, I still have the old hard drive, still sitting in the USB enclosure
that I put it in after last month's clinic. Any settings changed since
last month would be gone, but practically everything should still be
there. Someone here once told me (while we were discussing backups)
that all those configurations are in .files in the user folder. I
turned on Show Hidden Files and they all seemed to be there. So why
didn't the new install use them? Hmmm. I fired up OpenOffice.org Writer
and it came up just like a new install. I have at least a hundred
settings just for Writer, and none of them were being used. <sigh>

OK, maybe if I boot some of those other options that Grub gave me. I
shut down and restarted, then chose the 2.6.15-23  option. It still
came up with the new install. Shut down and restart ... and this time I
tried the 2.6.12-10 option. Still came up with the new install. Tried
over and over. Everything came up with the new install. But wait ...
that can't be.  How could I be booting Dapper if I selected the
2.6.12-10 kernel? Maybe Grub is screwed up? Maybe that's what it
displays to me, but what it actually points at is the new install?

OK, shutdown and go for a walk. Screw it. There will be smart people at
the Clinic tomorrow.

Back home a couple hours later I decided to restart the computer. I
just let it start up the top listing, the 2.6.15-25 kernel. When it
came up I looked at the filesystem to peruse the .files again. Wait ...
where are they? They were all here a couple hours ago. Wait, chroot is
missing too. All my files are missing ... WTF? (I did have enough sense
to use Kdar to make a full backup this morning before embarking on this
escapade.) 

OK, this is not making any sense. I *know* those files were all there a
couple hours ago. 

Never mind. Shut down and restart. This time I'll choose the top
2.6.12-10 boot option. It proceeded to boot. And when it got to
Configuring Network Interfaces it suddenly hung. Now, y'all are
probably thinking I was getting ready to throw this whole thing into
the river. But actually I was thrilled. You see, my old install always
used to do that. Could it be it is booting my old Breezy? Fingers
crossed ... waiting ... waiting ... OMG it did!!!!!!!!!!!!! I'm back!
YAY!!!!!!!!!!!

OK, right now I have no idea what is going on. All I know is that my
old Breezy is running, Sylpheed finds all my mail folders and address
books, Firefox comes up with all my bookmarks; everything is as it was.
Is there a new 8 GB partition out there somewhere? Maybe. I fired up
Krusader to use its Mountman utility, but it just showed all the old
stuff. No new hd3 drive. "Mount" from the command line just shows
everything it always did.

OK, it's running and I'm not turning it off. Not until I bring it to
the Clinic tomorrow. Then maybe someone can help me figure stuff out.

Davidson cracks open his MacBook Pro to find out.

***What Is Jetty?
Of course Tomcat is the first Java application server you think of, but
is it the right tool for every job? The open source Jetty serves up JSPs
and servlets in just a fraction of the memory needed by other app
servers and is designed for easy embedding in other applications and
non-traditional Java environments. Ethan McCallum takes a look at the
big things in this small package.
<http://www.onjava.com/pub/a/onjava/2006/06/14/what-is-jetty.html>


***Achieving Inversion of Control with Eclipse RCP 
Eclipse RCP uses a popular plugin scheme for extending the capabilities
of the core platform. Meanwhile, the Inversion of Control pattern is a
popular means of having a runtime container provide an implementation of
some needed service. Put them together and effectively, you're plugging
in the implementation of your plugin. Riccardo Govoni shows how a little
bytecode manipulation makes this possible.
<http://www.onjava.com/pub/a/onjava/2006/06/07/ioc-for-eclipse-rcp.html>

OK, fdisk -l shows:

jjj at Devil5:~$ sudo fdisk -l
Password:

Disk /dev/hda: 80.0 GB, 80026361856 bytes
255 heads, 63 sectors/track, 9729 cylinders
Units = cylinders of 16065 * 512 = 8225280 bytes

Device Boot     Start   End          Blocks    Id   System
/dev/hda1            1      125      1004031   82  Linux swap / Solaris 
/dev/hda2          126   7421   58605120   83  Linux
/dev/hda3         7422  8441     8193150   83  Linux

So there it is. Exactly as it is supposed to be.

The mystery is why, when booting the new Dapper, it showed all my old
files. There are two possibilities, as far as I can figure. 1) The new
Dapper mounted my Breezy /dev/hda2 somewhere, and the blond boy got
confused and wandered into it by mistake, thus thinking Dapper had been
installed over the old Breezy installation or, 2) the messed up inodes
were the culprit and I'm not as blond as I seem. It would make me feel
much better if it turns out to be (2). I offer only one fact in support
of (2): I booted all five possibilities (two Dapper, three Breezy) and
each time I got Dapper, and I'm pretty sure each time all my files were
there, and each time I got the "fsck needed" warning and used Ctrl-D to
ignore it and boot anyway. It was AFTER I finally let it fix the
filesystem problems, which it said were messed up inodes, that booting
one of the Breezy options worked properly. I haven't tried anything since.

Besides getting messed up, what do inodes do?

From johnxj at comcast.net  Sun Jun 18 21:14:47 2006
From: johnxj at comcast.net (John Jason Jordan)
Date: Sun, 18 Jun 2006 21:14:47 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Screwed
Message-ID: <20060618211447.b4cbee96.johnxj@comcast.net>

Got home from the Clinic. Booted up, went to update my Breezy to
Dapper. Started with Update Manager, but it said a couple dozen
packages could not be updated unless I used "sudo apt-get dist-upgrade"
from the command line. I decided to use that option.

It downloaded a gig of new files (25 minutes at home), then started the
upgrade. A few moments later it stopped. It said that the configuration
file /etc/login something or another needed to be changed and did I
want to (choose several options). I selected "D" which was "tell me
more about the options" since I did not understand a word of what they
said. This caused the terminal to spew out a couple pages, none of
which was any more comprehensible. At the bottom of the screen it said
"END." Well, when you're in a man page and it says "END" you hit Ctrl-z
to get out, right? So that's what I did. Whereupon it announced that
the "sudo apt-get dist-upgrade" process had terminated by user input.

Tip to programmers: Give the user an effin' CLUE. Some of us were not
born knowing how to run Linux from the command line.

So there I was sitting at a command prompt. The upgrade had started,
but not gone far. What to do? I decided just to restart the upgrade. So
I arrowed up and gave it the "sudo apt-get dist-upgrade" line again.
This restarted the process, and it seemed to proceed sort of from where
it left off, except I couldn't tell exactly where it left off. At least
it definitely did not re-download the files. It quickly got to the same
configuration file problem. This time I wisely selected Y (select the
developer's file). It proceeded to spew out pages and pages of stuff it
was doing. It all looked good, except that every once in a while I
noticed "Warning: Unable to delete old directory /x/x/x/. The directory
is not empty." This happened a couple dozen times over the next hundred
pages that flowed through the terminal window.

Finally it got sort of to the end, and announced that there were unmet
dependencies. Lots of them. It suggested "sudo apt - something" (can't
remember now) that would resolve the dependencies. I did so. It seemed
to fix some things, but a few refused to be fixed. Finally I decided
I'd done all I could do. I shut down and rebooted.

When it came back up there were pages of error messages during the boot
process, X wouldn't start, and I was staring at a command line. I
fiddled around a bit, then finally gave up. There are three old Breezy
selections on the Grub boot menu, and each has a recovery mode option.
I tried them all, but no hope. The recovery mode options just dump me
at a command line. That would be wonderful if I had any idea what to do
at the command line. I tried the "sudo apt-get dist-upgrade" line
again, but it did no more than it had done before when the GUI was
still running, i.e., nothing other than announce there were unmet
dependencies.

I am currently booted into the new Dapper installation on the new 8 GB
partition. Someone (at a Clinic, IIRC) told me that application
configuration files were located in hidden . folders in the user's home
folder. This new Dapper installation automatically mounts the old hda2
Breezy partition, so I dragged OO.o's . folder from there into the /home/jjj/
folder here, then fired up OO.o. Yay! It worked. Then I installed
Sylpheed and did the same for its . configuration file. Yay! The mail
folders are missing, but all my accounts are here. So I can send this
to the list and see any responses. (I could also do it from my Windows
desktop, but that would be caving in to the empire.)

Right now I am thinking of just taking the Ubuntu-64 Dapper DVD that I

On Sun, 18 Jun 2006, John Jason Jordan wrote:
> At the bottom of the screen it said "END." Well, when you're in a man 
> page and it says "END" you hit Ctrl-z to get out, right?

No.  CTRL-Z suspends a process in bash.  Do you just run your machine with 
an ever-rising number of suspended "man" processes?

You quit the pager with Q.

> Finally it got sort of to the end, and announced that there were unmet 
> dependencies. Lots of them. It suggested "sudo apt - something" (can't 
> remember now) that would resolve the dependencies. I did so. It seemed 
> to fix some things, but a few refused to be fixed. Finally I decided I'd 
> done all I could do. I shut down and rebooted.

You rebooted in the middle of a failing upgrade.  Your system told you 
very clearly that your upgrade didn't go the way it should and that 
packages were not upgraded properly... and you rebooted the machine -- a 
process that requires the system to go back and reload all of the running 
programs that were working just fine in memory now (but, as your machine 
just clearly told you, might not be in good shape on disk) from disk.

> When it came back up there were pages of error messages during the boot 
> process, X wouldn't start, and I was staring at a command line. I 
> fiddled around a bit, then finally gave up. There are three old Breezy 
> selections on the Grub boot menu, and each has a recovery mode option. I 
> tried them all, but no hope. The recovery mode options just dump me at a 
> command line. That would be wonderful if I had any idea what to do at 
> the command line. I tried the "sudo apt-get dist-upgrade" line again, 
> but it did no more than it had done before when the GUI was still 
> running, i.e., nothing other than announce there were unmet 
> dependencies.

So you look at the packages with unmet dependences and address them one at 
a time, either resolving the dependency problem or removing the package as 
is appropriate.

Now, I don't know anything about "Breezy" and "Dapper", but I know that 
you shouldn't be getting unmet dependency issues from a stable version 
using official repositories.  Are you upgrading to a stable version from 
official repositories?

If so, then you are in one of two situations:  There's a temporary fubar 
at the repository and if you keep updating your apt-cache (with apt-get 
update) and trying the upgrade again, it'll fix get fixed when the 
repository's back in order OR your distribution is maintained by lunkheads 
and you should probably go to something more reasonable.  I use Debian 
myself.

> I am currently booted into the new Dapper installation on the new 8 GB 
> partition. Someone (at a Clinic, IIRC) told me that application 
> configuration files were located in hidden . folders in the user's home 
> folder. This new Dapper installation automatically mounts the old hda2 
> Breezy partition, so I dragged OO.o's . folder from there into the 
> /home/jjj/ folder here, then fired up OO.o. Yay! It worked. Then I 
> installed Sylpheed and did the same for its . configuration file. Yay! 
> The mail folders are missing, but all my accounts are here. So I can 
> send this to the list and see any responses. (I could also do it from my 
> Windows desktop, but that would be caving in to the empire.)

Um, why did you create new home directories?!?

Probably your mail is in ~/mail or ~/Mail.  I only use Sylpheed with an 
IMAP account, so there are no local mail folders.  However, pine and mutt 
keep their mail in ~/mail.  These are not considered "application 
configuration data", of course.  This is your personal data and 
application-independent.

> Right now I am thinking of just taking the Ubuntu-64 Dapper DVD that I 
> burned and use it to do a new install over my old Breezy hda2 partition.

John Jason Jordan wrote:
> when you're in a man page and it says "END" you hit Ctrl-z
> to get out, right?

No, ctrl+z suspends the active terminal application.  Use fg to resume 
it.  bg to resume it in the background.  You hit "q" to get out of less 
or a man page once you're done with it.

Don't use ctrl+z unless you want to suspend the application you're using 
to do something else...

Rob

Typing help (or really, h) would have gotten you to a nice menu with a
bunch of help on it. The second line of which says " q  :q  Q  :Q  ZZ
Exit." In the meantime, you may want to invest in a free online command
line tutorial, or a book such as "A Practical Guide to Linux Commands,
Editors, and Shell Programming" by Mark Sobell, either of which would
probably introduce the pager, and in general how to use the command line.
You will find that often
the command line is required for some operations, and often a lot better
at doing them (wysiwyg editing aside) than a gui counterpart. On my own
system the xserver exists to give me a pretty background while a terminal
window is open. One window, because I like GNU screen.

You may have better luck in the future with using aptitude, as it is a lot
better at getting deep dependancies that apt-get misses. I believe it is
the recommended way of doing a dist-upgrade (though recommended by who, I
don't know). Aptitude has a weird little interface if you just run the
command, but I believe you can
type the same commands as when you run apt-get as well (so, in this case,
aptitude dist-upgrade). I haven't used Debian in a long time so I can't
actually check.

using Diald. These scenarios include a ... 3. Quick Diald operation
description ...
www.linux.com/howtos/Diald-HOWTO.shtml - 19k - Cached - Similar pages

Linux diald discussion
archives for Linux diald discussion mailing lists.
www.archivesat.com/Linux_diald_discussion/ - 5k - Cached - Similar pages

among the 288,000 hits it found.

> (3) Finally, how would I go about partitioning my hard drive? At the clinic
> I was being helped greatly, we first tried to partition using an Ubuntu
> disc (I don't know much more than this...) but we didn't want to wait until
> the sun went down, It was taking quite awhile. Does this Knoppix Live CD
> have something on it like that Ubuntu one does that will enable me to do
> this?

   You have several options; all should be run from the command line and in
single-user mode. If you can access the man pages for 'fdisk,' 'cfdisk,' or
'parted' you'll get the syntax to use them. From the Winduhs world ... it's
been far too long for me to remember the tool used.

   I do know that with the old Red Hat installation cds, and Slackware, too,
for that matter, the first thing you're offered is the ability to repartition
your hard drive. I've never worked with a GUI-based distribution such as
Ubuntu, and have booted Knoppix only a couple of times to rescue me from the
errors of my ways, but they may have boot images that will get you to a linux
command prompt where you could run fdisk or cfdisk. That may be intimidating,
but pressing 'h' gets you help, and as long as you don't write anything to
the partition table you can quit without harm.

   Before you do any of this, however, I strongly suggest that you decide how
you want to partition your disk. There are arguably as many opinions on the
"best" way to partition a hard drive as there are on the "best" distribution,
editor, or window/desktop manager. Take advice you trust until you learn
enough to know just what you want. Then, the next time you replace a hard
drive, partition it to your tastes.

HTH,

Rich

Hello Eric,

On Jun 19, 2006, at 10:48 AM, Eric Biggs wrote:
> I was at the clinic this Sunday and after unsuccessfully trying to  
> partition my hard drive, simply went home with a Knoppix Live CD.

Which version of the Knoppix CD do you have?

> (3) Finally, how would I go about partitioning my hard drive?  At  
> the clinic I was being helped greatly, we first tried to partition  
> using an Ubuntu disc (I don't know much more than this...) but we  
> didn't want to wait until the sun went down, It was taking quite  
> awhile.  Does this Knoppix Live CD have something on it like that  
> Ubuntu one does that will enable me to do this?

Yes.  Knoppix has lots of tools.  The command line tools are powerful  
but somewhat cryptic.  A nice GUI tool is QTparted ( K > System >  
QTParted ) which allows you to add, remove, and format partitions.   
QTparted can also resize some partitions under in certain situations.

Ultimately, what are you trying to do?  Do you wish to install linux  
as a single-OS system, install as a dual boot, only run from the CD,  
something else?

On Sunday 18 June 2006 9:14 pm, John Jason Jordan wrote:
> Tip to programmers: Give the user an effin' CLUE. Some of us were not
> born knowing how to run Linux from the command line.

If you're going to be your own sysadmin, you better acquire the knowledge to 
do it right. I agree that a lot of program output and error messages could be 
more helpful and friendlier. On the other hand, this is not some sort of wild 
new undocumented cutting-edge task- it is very well-documented. Wise persons 
study first. If reading howtos is too tedious, practice on a nothing-to-lose 
system, not your main PC. 

An operating system upgrade is not trivial. Only in the Linux world is this a 
routine task requiring just a little bit of knowledge to perform 
successfully. Pretty amazing piece of engineering, it is. Don't blame the 
devs for your lack of preparation.

On Mon, 19 Jun 2006, Carla Schroder wrote:

> An operating system upgrade is not trivial. Only in the Linux world is this
> a routine task requiring just a little bit of knowledge to perform
> successfully.

   I discovered that upgrading Slackware to be much simpler and easier than
was upgrading Red Hat. It now takes about a half-hour per machine, and most
of that time it's running upgradepkg on everthing installed. Even the kernel
is upgraded for me; a reboot and there we are with a shiny new kernel.

> Pretty amazing piece of engineering, it is. Don't blame the devs for your
> lack of preparation.

   It is a tribute to the folks who built on 35 years of UNIX to make linux
what it is.

   Regarding preparation, there are so many books, on-line resources, and
other sources of information readily available there is no valid excuse to
not learn the basics.

    People need training and licenses before they can drive, fly an airplane,
or drive a boat (in most states). In most professions, basic preparation via
college degrees is also mandatory, and some (lawyering and engineering come
to mind) require continuing education to maintain one's license. So, why
should learning something about an inherently multi-taking, multi-user OS not
be expected by new users? If the answer is, "I don't want to make the
effort," then use what Microsoft offers and let them do your thinking.

available that I know of. So I have to ask questions. If my questions
and occasional cries of anguish annoy you, then put me in your kill
filter. I might add that no one in my entire life ever accused me of
not having an opinion or of keeping it to myself. Another reason for
you to ignore me.

everything is working. What isn't working looks like stuff that I can

On 6/19/06, Chris Dawson <xrdawson at gmail.com> wrote:
> This is not Linux related, but I feel like asking this in the company
> of other geeks, so sorry for the off topic posting.  I am looking into
> buying a digital SLR.  I stopped at Camera World today.  I want a
> basic camera with removable lenses.  I liked the Nikon D50.  Does
> anyone have strong feelings for or against this?  Does anyone have
> other cameras between $500-$1000 that they would recommend?  Does
> anyone have a store locally in Portland, or a Internet vendor which
> they recommend?

I like ProPhoto supply on 19th and ..... the M street in NW Portland
(one block north of lovejoy).

I've been using a D70 for about 2 years and love it -- I wish it had a
splitprism or was a rangefinder, but thoes options aren't around in
the digital camera world yet.

The kit lens on the D70 is really nice, although it does vignette a
bit around the edges at the extreme focal lengths.  Batter life is
fantastic -- I've probably shot over 1k pictures on one charge +
downloaded them straight from the camera.  The D50 probably fixes
this, but despite advertising USB 2.0, the D70 only downloads at USB
1.1 speeds (easily fixed with a pcmcia cf card reader.)  I'm also much
happier with the controll layout on the nikons than the cannon's I've
used, that may just be me though -- I'm left-eyed, but right-handed,
so my cheek often gets in the way of controlls that may be easily
accessed by others.

I'm not a serious enough photographer to talk about color and noise,
so I'll stop here :)

dpreview.com is a great place to look, if you haven't read their reviews yet.

--Rogan


From johnxj at comcast.net  Mon Jun 19 18:07:44 2006
From: johnxj at comcast.net (John Jason Jordan)
Date: Mon, 19 Jun 2006 18:07:44 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Mean dependency killer needed, Clark Kent size
Message-ID: <20060619180744.db770f4b.johnxj@comcast.net>

Well, I HAD it running. My upgrade of Breezy to Dapper, I mean. Only a
couple problems remained, and I thought they would be simple.

The first one I tackled was that OO.o would not launch and its icon
that I keep in the gnome panel turned into a ? inside a yellow
triangle. I decided to do a reinstall, so I opened Synaptic. But
Synaptic announced I had broken packages. So I used the Broken Package
filter to find them and reinstall them. That solved the problem for all
but ia32-libs. 

Now, as far as I can tell, the whole damn Ubuntu operating system needs
ia32-libs. OK, that may be a bit of an exaggeration. But it seems like
everything uses it, and everything seems to depend on it. At least that
seems to be true for OO.o, the nvidia-glx driver, streamtuner, and
several other libraries. Synaptic won't touch it. 

Ubuntu Dapper-64 forums are full of posts from users having problems
with it. One person said he managed to fix it by going to a command
line, removing nvidia-glx, removing ia32-libs, then reinstalling
nvidia-glx. That didn't work for me. I successfully removed nvidia-glx,
but when I tried to remove ia32-libs, all I got was an error message. 

Another person said he had success when he renamed /etc/bin/ldd
to /etc/bin/ldd.old (I may have misremembered the folders). Didn't work
for me.

I've tried:

sudo apt-get -f remove -- which said it could not remove ia32-libs
sudo dpkg --configure -a -- which said it couldn't deal with ia32-libs
sudo apt-get dist-update -- which said it finished except there was an
unmet dependency with ia32-libs sudo apt-get remove ia32-libs -- which
said it couldn't remove ia32-libs

And finally, the command that is supposed to make the dead walk again:

sudo apt-get remove ia32-libs --purge

Which still won't touch it.

And after all the messing around, now it won't boot to the GUI any more.

Any suggestions?

From johnxj at comcast.net  Mon Jun 19 19:56:29 2006
From: johnxj at comcast.net (John Jason Jordan)
Date: Mon, 19 Jun 2006 19:56:29 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Mdbtools
Message-ID: <20060619195629.1b7f5ef7.johnxj@comcast.net>

This is to the gentleman at the Clinic who was trying to get OO.o on
his Suse 9.3 to read a Microsoft Access file so he can finally ditch
Windows completely. Sorry, I forgot your name. But I did it. So in case
you haven't succeeded yet, here is how I did it. I have a MS Access
file here that I have been trying to get into. While waiting for
inspiration to arrive bearing information on how to get my old
Breezy-upgraded-to-Dapper installation working, I was in my new, fresh
Dapper installation trying things out. As I said at the Clinic, I had
tried mdbtools before under Breezy with OO.o 1.93.129 and I couldn't
get it to work. Well, now it does.

This is a default installation of Ubuntu Dapper-64 from DVD, which also
installed OO.o 2.02. Using Synaptic (Debian equivalent of YaST), I
installed mdbtools. (I also installed mdbtools-gmdb, which is supposed
to be a file viewer for Access databases, but it crashes on trying to
open a file, so evidently it is allergic to Debian or something.) 

Once I had mdbtools installed I opened a new, blank OO.o Base file and
told it to open the Access database file. It did so and showed the
table. I was able to see the data. (It's an Old English to Modern
English dictionary of 28,000 words.) However, I couldn't edit the data.
Nothing would allow me to touch it. Like Mom used to say, look, don't
touch.

Then I opened a Writer document and hit F4. That opens up a window
where you can look at whatever databases you have "registered." (Base
will register it for you automatically.) I saw the database listed,
clicked down to see the table, and the data immediately displayed at
the top of the screen, sort of like a table in a spreadsheet. I
selected a dozen records or so and dragged them down to the writer
document. That opened up a dialog box where I could choose what fields
I wanted to import, and so on. And when I clicked on OK it imported
them right into the Writer document. 

Now, I still couldn't touch the data above the Writer document where it
was displayed from the database. No editing the .mdb file. But once it
was read into the Writer document I was free to do with it anything I
wanted. In other words, you could use this to get the table into a
table within Writer, convert the table to text (specifying commas or
tabs or something for delimiters), and then save the document as a CSV
data file. And once you had that you could import it into Base and have
a real open source database.

I don't know if you need Ubuntu to do this. It seems to me that all you
need is OO.o 2.02 or better and mdbtools, so no need to change your
Suse installation.

John Jason Jordan wrote:
> In my mind, I wasn't in an application. An application is OpenOffice.org Writer. It is Sylpheed. It is Firefox. It is NOT a terminal window. But that is really irrelevant.
>   
So applications are only things that have a GUI? Or could it be that 
your definition of application is a little narrow?

A terminal is an application. You can run other applications in the 
terminal, if you run the terminal in the right mode. It's also possible 
to run the terminal in such a mode that it won't run but one application 
in it, and that it exits when you close that application. That doesn't 
make the terminal any less of an application.


> My bitch is that YOU know how to get out of the situation, but I did not.
Were we born with that information? No. We learned it by reading manuals 
or somehow coming across the information just as you have. I'm sure you 
are not the first person to do this, and you certainly won't be the last.
>  I am an ordinary user. It would have taken maybe ten seconds for the developer to have added a line after "END" that said how to get out of it.
How is the programmer to know what pager program you are using? What if 
you are using a pager that uses [left-ctrl][right-shift][F1] to quit, 
and they put in that you press [ctrl]z to quit?

There are many pagers, and not all of them use ctrl-z to exit.
>  Instead, the developer assumed I had your knowledge of Linux. As a result I am now faced with the problem of how to clean up a godawful mess. I refuse to accept the blame for poor documentation.
>   
No, they assume you have the knowledge to find out how to use your system.

No one is born with this knowledge. People learn it... or not.

From nixlists at writemoore.net  Tue Jun 20 02:08:09 2006
From: nixlists at writemoore.net (Michael M.)
Date: Tue, 20 Jun 2006 02:08:09 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] I should have known better
In-Reply-To: <20060617172140.2443fe59.johnxj@comcast.net>
References: <20060617172140.2443fe59.johnxj@comcast.net>

John Jason Jordan wrote:
> Than to try to install Dapper by myself. 
>   

<snipped>

I spent much of the past several days reconsidering, retrying, 
retooling, and reinstalling ... not just Dapper, but Debian (Sarge & 
Etch), Ubuntu Breezy, Arch, Gentoo, and FreeBSD.  I hope you got Dapper 
working, but I gave up on it.  I think I'm officially writing off Ubuntu 
for the foreseeable future (which is to say, at least until the next 
release).  I did eventually get it installed, and mostly configured, but 
only after considerable headaches.  The Dapper installer didn't work for 
me unless I installed by accepting the default partitions (/ and /swap 
partitions only) on the whole disk or on unpartitioned free space.  Any 
attempt to partition my discs the way I wanted resulted in the installer 
hanging.  I couldn't even create a separate home partition.  Ditto any 
attempt to install on existing partitions.  Finally, I gave up, 
installed Breezy, and upgraded from there.  That worked.  But after all 
that, I decided it's not really what I want.

So after playing around with some other distros (and one other OS), and 
a visit to Powell's Technical, I decided to go back to Debian (Etch, 
this time) and try to learn the hard way.  :-)  That is, I got a couple 
of books:  Debian GNU/Linux 3.1 Bible and The Debian System.  I think 
part of my problem with using Linux has been my piecemeal approach to 
fixing problems as they come up, rather than trying really to understand 
what's going on -- understanding not just why something goes wrong, but 
also why it goes right.  In other words, I don't really get how it all 
works.  Playing around with Arch Linux and, to a lesser extent, Gentoo, 
helped give me some perspective on how other distros do things.  It's 
useful and interesting for helping to separate out what things are 
common to "Linux" from what's specific to Debian (and Debian-based) 
distros.  But I think, for me, the best way to learn is to stop the 
dabbling for awhile, dive into one distro headfirst, and try to learn 
what happens from the moment the machine gets turned on until it gets 
shutdown.  Debian is one of the better documented and best-supported 
distros around, despite not having a corporate backer, so I'm going with 
that.  If there'd been two relatively recent several-hundred-page books 
each documenting Arch, Gentoo, or Slackware, I might've gone with one of 
those, as I like the simplicity of their layouts in comparison to 
Debian.  (Ubuntu, on the other hand, is just too complex -- like Debian, 
but harder.)  If there exists somewhere a course like "Linux for 
Non-Programmers," I'll sign-up.

Although, having said that, I also picked up Mark Sobel's "A Practical 
Guide to Linux Commands, Editors, and Shell Programming."  I got it more 
for the the commands and editors parts than the shell programming part, 
but maybe I'll learn something.


-- 
Michael M. ++ Portland, OR ++ USA

Sorry to hear about your headaches with Dapper. I am still having
problems with the upgrade for my old Breezy-64 installation. Got some
thorny dependency issues that refuse to get fixed -- specifically
involving ia32-libs. It refuses to be removed, reinstalled, purged or

xorg.conf to switch from "nvidia" to "nv," but it still won't start X.

Meantime, I have the other Dapper-64 installation running just great --
the one I installed into an unused portion of the drive. I've spent
several hours in it so far and I love it. I am confident that I will be
able to do everything with Dapper-64 without needing chroot. I've got
Adobe Reader running, Firefox 1.5 with Flash and RealPlayer (still
working on the Adobe Reader plugin, but others have it working), and
all the rest of the tools I need. Most of the time I've spent in it was
spent reading Ubuntu forums to find out clever tricks for getting stuff
to install -- like using "force architecture" to get Adobe Reader 7.01 to
install. The forums are one of Ubuntu's strong points.

I have a hard time learning abstract stuff from books. I need hands-on
to learn something. (In Education we'd say I was kinesthetic.) There
are no two humans on the planet who learn the same way. Worse, we
humans have a terrible tendency to assume everyone is the same as us,
hence everyone assumes that they way they learned how to use computers
is what everyone else ought to do. And classes are good for real
beginners, but there are also problems with timing and relevancy.
Nevertheless, those books you mentioned do sound good. A command line
reference would be especially useful. The only problem is that every
one I have seen (including websites) is arranged alphabetically by
command. That isn't very helpful if you need to know how to fix
ia32-libs. Does Sobel's book have at least a good index?

Having tried Red Hat, Ubuntu, Arch, Gentoo, et al (9 years of Linux), I
finally settled on Arch.  Have tried others since I started using Arch, but
keep coming back.  (Writing this on Toshiba Satellite over its built-in
802.11g WiFI -- using all native Arch binaries.)  Am also biased toward KDE
(makes Suspend-to-RAM just work, for example).  Why do I pick these?  I like
to enjoy my PC experience.  Heh.

For example, I don't like having to install a distro and then run around
finding mp3 and nVidia binaries from other sources -- and hoping the other
sources have packages that were put together with the same care as the folks
in the dristro.

The Arch forums are close to a "Linux for Non-Programmers".  The Wiki is
also good -- though it tends to be a bit stale, at times.  Have found the
Gentoo Wiki more complete / up-to-date and often applies closely to the Arch
environment.

> So the source IP is the server and there where probes to all the ports you 
> mentioned.

> Some questions I can think of:
> 
> Is there anything in the logs to indicate the source port.

Here's a typical iptables log entry:

  Jun 20 07:15:38 host20 kernel: ** OUT_TCP DROP ** IN= OUT=eth0
  SRC=206.180.226.20 DST=203.206.95.1 LEN=44 TOS=0x00 PREC=0x00 TTL=64
  ID=0 DF PROTO=TCP SPT=80 DPT=64 WINDOW=5840 RES=0x00 ACK SYN URGP=0

Yes, the source port is logged, 80 in the line above.

> How many interfaces are there on the host?

18, including the loopback, 2 physical.

> Which interfaces did iptables block?

The physical interface that handles all outgoing traffic; the other
interface is part of a back net.

> It might be helpful to actually see some of the log entries.

  Jun 20 07:18:27 host20 kernel: ** OUT_TCP DROP ** IN= OUT=eth0

Subject: [PLUG] Three laptop hangs in 24 hours
Message-ID: <20060620155026.GA3982@gate.kl-ic.com>


Normally, my linux laptop goes weeks between reboots (thought it
is often closed and suspended).  In the last 24 hours, it has
gone into system freeze three times (once while trying to use
audacity, once while coming out of suspend, and once while web
surfing this morning).  No evidence left in /var/log/*

I am running really old Redhat 9 with an updated 2.4 kernel (why?
long story).

I suspect the problem is related to enabling the serial port in
the BIOS (the only major change in the last couple of days).   
However, I was hearing passing comments about lockups from Eric
Wilhelm at Advanced Topics last night, and I believe Michael
Rassmussen was having problems recently.  So before I assume that
the problem is the serial port, I am wondering if there are others
who have been seeing a sudden increase in hangs.  If this is 
general, it might indicate some subtle new security problem.

Q1) Has anyone else seen a recent unexplained increase in system hangs?

It would also be handy to load a tool that can monitor the laptop
and save more log information about the system freeze.  Even if
turning off the serial port fixes this, I want to know *why*.

Q2) Can anyone suggest a better tool to monitor system freezes?

Keith

From evan at evanheidtmann.info  Tue Jun 20 09:12:25 2006
From: evan at evanheidtmann.info (Evan Heidtmann)
Date: Tue, 20 Jun 2006 12:12:25 -0400
Subject: [PLUG] off-topic: digital camera recommendation
In-Reply-To: <659b9ea30606191716x22f0803xeb8854bb33d8de49@mail.gmail.com>
References: <659b9ea30606191716x22f0803xeb8854bb33d8de49@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <1150819945.23312.20.camel@luffy>

I've never used a D50. I used a D70 the other day for about 5 minutes,
and I didn't really see anything wrong with it.

I have been very pleased with my Canon Digital Rebel XT (aka 350D). It's
very quick, light, and easy to operate. The kit lens is disappointing,
but it's my understanding that pretty much all kit lenses are.

I recommend you take a close look at the reviews on this site:

http://dpreview.com/

They do very good reviews of a lot of cameras, and even if they don't
have a review, they will have a comprehensive list of specs. The Nikon
D50 review is here:

http://www.dpreview.com/reviews/nikond50/

You will be able to get a good camera for under $1000, but if you want
to enjoy your new toy to its fullest, you'll be investing in some good
lenses, which can put you about as far over $1000 as you want.

I bought my Rebel XT from a local store in the Beaverton area called
Advance Camera. They're good and very knowledgeable, but they're a small
store so you may have to buy the camera before you can lay your hands on
it.

That is a very important point. Make sure you handle the camera before
you buy it -- it really matters how well it fits in your hands.

-Evan

Somebody has helpfully packaged the flash plugin as an RPM.  You can
setup the yum repository by following the instructions at
http://macromedia.mplug.org/ but it is easier to just install the rpm
directly.

rpm -Uvh http://macromedia.mplug.org/rpm/RPMS.macromedia/flash-plugin-7.0.63-1.i386.rpm

If you are still having problems, check the mozilla and firefox plugin
directories to make sure the symlinks are correct.

From tcslighter at gmail.com  Tue Jun 20 12:21:51 2006
From: tcslighter at gmail.com (Tim Slighter)
Date: Tue, 20 Jun 2006 12:21:51 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] snort_inline
In-Reply-To: <200606201204.28293.carla@bratgrrl.com>
References: <200606192225.04609.carla@bratgrrl.com>
	<200606201112.46182.carla@bratgrrl.com>
	<65244f100606201133h1196fa7o6ece434d7216cf4f@mail.gmail.com>
	<200606201204.28293.carla@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <65244f100606201221r5205971bp255cfc48728ae710@mail.gmail.com>

You are right, I got most of my information using the snort manual for
how to configure and change the rules.  It is pretty straightforward.
You will need to have a specific version of libnids from packetfactory
and when you attempt to build using

./configure --enable-flexresp

it will tell you exactly what version you need and where to get it.

the rules come down to react and resp depending upon which side of the
connection you want to drop.  Sorry I cannot be of much more help in
terms of documentation.  If want an already configured version that
runs from a bootable cd, check out network security toolkit at -
http://www.networksecuritytoolkit.org.

http://stanton-finley.net/fedora_core_5_installation_notes.html

I've also used his suggestions for Java with Ubuntu.

Chris Fosnight

From tcslighter at gmail.com  Tue Jun 20 15:55:17 2006
From: tcslighter at gmail.com (Tim Slighter)
Date: Tue, 20 Jun 2006 15:55:17 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] snort_inline
In-Reply-To: <200606201552.06966.carla@bratgrrl.com>
References: <200606192225.04609.carla@bratgrrl.com>
	<200606201204.28293.carla@bratgrrl.com>
	<65244f100606201221r5205971bp255cfc48728ae710@mail.gmail.com>
	<200606201552.06966.carla@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <65244f100606201555x1ecac64cx5580fd6b0418b3e6@mail.gmail.com>

Straight out of the snort manual:


3.7.3 resp

The resp keyword is used attempt to close sessions when an alert is
triggered. In Snort, this is called flexible response.

Flexible Response supports the following mechanisms for attempting to
close sessions:

Option	Description	
rst_snd	Send TCP-RST packets to the sending socket	
rst_rcv	Send TCP-RST packets to the receiving socket	
rst_all	Send TCP_RST packets in both directions	
icmp_net	Send a ICMP_NET_UNREACH to the sender	
icmp_host	Send a ICMP_HOST_UNREACH to the sender	
icmp_port	Send a ICMP_PORT_UNREACH to the sender	
icmp_all	Send all above ICMP packets to the sender	

These options can be combined to send multiple responses to the target host.

3.7.3.1 Format


resp: <resp_mechanism>[,<resp_mechanism>[,<resp_mechanism>]];

3.7.3.2 Warnings

This functionality is not built in by default. Use the -
-enable-flexresp flag to configure when building Snort to enable this
functionality.

Be very careful when using Flexible Response. It is quite easy to get
Snort into an infinite loop by defining a rule such as:


alert tcp any any -> any any (resp:rst_all;)

It is easy to be fooled into interfering with normal network traffic as well.

3.7.3.3 Example

The following example attempts to reset any TCP connection to port 1524.

alert tcp any any -> any 1524 (flags:S; resp:rst_all;)

3.7.4 react

This keyword implements an ability for users to react to traffic that
matches a Snort rule. The basic reaction is blocking interesting sites
users want to access: New York Times, slashdot, or something really
important - napster and porn sites. The React code allows Snort to
actively close offending connections and/or send a visible notice to
the browser. The notice may include your own comment. The following
arguments (basic modifiers) are valid for this option:

block - close connection and send the visible notice
warn - send the visible, warning notice (will be available soon)
The basic argument may be combined with the following arguments
(additional modifiers):

msg - include the msg option text into the blocking visible notice
proxy: port_nr - use the proxy port to send the visible notice (will
be available soon)
Multiple additional arguments are separated by a comma. The react
keyword should be placed as the last one in the option list.

3.7.4.1 Format


react: <react_basic_modifier[, react_additional_modifier]>;
	
Figure 3.22: React Usage Example

3.7.4.2 Warnings

React functionality is not built in by default. This code is currently
bundled under Flexible Response, so enabling Flexible Response
(-enable-flexresp) will also enable React.

Be very careful when using react. Causing a network traffic generation
loop is very easy to do with this functionality.

From nixlists at writemoore.net  Tue Jun 20 19:10:06 2006
From: nixlists at writemoore.net (Michael M.)
Date: Tue, 20 Jun 2006 19:10:06 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] I should have known better
In-Reply-To: <53107f6e0606200657p51c87cd9m6df451b42b977a5@mail.gmail.com>
References: <20060617172140.2443fe59.johnxj@comcast.net>	<4497BAF9.1030707@writemoore.net>
	<53107f6e0606200657p51c87cd9m6df451b42b977a5@mail.gmail.com>
Message-ID: <4498AA7E.7050008@writemoore.net>

Jon Scully wrote:
>
> Having tried Red Hat, Ubuntu, Arch, Gentoo, et al (9 years of Linux), I
> finally settled on Arch.  Have tried others since I started using 
> Arch, but
> keep coming back.  (Writing this on Toshiba Satellite over its built-in
> 802.11g WiFI -- using all native Arch binaries.)  Am also biased 
> toward KDE
> (makes Suspend-to-RAM just work, for example).  Why do I pick these?  
> I like
> to enjoy my PC experience.  Heh.

Arch is awesome in oh so many ways but one, IMO.  What I like about Arch 
is its adherence to the "KISS" principle.  Just doing an installation of 
Arch is a great learning experience for any newbie because in one simple 
document, the whole configuration of your entire base system (excluding 
X) is laid out:

http://www.archlinux.org/docs/en/guide/install/arch-install-guide.html#config

It wasn't until I used Arch that I finally began to understand a little 
bit of how Linux is put together, what types of devices and settings are 
configured from which files and run by which scripts.  Debian 
complicates things considerably, at least in comparison to Arch.

The problem is that Arch is too bleeding edge for me, at least right 
now.  I thought about trying to run a static version of Arch, by just 
sticking to the release.  But that's not really how Arch is designed to 
work, and it probably wouldn't be very satisfying.  It might if Arch had 
a more predictable, regular release schedule, but it doesn't.  So you're 
left with the constant updates, and the risk that some buggy 
something-or-other will prevent such-and-such, which worked fine 
yesterday, from working today.  Often, the fix is relatively simple, 
like symlinking some library to something, but it gets wearying.  I 
think Arch needs to work a little more on quality control.  This 
wouldn't be a problem if I was knowledgeable enough to do my own QC -- 
i.e., if I could look at an Arch package file and figure out why it 
won't install or why the program refuses to run -- but I'm not there 
yet.  And what I *really* don't understand about Arch is why the devs 
insist on using the newest kernel at the earliest possible moment.  The 
Linux kernel development process itself is somewhat problematic -- I 
read that the kernel devs are considering putting a freeze on new 
features to concentrate on bug squashing for awhile, and I really hope 
they do that.  Put together kernel bugs, software bugs, occasional 
oopsies in Arch packages, and the winds of fortune, and you end up with 
a system where something or other isn't working right, on a fairly 
regular basis.  At least, that's been my experience.  Of course, the 
software bugs will bite you wherever you're using the software in 
question, but at least distros that aren't as cutting edge don't have 
quite so much else going on.

>
> For example, I don't like having to install a distro and then run around
> finding mp3 and nVidia binaries from other sources -- and hoping the 
> other
> sources have packages that were put together with the same care as the 
> folks
> in the dristro.

Well I don't think that's so much a problem with Debian or Ubuntu, since 
ultimately they're all put together by the same people, just some of 
them acting in an unofficial capacity.  With Debian, I think all the 
nVidia stuff is available from non-free (but I don't use the proprietary 
drivers, so I might be wrong), and all the multimedia stuff comes from 
debian-multimedia.org, which is maintained by Debian devs.  Even 
Backports.org is maintained by the folks in the distro -- it's just not 
an "official" repository.  When you're talking about community-based 
distros like Arch and Debian, I don't see the big difference between 
what's official and what isn't.

>
> The Arch forums are close to a "Linux for Non-Programmers".  The Wiki is
> also good -- though it tends to be a bit stale, at times.  Have found the
> Gentoo Wiki more complete / up-to-date and often applies closely to 
> the Arch
> environment.

Yeah, the Arch forums tend to be a very good resource, and the Gentoo 
Wiki is amazing -- really, it's a model for what distro Wiki's should 
be.  Ubuntu's is probably the next best, of those I've looked at.

-- 
Michael M. ++ Portland, OR ++ USA
"No live organism can continue for long to exist sanely under conditions of absolute reality; even larks and katydids are supposed, by some, to dream." --S. Jackson

John Jason Jordan wrote:
> I have a hard time learning abstract stuff from books. I need hands-on
> to learn something. (In Education we'd say I was kinesthetic.) There
> are no two humans on the planet who learn the same way. Worse, we
> humans have a terrible tendency to assume everyone is the same as us,
> hence everyone assumes that they way they learned how to use computers
> is what everyone else ought to do. And classes are good for real
> beginners, but there are also problems with timing and relevancy.
> Nevertheless, those books you mentioned do sound good. A command line
> reference would be especially useful. The only problem is that every
> one I have seen (including websites) is arranged alphabetically by
> command. That isn't very helpful if you need to know how to fix
> ia32-libs. Does Sobel's book have at least a good index?
>
>   

It's probably an age thing, but I have more of a problem learning from 
documentation on-line or included with the operating system than 
learning from a book.  Not that man pages and explanatory websites 
aren't invaluable and indispensable, but more as references than as a 
learning tool.  How-to's, tutorials, man pages, and the like are great 
for problem solving and even for learning discrete chunks of how 
something works.  I can't put it all together from those, though, and 
that's where I find books to be invaluable.  Plus, there's just 
something about the "solidity" of a printed book that I find more 
comforting than even an equivalent document on-line.  For example, I 
tried going through the Rute User's Tutorial on-line (and locally -- it 
can be installed with aptitude), and I had a much harder time than I 
would've if I had the same information in a book sitting open in front 
of the machine.  (It's an excellent document, nonetheless.)   I'm just 
not as attuned to learning from a screen -- gleaning information, sure, 
but not really *learning.*  Maybe all those hours in my formative years 
spent watching "Gilligan's Island" on a screen have permanently colored 
what I think screens really are for.

I haven't spent enough time with the books yet really to judge them, but 
I'm finding "The Debian System" to be more valuable than "The Debian 
GNU/Linux Bible."  I think anyone at any level could benefit from it 
(obviously, only if you're interested in Debian or one of its 
derivatives) because it delves into the concepts behind the structure.  
It's an attempt to explain why Debian is organized the way it is and the 
implications of that organization on techniques for managing the 
system.  Along the way, of course, there's a lot of how-to type 
information, but that isn't the thrust of the book.  The "Bible" is more 
task-oriented (chapters on graphics and sound, on Gnome and KDE, on web 
servers, intranet mail servers, databases, etc.), but as such has 
already dated some and doesn't really delve deeply enough into a lot of 
its subjects.  I mean, if you want to learn MySQL or PostGreSQL, you're 
not going to get very far with a few pages each in a book ostensibly 
about Debian; and if you don't care about them (or OpenLDAP or numerous 
other topics), then they take up space that could be given over to a 
more discursive examination of what makes Debian tick.  I'm finding it 
less helpful than "The Linux Cookbook" as a more task-oriented reference 
or as an "idea" book.  There is plenty of information, and it 
complements "The Debian System," but almost any given person is going to 
find substantial portions of it either irrelevant or incomplete.

Sobel's book looks pretty great, and yes, it does have a solid index.  
It also has an extensive (over 200 pages) command reference that's 
cross-referenced by type ("network utilities," "utilities that display 
and alter status," "utilities that display and manipulate files," etc.), 
a few useful appendices (one section even covers Bittorrent), and a good 
glossary.  It actually starts off with some really basic stuff, things 
even I have learned (not just "things I've used at one point or 
another," but things I already know).  But that's a good thing, I think 
-- it's useful to review, and to have it all in one place.  It goes into 
vim and emacs pretty extensively -- granted, you can buy entire books on 
either, but there seems to be enough here to get more than the 
fundamentals and probably as much as most people would need for general 
use.  The book goes places I probably won't in some later sections, 
dealing with programming in C and related topics.  But there are some 
things covered in the course of all that that I've either been curious 
about or would be useful to have a rudimentary knowledge of, like 
working with gawk and sed, or the differences between bash and tcsh.  
There are exercises throughout.  All in all, almost anyone who 
anticipates ever launching a terminal could get quite a bit from it.


-- 
Michael M. ++ Portland, OR ++ USA
"No live organism can continue for long to exist sanely under conditions of absolute reality; even larks and katydids are supposed, by some, to dream." --S. Jackson

firewall (iptables) on the box itself.  If so, then being up-to-date would
seem to be an irrelevant issue, as the other boxes (firewalls) are up to
date ;-)

I think one has to weigh stability (i.e. not patching to the bleeding edge)
with security, some times, and try to choose a level that makes sense.

So, as you stated, making sure it's safe works in this case, me thinks.

From GeorgeH at ci.hillsboro.or.us  Mon Jun 19 09:06:05 2006
From: GeorgeH at ci.hillsboro.or.us (George Heuston)
Date: Mon, 19 Jun 2006 09:06:05 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] CRIME Meeting 21 June -- Come on Out
Message-ID: <DE7AE42D6E2E474582AB5CB77802B4F610740D4E@lando.w2k.ci.hillsboro.or.us>

Computer Related Investigations, Management, and Education (CRME)

 

When: 21 June 2006, 10AM - Noon

 

Where: Hillsboro Civic Center Auditorium

 

Speaker/Topic:  David Aucsmith, Microsoft, will speak on the "Internet
Security Environment."

 

Abstract:  This talk will cover a broad perspective on Internet crime
and security.  It will address: (1) who the attackers are and what
motivates them, (2) what type of attacks are occurring and how they are
changing, and (3) the state of intelligence about the attackers and
attacks.  Though the talk will use Microsoft technology and products as
primary examples, the talk will cover the topics from a law enforcement
and national security perspective.

 

Who may attend?  Open to the public - no cost.

 

Bio:  David Aucsmith is the Senior Director of Microsoft's Institute for
Advanced Technology in Governments.  He is responsible for technical
relationships with United States Government agencies, as well as on
select special projects

Before joining Microsoft in August 2002, Aucsmith was the chief security
architect for Intel Corp. from 1994 to 2002.  He has worked in a variety
of security technology areas including secure computer systems, secure
communications systems, random number generation, cryptography,
steganography and network intrusion detection.  Aucsmith is a former
officer in the U.S. Navy and has been heavily involved in computer
security and cybercrime issues for more than 20 years.  He is an
industry representative to numerous international, government and
academic organizations.  Currently he is a member of the advisory board
of the National Security Agency, co-chairman of the FBI's Information
Technology Study Group, a member of the Secret Service Task Force on
Computer Aided Counterfeiting, member of the Computer Science and
Telecommunications Board of the National Academes of Science, a member
of the President's Task Force on National Defense and Computer
Technology and a member of the Department of Defense's Global
Information Grid Senior Industry Review Group.  Aucsmith was also U.S.
industry representative to the G8 Committee on Organized, Transnational,
and Technological Crime where he participated directly in the G8 summits
in Paris, Berlin and Tokyo.  Previously he has worked with the European
Commission DG XIII to craft digital signature regulations, representing
the U.S. industry at the European Commission hearings on digital
signatures.

Aucsmith holds 29 patents for digital security technology and is an
editor for the IEE Journal of Information Security, a member of the
advisory board for the College of Computing at the Georgia Institute of
Technology, and was featured in Time Magazine as a member of the
magazine's technology board.  Aucsmith holds a Bachelor of Science
degree in biochemistry from the University of Georgia and Master of
Science degrees in physics from the Naval Postgraduate School and
information and computer sciences from the Georgia Institute of
Technology respectively.

From fifer at 7technw.com  Mon Jun 19 13:03:41 2006
From: fifer at 7technw.com (Richard Amerman)
Date: Mon, 19 Jun 2006 13:03:41 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Plone Training: Build by Design: Rapid Product Dev for Plone
 using ArchGenXML
Message-ID: <4497031D.3060104@7technw.com>

7 Tech Northwest is proud to announce our first ArchGenXML training 
scheduled for 25-27 July in Vancouver, WA.

http://www.7technw.com/training/t-agx01-f

Many of you have been interested in ArchGenXML for some time, some may 
already have been experimenting with it, others may have not even heard 
of this great RAD tool for Plone. Some of you may have seen a demo of it 
first hand at some event, read something about it online, or seen one of 
a few pod-casts that show off this amazing technology as the 
demonstrator cranks out a new Plone product almost faster than you can 
follow.

To put it simply, ArchGenXML allows you to create fully functional, 
ready to install, Plone products from a drawing. In this apparent magic 
act, the drawing is a UML diagram and the resulting product is based on 
Archetypes.

This technology is not actually magical, does allow a developer to 
quickly visualize an idea and move it into a working product very 
quickly. This tool is the product of the hard work and dedication of 
many key developers in the Plone community. Every user has a different 
perspective on how it fits into their tool-set, and how deep down the 
rabbit hole they tend to plunge, but all will agree that it is a key 
feather in the Plone development communities hat.

We will be spending most of three days delving into all aspects of this 
tool. Every student will leave with both first hand knowledge of the 
capabilities of this tool, and personal experience in it's use. We will 
also explore other related tools including the future replacement of 
ArchGenXML, Genesis.

We will start with a foundation that will allow you to best capitalize 
on the benefits ArchGenXML has to offer, starting with a quick reminder 
of what it means to be a product in Plone, then an overview of 
Archetypes, and then into an introduction to UML. This foundation will 
give us a solid base from which to build our understanding of ArchGenXML.

We will be offering this training again in the future as demand dictates 
as well as other Plone trainings. See our website for details.
http://www.7technw.com/training

If you want to know more about this opportunity just let us know!

Jon Scully wrote:
> First, an intruder would have to get through two firewalls, plus the
> firewall (iptables) on the box itself.  If so, then being up-to-date would
> seem to be an irrelevant issue, as the other boxes (firewalls) are up to
> date ;-)
> 
> I think one has to weigh stability (i.e. not patching to the bleeding edge)
> with security, some times, and try to choose a level that makes sense.

You also realize that 70% to 90% of all security breaches are "inside 
jobs"... don't you?

Here's one story from last year: 
http://www.itweek.co.uk/vnunet/news/2127220/computer-hacking-inside-job

You are absolutely correct that one has to weigh the cost of whatever 
security plan is in place. Just don't expect that a firewall is the end 
all, be all of security.

Some questions to ponder... How would you know if the system were 
compromised? If it were, how would you know what "they" changed? How 
could you validate that they didn't change anything?

From josh at emediatedesigns.com  Thu Jun 22 03:03:55 2006

Subject: [PLUG] small Linux boxes
