Hello all,

I'm looking to build a linux box that will server one purpose.  It will 
just encode audio files.  I may encode video too but not right away.  I 
want this machine to be very small.  Thus a small case.  I'm looking for 
any pre-built or easy to build small case machines and hopefully local 
supplier that would be compatible with linux.  If all the features minus 
the sound and potentially video was built on the mother board that would 
be fine.  I think I would need just 2 expansion slots to deal with the 
possible additional cards. 

I have seen cases with pre-built system before about but not in a 
while.  really want a small box and was hoping to spend about $300.  I 
don't need a killer CPU for this or more then 1GB Ram (possible only 
512MB) and the HD can be as small as 40GB.  I can buy a full on 
mid-tower case for this price but want the machine to be small. 

suggestions?  Anyone buy a pre-built small case system that has worked 
with Linux - sound/video supported? 

I prefer to work with a local dealer but if that fails I would go 
elsewhere. 

Thanks and Happy Solstice to all.  I hope you enjoy the longest day as 
they are now only getting shorter. :-( 

Josh

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Thu Jun 22 13:37:30 2006
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Thu, 22 Jun 2006 13:37:30 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] small Linux boxes
In-Reply-To: <449A6B0B.7070708@emediatedesigns.com>

On Thu, Jun 22, 2006 at 03:03:55AM -0700, Josh Orchard wrote:
> Hello all,
> 
> I'm looking to build a linux box that will server one purpose.  It will 
> just encode audio files.  I may encode video too but not right away.  I 
> want this machine to be very small.  Thus a small case.  I'm looking for 
> any pre-built or easy to build small case machines and hopefully local 
> supplier that would be compatible with linux.  If all the features minus 
> the sound and potentially video was built on the mother board that would 
> be fine.  I think I would need just 2 expansion slots to deal with the 
> possible additional cards. 
> 
> I have seen cases with pre-built system before about but not in a 
> while.  really want a small box and was hoping to spend about $300.  I 
> don't need a killer CPU for this or more then 1GB Ram (possible only 
> 512MB) and the HD can be as small as 40GB.  I can buy a full on 
> mid-tower case for this price but want the machine to be small. 
> 
> suggestions?  Anyone buy a pre-built small case system that has worked 
> with Linux - sound/video supported? 

An older used laptop would do a fine job - audio encoding can be done
with quite a modest machine.  Check http://www.linux-laptop.net/ for
info on specific models.

If you must have new, and a desktop-like machine, then there are a
few mini-ITX machines around.  You will end up spending more like
$500, though, when you get done buying all the pieces.  I have one
Shuttle ST62K mini-ITX running Linux, and compared to the average
desktop install, it was a pain in the rear.  A lot of odd built-in
hardware with weird drivers, not the same as a full-sized motherboard. 
There are relatively few people running Linux on mini-ITX, so the
ST62K built-in chipsets doesn't get much attention. 

I chose the ST62K because it has a very quiet cooling system.  That
might be important for a sound recording system.  That said, I don't
even know if the sound input works on it.  Probably.

I put a different video card in it, using up the one and only PCI slot.

Keith

While at Pacific Solutions today I saw a couple of In-Win cases on the shelf.
Both were much smaller than a mini-tower. One was appx 2/3 size of a mini
tower and seemed to be designed to stand up or lay down.  The other was
flatter - more of a pizza box form factor but rectangular.  Linda said they
both support standard PC components and have 240W power supplies.  The
pizza-box like one only accept half height cards though.  

You can see an example of this case at 
http://www.in-win.us/products_pccase_series.php?cat_id=1&series_id=4

With standard PC components and a motherboard with built in peripherals you
should be able to keep the cost down.

Shuttle, AOpen and others make inexpensive "Mini" or "Small Form Factor"
barebones systems.  It's a case and motherboard, just add CPU, RAM and
HDD.  They're a bit bigger than a shoebox or loaf of bread.

If you want cheap, check out what's at Free Geek.  They sometimes have
laptops, mini systems and such.  Bring cash or a checkbook, they don't
take plastic yet.



From keithl at kl-ic.com  Fri Jun 23 09:36:13 2006
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Fri, 23 Jun 2006 09:36:13 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] huh??  commercialized or irrelevant?
In-Reply-To: <86ejxiqmb4.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <86ejxiqmb4.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <20060623163613.GA6919@gate.kl-ic.com>

On Wed, Jun 21, 2006 at 01:35:27PM -0700, Russell Senior wrote:
> 
> Rogoway had an short article in a recent Oregonian about Compiere
> moving to California, and it made Compiere sound like a well-known
> local open source company.  This surprised me a bit because, well, I'd
> never even heard of it before.
> 
> Later on in the article, he quotes Scott Kveton (recently leaving
> OSUOSL for a startup) as saying: "For this thing to be relevant, we
> have to commercialize it.  Otherwise it's just a novelty."  WTF??

Scott probably said a lot more than that, and the Oregonian reporter
chose the words that fit what he wanted to write.  I've talked with 
Scott a little about this, and my no-doubt-faulty impression is that
he wants to see a lot more commercial activity.  For example, an
individual or small business should be able to use open source and be
supported by a well-organized and efficient support services company.

To date there are a lot of inefficient small supoprt providers,
and large corp-to-corp providers like IBM, but little in between. 
No "H&R Block" or "Jiffy-Lube" or "Geek Squad" for open source. 
Scott's work on OpenID and reliable authentication may contribute
to the infrastructure such businesses will need.

Compiere is working on small business Enterprise Resource Planning
and Customer Relationship Management software (ERP and CRM), which
are also pieces of the puzzle.  The fact that such business needs
are invisible to most of us demonstrates how non-commercial most
of us are.  Most of our neighbors are out there buying and selling
stuff, though, and if we want them to use open source, we have to 
do things that are relevant to them.  Video player and blogging and
browser plugins are indeed just novelties to these business people,
compared to making and distributing the stuff of everyday existence.

Relevance is in the eye of the beholder.  To the vast majority of
eyes, computers in general and open source in particular are just
not that relevant.  We don't get to define relevance for these 
people, but we can identify it and move towards it if we choose.

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom          keithl at keithl.com         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs


From computers at chrisking.com  Thu Jun 22 11:32:01 2006

Subject: [PLUG] ANNOUCEMENT: Portland PostgreSQL Users Group starting
Message-ID: <9eb0fac583500ed27b0991003951bf83@chrisking.com>


The Portland PostgreSQL Users Group is recruiting!

Don't know what PostgreSQL is?  Go to http://www.postgresql.org/

We have a mailing list (send email to majordomo at postgresql.org, with 
"subscribe pdxpug" in the BODY of the message), and a website - 
http://pugs.postgresql.org/pdx/ - and we need a few more people.

Go ahead and subscribe to the mailing list to find out what we're up 
to!  We have a couple local experts lined up for talks, and are gearing 
up for a meeting in July. Subjects for talks might include DOMAINS, 
PL/pgSQL, DBD::Pg (my Perl bias is starting to show..).

A little bit about me --

I am a UNIX systems administrator with about 7 years of experience and 
I started working with PostgreSQL last year.  I'm in the middle of 
implementing an ERP package that uses pgSQL as its backend. If you're 
going to OSCON, I'll be helping staff the pgSQL booth, so you can stop 
by and say hello!

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Jun 23 10:04:32 2006
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri, 23 Jun 2006 10:04:32 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] huh??  commercialized or irrelevant?
In-Reply-To: <20060623163613.GA6919@gate.kl-ic.com>
References: <86ejxiqmb4.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	<20060623163613.GA6919@gate.kl-ic.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.63.0606230955180.20787@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Fri, 23 Jun 2006, Keith Lofstrom wrote:

> Compiere is working on small business Enterprise Resource Planning and
> Customer Relationship Management software (ERP and CRM), which are also
> pieces of the puzzle. The fact that such business needs are invisible to
> most of us demonstrates how non-commercial most of us are. Most of our
> neighbors are out there buying and selling stuff, though, and if we want
> them to use open source, we have to do things that are relevant to them.
> Video player and blogging and browser plugins are indeed just novelties to
> these business people, compared to making and distributing the stuff of
> everyday existence.

   I looked at compiere's web site not long ago as I tried to find a CRM/sales
administration tool that would work with postgres Right Now. I did not look
too long at it. As a small business operation, I find "ERP for small
business" to be an oxymoron. We're not what one thinks of when the word
'enterprise' is mumbled.

   There's absolutely nothing wrong with commercialization of open source
applications. However, from what I've seen there's a bimodal distribution
that's developed. At the large business size end of the scale are
applications like SugarCRM which are designed for large businesses with a
professional sales team. (I have issues with their emphasis on eye candy and
hardwired requirement for mysql, but that's me.) At the small end there're a
few nascent projects done by one or a few folks in their spare time. The high
end is commercialized and the low end comes along gradually as time permits.

   FWIW, the XRMS team is getting closer to having their CRM working with
postgres. I did some work for them on translating the SQL for the access
control tables, so I hope to see a fully functional postgres port Real Soon
Now.

Rich

On Fri, 23 Jun 2006, Randy Stapilus wrote:

> So, a question: Bearing in mind the overall size and scope and type of
> people who use Linux and open source, notably in the Portland area, *is*
> there a realistic market for an "H&R Block" or "Jiffy-Lube" or "Geek Squad"
> for open source? Or is the community just not substantial enough (yet at
> least) to support it?

Randy,

   I believe there is a substantial number of small businesses of all types
that are running partially or completely on linux. However, they have already
established relationships with individual consultants (or consulting
companies), and I suspect that's the support model for the future, too.

   Those who are already using linux won't go to a storefront support
business, and neither will those who know nothing about linux or FOSS in
general. I suspect that defenestration decisions are based on trusting
relationships with individuals, and that such decisions will never be
commoditized.

Rich

On Fri, 23 Jun 2006, Randy Stapilus wrote:

> So, a question: Bearing in mind the overall size and scope and type 
> of people who use Linux and open source, notably in the Portland 
> area, *is* there a realistic market for an "H&R Block" or 
> "Jiffy-Lube" or "Geek Squad" for open source? Or is the community 
> just not substantial enough (yet at least) to support it?

This is a bit afield of the question of commericializing open source 
applications, but...

I'm the sole admin in a 30-person company. Workstations run (in order 
of preponderance) Mac OS X, Windows, and Linux.

Most of our servers run Linux (mostly CentOS, with some Debian mixed 
in), though a couple critical servers run OS X. We've got one Windows 
server.

What I could use is a company that could provide adequate backup to 
cover during my absence. I've talked about this with our exec staff -- 
and they've agreed that we could pay something akin to a retainer to 
an IT support firm that could cover emergencies or even step in during 
periods when things get crazy around here.

The firm's admins would need basic Unix and Windows troubleshooting 
skills, and I could provide documentation for the non-standard 
applications we use.

Such a firm would, of course, need a semi-broad customer base to be 
able to bill enough hours -- but I can say without a doubt there's at 
least a partial market here in Portland.

-- 
Paul Heinlein <> heinlein at madboa.com <> www.madboa.com


From keithl at kl-ic.com  Fri Jun 23 10:49:06 2006
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Fri, 23 Jun 2006 10:49:06 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] huh??  commercialized or irrelevant?
In-Reply-To: <op.tblxzab6v05gle@randy>
References: <86ejxiqmb4.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	<20060623163613.GA6919@gate.kl-ic.com> <op.tblxzab6v05gle@randy>
Message-ID: <20060623174906.GA23627@gate.kl-ic.com>

On Fri, Jun 23, 2006 at 09:41:24AM -0700, Randy Stapilus wrote:
> So, a question: Bearing in mind the overall size and scope and type of  
> people who use Linux and open source, notably in the Portland area, *is*  
> there a realistic market for an "H&R Block" or "Jiffy-Lube" or "Geek  
> Squad" for open source? Or is the community just not substantial enough  
> (yet at least) to support it?

Jane Smallbusinesswoman will not use Linux until she can get this
support.  The market become substantial like most markets; you
build it, starting with zero customers.  Fortunately, 90% of the
work can be done remotely, so you can have customers anywhere you
can find local contractor semi-geeks who can follow instructions
for installs and initial configuration and so forth.  With a full
distributed second-level support team ( somebody who knows Linux
networking, somebody who knows business apps, etc. ), a support
company could provide deep knowledge without a lot of learning-
while-doing, a problem with the current support model.  You need
support staff that is patient and likes helping people with 
inadequate computer skills - nobody like that here. :-(

Such an effort might grow out of the distro companies.  It could
grow out of the right people at PLUG or POSSE.  The key for 
a successful businesses is the "learning curve", an empirical
rule of thumb that says that markets tend to grow by 10x when
price drops by half.  So if there are a dozen or so consultants
in the Portland area tweaking Linux for the occasional business,
then a system that permits the same work to be done twice as
efficiently would soon grow into sixty staff serving 10x the
customers, in Portland alone.  As the support process is
highly amenable to automation, lessons learned, etc., quite a
few efficiency doublings are possible.   Most of the automation
effort can be shared at a national level (helping muffler shops
in Idaho is very much like helping muffler shops in Vermont),
so a large effort can be much more efficient than a small one.

But all this has very little to do with most of the stuff we
spend our time doing.  It involves helping computer-ignorant
users, and many of us are too elitist for that.    The cool
thing is that it doesn't take a large percentage of Linux geeks
to develop a proper customer-service attitude, and succeed
brilliantly, while the rest of us stand around scratching our
heads and accusing them of selling out or something.

I think Scott Kveton is one of the folks that is figuring things
out, and I will enjoy watching him blow our doors off on his way
to success.

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom          keithl at keithl.com         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Fri Jun 23 12:47:00 2006
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 23 Jun 2006 12:47:00 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] huh??  commercialized or irrelevant?
In-Reply-To: <20060623174906.GA23627@gate.kl-ic.com>
References: <86ejxiqmb4.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
	<20060623163613.GA6919@gate.kl-ic.com> <op.tblxzab6v05gle@randy>
	<20060623174906.GA23627@gate.kl-ic.com>
Message-ID: <86y7vnd58r.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Keith" == Keith Lofstrom <keithl at kl-ic.com> writes:

Keith> Jane Smallbusinesswoman will not use Linux until she can get
Keith> this support.  

Where does she get it today with MS stuff?  Likely, the same class of
consultants that are already also available for FOSS.

Keith> [...] But all this has very little to do with most of the stuff
Keith> we spend our time doing.  It involves helping computer-ignorant
Keith> users, and many of us are too elitist for that. [...]

For me, it isn't about elitism, it's that i am not terribly interested
in computer support (outside the clinics, and those aren't support so
much as they are sharing my problem-solving skills/experience).
Elitism implies I think I am better than they are.  I don't.  I do
what works for me and I assume that other people to do what works for
them.  I'm happy to help where I can, because I am just a sharer by
nature.

I use Linux as a platform for solving problems.  I use it because it
lets me focus on my problems, not on Bill Gates' problems.  For me,
Microsoft basically doesn't even exist and hasn't existed since the
early 1990s.  I don't want to think about it and I usually don't have
to.

Recently, I was able to build a data collection platform on top of a
Knoppix CD so that I could continue developing on a sane platform and
the end-user could use whatever random hardware they had and I didn't
have to worry about their existing software environment.

To say that linux needs to succeed commercially to be relevant is
bogus.  It succeeded for me a long time ago and there isn't very much
that could happen that would reverse that success.  It might need to
"succeed commercially" (whatever that means) in order to generate
direct jobs for people.  So, that might seem relevant for economic
development wonks (who tradeoff public investment/incentives against
future tax revenues).  But FOSS succeeds and draws investment because
of the money it saves (and the control/flexibility it provides), not
so much because of the money it has the potential to extract from
others.

I wish Scott Kveton good luck, etc, but his success is not
particularly relevant to me.


-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com


From scratchcomputing at gmail.com  Fri Jun 23 12:59:23 2006
From: scratchcomputing at gmail.com (Eric Wilhelm)
Date: Fri, 23 Jun 2006 12:59:23 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] OSCamp call for Speakers
In-Reply-To: <NJBBILMKELIKKAPBPBEMKEFGDHAA.jon@perrspectives.com>
References: <NJBBILMKELIKKAPBPBEMKEFGDHAA.jon@perrspectives.com>
Message-ID: <200606231259.23436.ewilhelm@cpan.org>

Hi all,

If you've been to a meeting in the last few months, you may have heard 
me mention OSCamp.  If you didn't go to Recent Changes Camp, you're 
probably wondering what OSCamp is "about."  The answer is that it's 
about whatever you make it about, but I'm trying to make that more 
tangible for those with less imagination.

  http://oscamp.org/Call_for_Speakers

We're looking for presentations like:

  "Have you thought of using this open-source technology in your 
$underfunded_cause organization?"

  "This small business would have had to close the doors without 
$open_source_technology_x."

And other sorts of talks with these qualities:

  * light on tech
  * neat / warm-fuzzy
  * community / small biz / government / education
  * mildly commercial / infommercial testimonials

These parameters are flexible.  My main goal is to get OSCamp to be a 
gateway drug to oscon and/or OSS and/or Portland.

As I see it, the OSCamp crowd will consist of (hopefully)

  A.  oscon attendees who wandered in
  B.  community folk who couldn't afford/justify the cost of oscon
  C.  curious onlookers who might not otherwise be thinking about OSS

I'm shooting for a healthy C crowd, but I think getting some tangible 
speakers/topics on the schedule is critical to making that happen.

If you're interested in speaking, please contact me and/or any other 
OSCamp representative.

Of course, if you're not interested in speaking, still do come down and 
see what it's all about.  If you're having trouble getting off work, 
put a page that says there will be a session on "$topic related to 
$job" on the wiki and show your boss :-)

Thanks,
Eric

From nsxfreddy at gmail.com  Sat Jun 24 13:47:17 2006
From: nsxfreddy at gmail.com (Jason R. Martin)
Date: Sat, 24 Jun 2006 13:47:17 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Unzipping self-extracting .exe archives
In-Reply-To: <20060624125055.8eb20bbb.johnxj@comcast.net>
References: <20060624125055.8eb20bbb.johnxj@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <c29537840606241347i1bdff092pf3a6d36de92d80d6@mail.gmail.com>

On 6/24/06, John Jason Jordan <johnxj at comcast.net> wrote:
> I keep having to do this. The files are zip archives that a Windows user just has to double-click on to uncompress. It's a pain to have to go to my Windows desktop to do this. File Roller won't do it. I don't need to be able to double-click on the archive to extract it; a command line utility would be fine. Is there a Linux utility that can unzip these things and preserve the internal directory structure in the process?

Self-extracting zips are just normal zip files with the SFX prefix
concatenated with the zip file and a .exe extension.  The command-line
"unzip" is smart enough to handle it (at least on my FC5 box).  You
can even create them, but you need to find the prefix first online
somewhere.

Jason

>From: "Rogan Creswick" <creswick at gmail.com>
> Finally, you can program in any paradigm in pretty much any language.
> It's possible to write functional C, and you can write procedural
> lisp.  Many paradigms aren't mutually exclusive either --
> Object-Oriented languages involve lots of procedural elements, and as
> I eluded to above, they have some functional aspects as well.
> Regardless of the language, if you do any work with interfaces you
> will need to use some sort of event-based paradigm.

My tendancy is not place OO in the same level as the procedural and
functional languages. Pretty well all the OO languages are procedural,
and OO is more a way of organizing the program, not of writing the
program.

Anyone who is decent with C writes OO programs. Just now there is a
formal term for type of organization used. The distinguishing
characteristic is simply that with an OO language, the compiler takes
care of creating the jump tables for you.

There is also the temptation to refer to the one group as dys-functional
languages.

> ignore it and boot anyway. It was AFTER I finally let it fix the

> one of the Breezy options worked properly. I haven't tried anything since.

I'm sorry, but it very definitely sounds like #1. Time to queue the
jokes. As I think you've figured out, the Dapper Drake install noticed
the existing filesystem and mounted it. In general a reasonable and
pretty harmless thing to do, though it sounds like it confused you.

> Besides getting messed up, what do inodes do?

They're a specific piece of on-disk structure. In traditional filesystems
you get two types of blocks; data blocks and blocks of inodes. Data
blocks simply hold actual file data, simple and boring. inodes are the
"heads" of files, they contain permissions information and point to
blocks of data, they also hold a reference counter. A directory is an
inode where the data blocks contain filenames and pointers to inodes. Due
to the reference counter, multiple directories can contain links to the
same inode and the reference counter tracks the number of links (this is
what `ln` without -s does). For really large files the inode has an
indirection pointer, which is simply a data block with pointers to other
data blocks (with the largest files on a traditional UFS filesystem,
there could be 3 levels of indirection).

So literally an inode is pretty well a single file.

A wrong reference count means the reference counter on the inode had a
number that was different from the number of links that `fsck` found. If
the reference counter was too low, if one link was removed the system
might try deleting the data blocks while there was still a legitimate
pointer to the file. If the reference counter was too high, the system
might of removed the last link, but never marked the data blocks as
unused. On ext2 inodes also have a marker indicating whether they're a
file, or have been deleted; so if fsck finds an inode that is marked as
a file, but no links that is an unreferenced inode.

In traditional filesystems, inodes are allocated in distinct areas of the
disk, separate from where data blocks are located. This makes allocation
simpler, disk checks simpler and works pretty well. Some filesystems,
such as ReiserFS simply allocate inodes out of the pool of data blocks.

One interesting bug report was a case of a disk recovery firm storing an
image of a ReiserFS on top of a ReiserFS filesystem. They had a crash and
had to run a full check with fsck. fsck found the contents of the
filesystem, but it also found something that looked like part of a valid
ReiserFS filesystem inside the data blocks of what was a file. The
result was it merge the FS-image with the parent filesystem. Afterwords
they added per-FS magic numbers to the inode blocks. An interesting case
of the unexpected happening.


>From: John Jason Jordan <johnxj at comcast.net>
> 1) I googled and man-paged on fsck and can't find a way to give a
> command that it should be run on the next boot before the filesystem is
> mounted. I did try to run it while the system was mounted, but it gave
> me dire warnings, so I canceled. Maybe I missed the option that I need.
> I can't give the command during boot because there is no command line
> then. In Windows the GUI has an option to clean up the disk or
> something (never needed it), and if you click on Yes it announces it
> will be run on the next boot. What is the Linux way to do this? Or is
> there a better way?

The simplest is to do `touch /forcefsck`. Nearly all distributions this
will pass "-f" to fsck on the next boot, forcing fsck to look at the
filesystems even though they appear to be clean (unmounted properly).

The hard-core hacker way is to pass "init=/bin/bash" to the kernel. This
causes the kernel to run the shell instead of init, and you get a true
single-process system. From here you run `fsck` and clear out any damage
that has been done. If you need to remove or change anything on the
root filesystem you do `mount -n / -o rw,remount` (and a
`mount -n / -o ro,remount` when done!).

Elliott,

   While I was being flippant, I recently read that there are about 200 linux
distributions! That boggles my tiny mind, and I'm sure the number has
increased since then.

> If you show up at an advanced topics meeting and say that you might get

   HTML is a subset of SGML, the family of text markup languages that describe
how text is to be formatted for presentation on a computer screen, printed
page, or spoken report. Page layout via text markup is _not_ programming
under any definition of the term.

   Germane to the original question, there is no "best" programming language
(in the opinion of this non-professional). It all depends on what you want to
have the computer do.

Rich Shepard wrote:

>>>   Given the interest in this thread, I wonder if those of us with large
>>> collections of records could work as a group to digitize them.
>>
>> What did you have in mind?
> 
>   Share the costs and efforts of digitizing our collections. I suspect that
> for most of us it will be a one-time process, so it makes sense to 
> cooperate
> on the effort. Besides, we could get to listen to what others enjoy(ed) in
> the way of music while we're at it.

I've had a little time to try out the USB turntable using Audacity on my 
XP laptop. I haven't had time to clear all the dependencies and get 
Audacity 1.2.3 or higher installed on my Linux machine (SuSE 9.1). The 
earlier version of Audacity doesn't look like it supports the USB 
interface, but it may be my ignorance of how to "wire" the connection in 
the OS.

The recording process is simple enough, and I'm satisfied with the 
quality, as far as that step goes. What I haven't done successfully is 
to remove scratches from music with a wide dynamic range. The 
recommendations on the Audacity forum say that one should sample the 
noise at the beginning of the LP and then remove that from the rest of 
the recording. When I do that for a recording of Chuck Mangione's 
Bellavia, it works well. But when I do it from a The Moody Blues Days of 
Future Passed, it takes out some of the music.

When I recorded music with Gramofile I could use the included filter set 
to remove scratch and pop noise successfully from classical recordings 
without losing quiet music in the process. I'll have to try hooking up 
the turntable to the line in port of the sound card on my Linux machine 
and see what Gramofile does with Days of Future Passed.

BTW, it doesn't work to record with Audacity, export to wav, and then 
try to remove the noise with Gramofile. Each has its own native format, 
and does the noise removal based on those files, not a wav file.

Does anyone know of a noise filtering program that will work on a wav file?

Audacity has a useful feature if you want to have a single music file 
instead of separate files for each track. You can record the two sides 
of an LP or tape separately and then copy and paste side two into side 
one. You could also pause the recording while flipping the LP over. 
Also, if you have separate tracks in mp3, wav, or ogg format and want to 
combine them, Audacity can import each of those.

If you want to go the other way and separate out tracks, Gramofile has 
an automated feature for this that works most of the time. I think 
Audacity can do it too, but the advantage with Audacity is the graph it 
displays of the sound which makes it easier to see the quiet bit between 
tracks.

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens


From heinlein at madboa.com  Mon Jun 26 08:16:49 2006

On Mon, 26 Jun 2006, Edward Terry wrote:

> > > HTML is another possibility, particularly if you're interested 
> > > in building your own website.  It's easy to learn, and it's 
> > > always useful to know.
> > 
> > 
> > If you show up at an advanced topics meeting and say that you 
> > might get punched, and you will deserve that and more. Programming 
> > languages such as Python or Ruby are at a completely different 
> > level than a text formatting language like HTML. HTML is at worst 
> > linear complexity to handle, Python and Ruby are vastly more 
> > complex.
> 
> I'm unlikely to show up at an advanced topics meeting, since I 
> assume those are for IT professionals and advanced Linux users, and 
> I'm neither.  I wasn't aware that some computer languages are not 
> programming languages.  At any rate, he said he planned to learn a 
> computer language, not a programming language, and he didn't mention 
> that he was looking for a complex one.  I would think anyone 
> interested in learning about computer languages should learn HTML; 
> even I know some.

HTML describes textual content and, to a lesser extent, its visual 
layout.

Programming languages, on the other hand, describe hardware behavior. 
Some programing languages put several layers of abstraction between 
you and the hardware; others allow you to manipulate it with little 
mediation.

While mastering HTML is a very useful skill for communicating with 
other people in the Web Age, it has little to do with telling your 
computer how to accomplish a task.

-- 
Paul Heinlein <> heinlein at madboa.com <> www.madboa.com

From dave at dhdo.org  Mon Jun 26 11:29:52 2006

Message-ID: <200606261129.52669.dave@dhdo.org>

On Monday 26 June 2006 10:54, m0gely wrote:
> Paul Heinlein wrote:
> > While mastering HTML is a very useful skill for communicating with
> > other people in the Web Age, it has little to do with telling your
> > computer how to accomplish a task.
>
> By that definition I would say HTML fits the bill.  It very much so
> tells, or instructs the browser what to display, and how.

HTML is a Markup Language (hence the ML).  It is no more different than 
pressing ctl-b to get bold text in a word processor, though, slightly more 
verbose.

While it is a Language, it is not a Programming Language.  A rule-of-thumb 
test to see if something is a programming language is to ask if there's a way 
to say 'if' in the language you're using. 

Of course, it's a rule of thumb, not a law carved in stone.

-- 
-Dave

BIG WARNING!! BIG WARNING!! BIG WARNING!! BIG WARNING!!

MS Windows DOESN'T sublicense nor can a license for MS Windows be 
transferred to a third party.  Ignore preinstalled MS Windows, 
it's best to uninstall that and throw the media out if you can't
purchase or don't possess a valid license from Microsoft.  You can 
go to jail for using MS Windows without the proper license.  
Considering Microsoft's attitude about piracy, the question really 
is, when will someone go to prison?  Buying used equipment or any 
equipment for that matter, your best bet is to make sure it's 
open source software compatible up front.  If you have to spend a 
little more, believe me that it's worthwhile to get equipment
that will serve you well.

BIG WARNING!! BIG WARNING!! BIG WARNING!! BIG WARNING!!

> Thanks all, I've been doing more and more research.  Getting closer.  
> Heck, I even thought to buy my own odd box and just build the computer 
> in there. 

That's a viable idea depending on what you are trying to accomplish.
You don't need a case per se to run a pc as long as it's grounded
properly, etc.  I've been thinking it would be nice to build a MythTV
system for example directly into the cabinet of a big screen television 
skipping the ATX case.

I hear that SUN systems are good for music and video work, might be 
something worth looking into depending on what you're after.

and the confidence of Sun worldwide support for their production
applications.  PostgreSQL users can take this as an opportunity to
re-evaluate the Solaris platform for their projects where reliability is a
central goal.

Berkus, will be working over the next few months to improve and expand the
PostgreSQL for Solaris distribution, enhance performance, and add new
features.  100% of these enhancements will be open source and contributed to
the PostgreSQL project or appropriate associated projects.

From sofar at foo-projects.org  Mon Jun 26 13:55:23 2006
From: sofar at foo-projects.org (Auke Kok)
Date: Mon, 26 Jun 2006 13:55:23 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Why is java is evil ???? (was "new guy with questions")
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.64.0606261326100.2542@blackbox.fnordora.org>
References: <00d401c69959$2d632850$0501010a@billslaptop>
	<Pine.LNX.4.64.0606261326100.2542@blackbox.fnordora.org>
Message-ID: <44A049BB.7020003@foo-projects.org>

alan wrote:
> On Mon, 26 Jun 2006, Bill Ensley wrote:
> 
>> OK, So I was "born" into my programming career using Java, but I have
>> Taken the time to learn a bit of C, C++, ASP, Perl, and Visual Basic
>> (eeewww).
>>
>> I really enjoy programming in Java and it does all that I need,
>> That is to say that I can share code across my desktop apps,
>> My web apps, and my applets.  (Yes I need all three)
>>
>> Is there anyone on this list that can give me a truly unbiased :)
>> Reason why I shouldn't use Java for all of this?
> 
> Not really.
> 
> The main perception of Java as "evil" has been from the non-free license 
> agreement the Sun tools have had.  Other than that, it it works then use 
> it.

this is a bit unfair, and IMHO wrong perception. The biggest disadvantage of 
Java applications is that somehow you always end up with a klunky JRE on your 
system, and that java itself is a byte-compiled system (the language isn't, 
but the implementation is).

This may seem very efficient for modern (fast, large memory) systems but every 
time I see a phone load a java game (for 30 seconds...), I cannot think 
otherwise than that java is not well suited for any embedded application, even 
though the mobile phone industry thinks I prefer to swallow it :)

Most older programmers don't want to see the large layer of obscurity that the 
VM adds in between - and certainly it's going to be tough doing kernel 
programming in Java.

That makes Java the ultimate application programming language: it will never 
be (POV) suitable for anything lowlevel as kernel code. You won't see much 
Java books on a linux kernel hackers' bookshelf :)


Cheers,

Auke

From m0gely at telestream.com  Mon Jun 26 14:56:27 2006
From: m0gely at telestream.com (m0gely)
Date: Mon, 26 Jun 2006 14:56:27 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] MS license, was small Linux boxes
In-Reply-To: <44A04FED.1070004@dslnorthwest.net>
References: <449A6B0B.7070708@emediatedesigns.com>	<20060623021810.GB6430@patch.com>	<449DAD43.9040001@emediatedesigns.com>	<1151279035.449f1fbb13569@xerxes.robinson-west.com>
	<44A04FED.1070004@dslnorthwest.net>
Message-ID: <44A0580B.2070507@telestream.com>

Denis Heidtmann wrote:

> Please elaborate. What does "transferred to a third party" mean?  If I 
> buy a
> used machine I cannot use the OS installed on it?

The way Windows OEM licensing works is that the version of Windows you 
get with a PC lives and dies with that PC.  Meaning that if you install 
Linux on the machine you can't offer the Windows license that came with 
the PC to anyone else.  If you eventually throw the PC in the trash, you 
cannot keep the Windows license and use it on another machine either.

But you can certainly give or sell the machine to someone and the 
license goes with it.

The retail version of Windows does not have these restrictions.  It's 
very simple.  Don't register software, and they will never know.  This 
is such a gray area that it's not enforceable.  What constitutes a new 
computer?  If your new eMachine blows it's all-in-one motherboard 2 
months out of warranty and you throw an Asus in there to replace it, 
it's basically a new machine.

-- 
- m0gely

On 6/26/06, Robert Citek <rwcitek at alum.calberkeley.org> wrote:
>
> On Jun 26, 2006, at 5:21 PM, m0gely wrote:
>
> > Dave wrote:
> >
> >> A rule-of-thumb test to see if something is a programming language
> >> is to ask if there's a way to say 'if' in the language you're using.
> >
> > <b>IF</b>
> >
> > =]  I don't consider it a programing language either. I was just
> > being difficult.
>
> Would XSLT be considered a programming language?  XSLT is written in
> XML, which is a mark-up language like HTML.
>

Yes.  It is declarative, functional language specialized to doing tree
transformations on XML. It is Turing complete.  You wouldn't want to
use it for general-purpose programming but it is a programming
language.

You could create a normal programming language in XML. XML is just a
syntax for markup languages.  The specific markup languages can be
interpreted as a programming language.  It is usually used for data
structures and is most suited for documents.

 - Ian

Right, the VM is what allows for cross-platform compatibility, which is an
advantage most Linux users can appreciate.  It's really not klunky, just
something you have to install once.  So how is bytecode worse than native
binaries, notwithstanding the very marginal performance hit?

> Most older programmers don't want to see the large layer of 
> obscurity that the 
> VM adds in between - and certainly it's going to be tough 
> doing kernel 
> programming in Java.

Kernel programming in Java?  Would you pick your teeth with a javelin?  How
about writing a word processor in assembler?  That "layer of obscurity" is
also a good thing.  It means that Java programmers don't have to worry about
how things are done at a lower lever, so it's much easier to code complex
operations while avoiding many of the memory leaks and security holes that C
and C++ tend to foster.

> That makes Java the ultimate application programming 
> language: it will never 
> be (POV) suitable for anything lowlevel as kernel code. You 
> won't see much 
> Java books on a linux kernel hackers' bookshelf :)

Indeed, most kernel hackers know one tool from another.  But Mr. Ensley was
asking about using Java for his Web app's and desktop app's, for which Java
is eminently suited.  The licensing issues surrounding it have been debated
for years, but I would say it's more just idealism than any practical
consideration.

--Jason V. C.

[KvetchMode:On]
Having spent the past hour trying to copy my /home/jjj folder from one
location to another, I guess I'm going to have to learn to do file
copying via the command line. I drag the folder to the new location and
it copies some files, but not others. It copies some folders, but not
others. And they all act this way -- XFE, Konqueror, Krusader,
Nautilus, and even when I run them from the terminal as root. You have
to go through painstakingly comparing the two folders to see what
didn't get copied, then copy just that one file. Over and over. During
the past year I've tried every GUI file manager there is, and not one
of them will copy all the subfolders and al the files in those
subfolders. No warnings, no explanations as to why. I've never figured
out what the secret is. It's not permissions or ownership because when
I go back and drag the files one at a time they copy just fine.

The task at hand arises because I have a perfectly good and usable
Ubuntu Dapper-64 installation that I created in an unused portion of my
hard disk. I have spent several days getting it all configured.
installing all my apps, getting wifi working, making sure everything
was cool. In the process I copied all the files in /home/jjj from my
borked Breezy installation. The new Dapper installation is ultimately
going to be my emergency rescue installation, since it is set to mount
the old Breezy partition. Having done that, today I reformatted the
borked 60 GB Breezy installation and installed a new, fresh Dapper-64
on it, which will ultimately be the main installation. Now I need to
copy all the configs one more time. It took me a couple hours the first
time, and I'm an hour into it the second time. 

I tried to learn how to use the cp command. Really, I did. I read the
man page, I googled, and I remain too scared to use it. Too many
options that I didn't understand. So here I sit, dragging files one at
a time. And it's too effin' hot, too. <sigh>
[KvetchMode:Off]

From danielmyoung at gmail.com  Mon Jun 26 20:42:03 2006

Message-ID: <2e42bd9b0606262042v3952a3b0x77a18b541907206f@mail.gmail.com>

On 6/26/06, Steven Susbauer <stupendoussteve at gmail.com> wrote:
> On Mon, 26 Jun 2006, John Jason Jordan wrote:
> > I tried to learn how to use the cp command. Really, I did. I read the
> > man page, I googled, and I remain too scared to use it. Too many
> > options that I didn't understand. So here I sit, dragging files one at
> > a time. And it's too effin' hot, too. <sigh>
>
> cp -R /home/jjj/* /home/blah
>
> Should do it.

The -a flag follows the principle of least surprise; it's recursive,
it preserves file permissions and timestamps, and links remain links.
It's the "do what I mean" option. The -v flag shows you what's
happening, which is nice for large copies.

As long as directory /home/blah is not present, just:
cp -av /home/jjj /home/blah

When you're scared, "cd /tmp" and try out stuff there.

-- 
Dan

From johnxj at comcast.net  Tue Jun 27 01:06:53 2006
From: johnxj at comcast.net (John Jason Jordan)
Date: Tue, 27 Jun 2006 01:06:53 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Dapper + Reiser
Message-ID: <20060627010653.8dc2a011.johnxj@comcast.net>

OK, I had to reformat that old Breezy partition because "sudo apt-get
dist update" got it so mucked up there was no hope. And I wanted to try
out Reiserfs, because everyone seems to think it's a lot faster than
ext3.

So I stuck the Dapper-64 DVD in the drive and restarted the computer.
When the live version came up it had an icon on the desktop labeled
INSTALL in very large letters. I proceeded to install. Except that the
only way you can install and reformat a partition at the same time is
to use ext3. Reiserfs is not an option. However, since I was actually
running Dapper-64 from the CD, I just exited from the Install utility
and used Disk Manager, which was happy to format the partition
Reiserfs. Then I went back and installed Dapper-64 on it. I had to undo
all the defaults to do so, because it still insisted on reformatting
it. But it did recognize the reiserfs filesystem, and after poking at
it a bit I figured out how to make it work.

Then I spent the next eight hours trying to get it all configured the
way I want it. That included two hours trying to figure out why the
Ubuntu wiki instructions to get wireless up and running worked fine on
the test setup, but wouldn't work this time. (Still not resolved.) And
I spent more hours reinstalling applications, trying to get my configs
transferred over, etc. Finally I got all that done, but I noticed that
nothing could see my fonts. They were in a Fonts folder in /home/jjj,
which worked fine in Breezy, but I guess not in Dapper. So I proceeded
to move them all to /usr/share/fonts. That part actually worked using
the GUI drag and drop. But I guess it's because they were not inside
folders. Anyway, I got all but the OpenType fonts in, and decided I
wanted to make a separate folder for them. And then I discovered that
it never occurred to any of the Nautilus developers that a user might
want to create a folder. No buttons for that. So I fired up Konqueror,
but it wouldn't come up, even though I had been using it earlier.
Neither would Krusader. Or XFE. This was too much. Something bad must
be going on. 

I decided to restart. But when I hit the Shutdown icon, it started to
shut down, then suddenly X came back, then it disappeared and it went
back to shutting down, then X reappeared, and back and forth for a
while. Then a window popped up with a wonderful error message that said
"the graphical subsystem has been shut down and restarted six times in
the last 90 seconds. This probably means something really bad is going
on." (I swear, that is what it said. Now where would you get something
as pungent as that in Windows?) So I decided to hit the power button
and restart.

It started back up, but X wouldn't start. It just kept trying and
failing and trying and failing. I didn't wait for the "six times" error
message. I just hit the power button. 

Then I tried the second choice for this installation -- the 15-23
kernel instead of the 15-25 that is the top choice. The 15-23 one never
even got to trying to start X. It hung on "loading hardware drivers."
That's probably because I had been using nothing but the 15-25, so that
is the kernel that the drivers were set up for. (Just a guess.)

At that point I decided to go back to this test/rescue installation. I
figured it was set to mount hda2 automatically during boot, so I could
use it to poke around and maybe figure out what is wrong. Well, what
was wrong was Reiserfs. In the middle of booting the test installation
announced that there was a bad superblock on hda2 and it could not
mount it. From reading the rest of the error message, it was clear that
Dapper-64 cannot mount a Reiserfs partition. It did not even recognize
it, hence the "bad superblock" message.

So my new installation is borked. Won't boot and I don't have an easy
way to get at the partition. Not that I have much likelihood of
figuring out what is wrong anyway. Tomorrow I'll have to start over.
Eight hours down the tube. But just think how much I have learned about
Linux! <sigh>

Oh, and Reiserfs is no faster than ext3. 

But while writing this chapter in the saga of How Not to Install Linux,
It occurrred to me that I should just use this test installation to
reformat the 60 GB hda2 partition (as ext3), then copy absolutely
everything from the test installation to hda2. I can use Aaron's rescue
CD that I copied at the last clinic, and I even wrote down the copy
syntax. Not sure how Grub will take that, though. But it's worth a
shot. And if it doesn't work, I'll learn even more about How Not to
Install Linux!

> [KvetchMode:Off]

In case you've never tried it, a nice middle-ground between sucky GUI 
file managers and scary command-line file operations is Midnight 
Commander (aka "mc").  It's a classic two-paned file manager with a 
curses interface that runs in a terminal.  Helpfully, it has the main 
file operations displayed in a neat little row across the bottom of the 
terminal, so you don't even have to remember what "F7" does vs. what 
"F8" does.

To copy files or directories, navigate to the file or directory you want 
to copy on one side of mc so that it is highlighted, navigate to the 
destination on the other side, and hit F5.  To move them, rather than 
copy them, hit F6.  If you're using mc in a terminal, you can even use 
the mouse.

I use it much more than I use either Nautilus or 'mv' or 'cp'.  But I 
guess I'm partial to two-paned file managers.  They always made sense to 
me, conceptually; I used one back in Windows days as well.  A good GUI 
two-paned manager for Linux is emelfm, but mc does everything I need and 
has the advantage of working on the console, so I stopped using emelfm.

One thing to keep in mind is that, as with the 'rm' command, deleting a 
file with mc is really deleting it.  It doesn't move it to the trash.  
But it does ask for a confirmation.

-- 
Michael M. ++ Portland, OR ++ USA

On Tue, 27 Jun 2006 02:52:25 -0700
"Michael M." <nixlists at writemoore.net> dijo:

> In case you've never tried it, a nice middle-ground between sucky GUI 
> file managers and scary command-line file operations is Midnight 
> Commander (aka "mc").  It's a classic two-paned file manager with a 
> curses interface that runs in a terminal.  Helpfully, it has the main 
> file operations displayed in a neat little row across the bottom of the 
> terminal, so you don't even have to remember what "F7" does vs. what 
> "F8" does.

I did try Midnight Commander, but I find it easier and more logical to
have a tree in the left pane and when you click on a folder in the tree
its contents are displayed in the right pane. But your comment points
out one important thing in all these discussions -- our minds all work
differently.

The very best file manager I ever used was Norton File Manager for NT
3.51. You had a choice of various "looks," but the default was similar
to the original file manager that Windows 3.1 came with. Except Norton
added all the stuff that Microsoft didn't think anyone would want -- an
FTP utility, built in zip compression or (optionally) compress with
NT's compression, a file viewer pane (like Konqueror, but it popped up
on the bottom instead of taking over the whole window), file
associations, network points, share creation, permissions, and just
about anything else one would want to do with a file manager. It was
compact, came up instantly, and everything you needed to do was in one
program window. 

I'm learning a new term here, I think -- "recursive." That's when it
moves not just the folder you're dragging, but all its contents,
subfolders, and their contents as well, right? 

OK, off to try to copy this installation to the 60 GB partition. But
this time I'm not going to cross my fingers. I think the computer saw
me do that last time. Realizing that I didn't know what I was doing it
deliberately screwed things up. Computers'll do that, ya know.

From plancashire at ci.portland.or.us  Tue Jun 27 10:14:54 2006
From: plancashire at ci.portland.or.us (Lancashire, Pete)
Date: Tue, 27 Jun 2006 10:14:54 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Why is java is evil ???? (was "new guy with questions" )
Message-ID: <9AFECDC22C4D6942BDFFCBDFCDB27A97074EDB36@cityemail.bit.city>

not evil but ..

i was doing a gig where a lot of data validation
and conversion scripts were needed. Many were less
then 50 (working code not comments docs) lines of
perl.

i handed about a dozen of them to someone else to
do. he did them in Java.

some where run every time a file would show up in
a particular upload directory, some via a signal
from another process. some of those files would
show up a few per minute.

with java, the server cpu load went from a daily
max of 60% avg of 30% to a max of 100% and avg of
75%. RAM went through the roof, many times the
java processes would crap out mot having enough
memory.

i had to recode them myself, he refused to use
anything other the Java, it was against his religion
or something.

just venting ..

-pete

From sofar at foo-projects.org  Tue Jun 27 10:34:54 2006
From: sofar at foo-projects.org (Auke Kok)
Date: Tue, 27 Jun 2006 10:34:54 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Why is java is evil ???? (was "new guy with questions"
 )
In-Reply-To: <00b201c69a0e$499ca4a0$0501010a@billslaptop>
References: <00b201c69a0e$499ca4a0$0501010a@billslaptop>
Message-ID: <44A16C3E.2060102@foo-projects.org>

Bill Ensley wrote:
> It's my understanding that you can program badly in any language,
> What you needed to do was probably just fine in java, but the 
> Developer just didn't optimize properly.

 From a design standpoint this is completely irrelevant: the compiler really 
should do the optimization for you - it knows best which data is duplicate and 
can be optimized, and it knows the subarchitecture better than the programmer.

Even better: the programmer should not need to know how to optimize code other 
than write ""decent"" code. Decent code is always good. Optimized code often 
compromises stability, readability and (funny enough) performance.

Auke

Auke Kok wrote:
>  From a design standpoint this is completely irrelevant: the compiler 
> really should do the optimization for you - it knows best which data is 
> duplicate and can be optimized, and it knows the subarchitecture better 
> than the programmer.

Some compilers are pretty smart but I'm not sure there's many of them 
that can make basic algorithm substitutions to correct for a 
programmer's bad choice (eg: replacing a hand-made bubble sort with a 
library version of quicksort)

--Brent

From jvancleve at chrome.com  Tue Jun 27 11:17:09 2006
From: jvancleve at chrome.com (Jason Van Cleve)

Subject: [PLUG] Why is java is evil ???? (was "new guy with questions" )
Message-ID: <B5FE13D82C10EF4085844A9F70364A4F0896CEF6@PDXMSX02.hq.chrome.com>

> -----Original Message-----
> From: plug-bounces at lists.pdxlinux.org 
> [mailto:plug-bounces at lists.pdxlinux.org] On Behalf Of Lancashire, Pete
> Sent: Tuesday, June 27, 2006 10:52 AM
> To: 'General Linux/UNIX discussion and help; civil and on-topic'
> Subject: RE: [PLUG] Why is java is evil ???? (was "new guy 
> with questions" )
> 
> I cant remember what the (min/max was too long ago) just to 
> load the VM. at times there would be 20 or so running. I did 
> not know if you could have a vm shared or not, and it was 
> back in the 1.2 days as well so performance was not as good 
> as i have been told 1.4/5 is.

That's an obvious design error, running multiple VMs like that.  Java is not
lightweight and not a scripting language.  Maybe your Java guy didn't
realize how his app' would be used.  A better solution would be to build it
as a daemon and have it check for new files itself, maybe spawn a thread for
each one.  But even as a Java coder, I think I'd have chosen a different
language for that sort of processing.

--Jason

Considering all the issues you are having, how could you possibly say
that reiser is no faster than ext3 given the circumstances?  That is
kind of like racing a porsche down a road and in the process the road
gets torn asunder and then sending a GTO down the same path over
potholes and gaps and large chunks of asphalt everywhere and claiming
that the GTO is no faster than the porsche.


On 6/27/06, John Jason Jordan <johnxj at comcast.net> wrote:
> OK, I had to reformat that old Breezy partition because "sudo apt-get
> dist update" got it so mucked up there was no hope. And I wanted to try
> out Reiserfs, because everyone seems to think it's a lot faster than
> ext3.
>
> So I stuck the Dapper-64 DVD in the drive and restarted the computer.
> When the live version came up it had an icon on the desktop labeled
> INSTALL in very large letters. I proceeded to install. Except that the
> only way you can install and reformat a partition at the same time is
> to use ext3. Reiserfs is not an option. However, since I was actually
> running Dapper-64 from the CD, I just exited from the Install utility
> and used Disk Manager, which was happy to format the partition
> Reiserfs. Then I went back and installed Dapper-64 on it. I had to undo
> all the defaults to do so, because it still insisted on reformatting
> it. But it did recognize the reiserfs filesystem, and after poking at
> it a bit I figured out how to make it work.
>
> Then I spent the next eight hours trying to get it all configured the
> way I want it. That included two hours trying to figure out why the
> Ubuntu wiki instructions to get wireless up and running worked fine on
> the test setup, but wouldn't work this time. (Still not resolved.) And
> I spent more hours reinstalling applications, trying to get my configs
> transferred over, etc. Finally I got all that done, but I noticed that
> nothing could see my fonts. They were in a Fonts folder in /home/jjj,
> which worked fine in Breezy, but I guess not in Dapper. So I proceeded
> to move them all to /usr/share/fonts. That part actually worked using
> the GUI drag and drop. But I guess it's because they were not inside
> folders. Anyway, I got all but the OpenType fonts in, and decided I
> wanted to make a separate folder for them. And then I discovered that
> it never occurred to any of the Nautilus developers that a user might
> want to create a folder. No buttons for that. So I fired up Konqueror,
> but it wouldn't come up, even though I had been using it earlier.
> Neither would Krusader. Or XFE. This was too much. Something bad must
> be going on.
>
> I decided to restart. But when I hit the Shutdown icon, it started to
> shut down, then suddenly X came back, then it disappeared and it went
> back to shutting down, then X reappeared, and back and forth for a
> while. Then a window popped up with a wonderful error message that said
> "the graphical subsystem has been shut down and restarted six times in
> the last 90 seconds. This probably means something really bad is going
> on." (I swear, that is what it said. Now where would you get something
> as pungent as that in Windows?) So I decided to hit the power button
> and restart.
>
> It started back up, but X wouldn't start. It just kept trying and
> failing and trying and failing. I didn't wait for the "six times" error
> message. I just hit the power button.
>
> Then I tried the second choice for this installation -- the 15-23
> kernel instead of the 15-25 that is the top choice. The 15-23 one never
> even got to trying to start X. It hung on "loading hardware drivers."
> That's probably because I had been using nothing but the 15-25, so that
> is the kernel that the drivers were set up for. (Just a guess.)
>
> At that point I decided to go back to this test/rescue installation. I
> figured it was set to mount hda2 automatically during boot, so I could
> use it to poke around and maybe figure out what is wrong. Well, what
> was wrong was Reiserfs. In the middle of booting the test installation
> announced that there was a bad superblock on hda2 and it could not
> mount it. From reading the rest of the error message, it was clear that
> Dapper-64 cannot mount a Reiserfs partition. It did not even recognize
> it, hence the "bad superblock" message.
>
> So my new installation is borked. Won't boot and I don't have an easy
> way to get at the partition. Not that I have much likelihood of
> figuring out what is wrong anyway. Tomorrow I'll have to start over.
> Eight hours down the tube. But just think how much I have learned about
> Linux! <sigh>
>
> Oh, and Reiserfs is no faster than ext3.
>
> But while writing this chapter in the saga of How Not to Install Linux,
> It occurrred to me that I should just use this test installation to
> reformat the 60 GB hda2 partition (as ext3), then copy absolutely
> everything from the test installation to hda2. I can use Aaron's rescue
> CD that I copied at the last clinic, and I even wrote down the copy
> syntax. Not sure how Grub will take that, though. But it's worth a
> shot. And if it doesn't work, I'll learn even more about How Not to
> Install Linux!

From sofar at foo-projects.org  Tue Jun 27 14:30:20 2006
From: sofar at foo-projects.org (Auke Kok)

Tim Slighter wrote:
> Considering all the issues you are having, how could you possibly say
> that reiser is no faster than ext3 given the circumstances?  That is
> kind of like racing a porsche down a road and in the process the road
> gets torn asunder and then sending a GTO down the same path over
> potholes and gaps and large chunks of asphalt everywhere and claiming
> that the GTO is no faster than the porsche.

I'd say that if he has a recently new system with large L2 cache, a big fast 
disc with more cache, and isn't running some obscure benchmark test, he will 
not be able to point out the difference between ext3 and reiserfs.

Reiserfs is _not_ the end-all aweness of filesystems. It does a few things 
faster than ext3 (but please, which user really uses something intensive as 
git or deletes entire kernel trees every hour (such as me) and actually gets 
in the range where you would be able to spot the difference...). Ext3 in its 
turn does a few things faster than reiserfs too, and the differences are 
mostly not large.

car analogy: both the GTO and the porsche only go as fast as the traffic jam. 
The porsche however requires expensive european maintenance and a mechanic 
which is a jerk, whereas the GTO can be reassembled using two pliers and duck 
tape, and fits older carburator-engines without using a hacksaw. ;^)

cheers,

Auke

From russj at dimstar.net  Tue Jun 27 20:39:33 2006
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Tue, 27 Jun 2006 20:39:33 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] OK, GUI file managers all suck
In-Reply-To: <9AFECDC22C4D6942BDFFCBDFCDB27A97074EDB33@cityemail.bit.city>
References: <9AFECDC22C4D6942BDFFCBDFCDB27A97074EDB33@cityemail.bit.city>
Message-ID: <44A1F9F5.7050901@dimstar.net>

Lancashire, Pete wrote:
> toss in -p for good luck. It preserves the ownership.
> although in 99.9% of the cases jjj ownes the files you
> never know
>
>   
My copy of choice, as it works in environments where there's a single 
user, or many users, is the following:

# find . | cpio -pdm /path/to/destination

If I'm doing a particularly long copy (like all the home directories on 
a server) I do something like this:

# cd /home
# for each in `ls`; do echo "processing $each"; find $each | cpio -pdm 
/path/to/destination; done

Works well, saves permissions and ownership, and works across many 
platforms.

Russ

From ron at Opus1.COM  Tue Jun 27 23:40:02 2006
From: ron at Opus1.COM (Ronald Chmara)
Date: Tue, 27 Jun 2006 23:40:02 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Why is java is evil ???? (was "new guy with questions" )
In-Reply-To: <9AFECDC22C4D6942BDFFCBDFCDB27A97074EDB39@cityemail.bit.city>
References: <9AFECDC22C4D6942BDFFCBDFCDB27A97074EDB39@cityemail.bit.city>
Message-ID: <d4264cf8e5ae605efd20948c79b46c25@opus1.com>

On Jun 27, 2006, at 10:52 AM, Lancashire, Pete wrote:
> totally agree poor programming can be done in any lang.
> each instance took something like 32 or 64 MB, the server
> was fully loaded with 256 MB :)
> I cant remember what the (min/max was too long ago) just to load
> the VM. at times there would be 20 or so running. I did not
> know if you could have a vm shared or not, and it was back
> in the 1.2 days as well so performance was not as good as i
> have been told 1.4/5 is.
> but just to read 200K lines of 50 chars of EBCDIC, convert to
> ASCII, do a few if field x is not this or that, then write back
> out to another file, it just seemed too much in resources.
> i guess what got me the most was he got his 'religion' from
> school, that java was the answer to all solutions, but that
> is a whole other thread ..

<rant>

I think part of the problem is that the OO paradigm, as often being 
taught, actually supports and *encourages* poor coding practices (in 
terms of RAM and CPU load), in so many ways.

Rather than a developer being expected to be tightly coupled to the 
performance of the computer, and their program, programmers are 
encouraged to break tasks/jobs/data down into discrete, isolated, 
units, with their own protected memory spaces, in order to... well... 
do anything. Add in insane re-use models of using existing bloatware to 
avoid writing 10 lines (or less) of code ("load up a ginormous 128Kb 
library object to simply wrap an 6 letter XML tag around an item? Don't 
mind if I do!"), and it just gets uglier. (Sun/MS/Dell sells more 
hardware, yay!)

An example:....

What does good "religious" OO teach us? To use "nouns" (or members of a 
class), and to isolate those nouns! (I'm going to skip over this 
debate).

So, 200,000 lines... well, a line is one kind of noun, so maybe we need 
200,000 objects from our "line" class.

But then again, the pieces of *text* in those lines, if it represents 
something like a database field parameter, is another kind of noun, so 
if there are 10 different items in a line, that's then inherited (from 
line) class pieces, or 2,000,000 different objects to track in memory.

Since we don't want our properties for the first piece of a text 
object, as a child of a line object, at line 199,999, to interfere with 
any other lines or the existing line's text properties, we have to keep 
track of 2,000,000 different objects.

Of course, since each of those pieces of text may have any one of, oh, 
say, 10 properties, we need memory space for 20,000,000 variables. 
Assuming (LOL!) that each variable takes up *only* one 8-bit byte, 
that's 160,000,000 bits needed. 19531.25K. 19.07 *Megabytes*.

Now that we have our 20,000,000 object variables loaded in 19 Mb of 
RAM, cleanly isolated, we only need to test if one of the lines has a 
variable set to "foo".

*cough*

It may seem funny, but I have seen software written like this.  
Actually, is it fairly rare that I see OO software that *isn't* written 
like this, quite sadly. Maybe because the emphasis is on thinking about 
OO ideals (polymorphism, code maintenance), and not things endusers 
care about (speed, minimal footprints), I see it much more in lock-in 
industries, and code from the folks who never wrote to a target of 
256K(max) of RAM.

Please note that I did not say 256M.
</rant>

-Ifeelolderthandirtbop

4245 NE Alberta Ct.
Portland, OR 97218
503-282-1370

	Here is my problem: I have a rather involved directory structure and I am 
going to be securing the server that this directory structure is on. One of

order to do their work. I want to backup the permission and ownership 
settings for this directory structure before I harden everything so that way,

problems where tarring the directory structure to preserve permissions and 
ownership settings is impractical (a good example is the directory structure 
for the full gcc source code).

From heinlein at madboa.com  Wed Jun 28 08:45:50 2006
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed, 28 Jun 2006 08:45:50 -0700 (PDT)
Subject: [PLUG] OK, GUI file managers all suck
In-Reply-To: <9AFECDC22C4D6942BDFFCBDFCDB27A97074EDB5C@cityemail.bit.city>
References: <9AFECDC22C4D6942BDFFCBDFCDB27A97074EDB5C@cityemail.bit.city>
Message-ID: <Pine.OSX.4.64.0606280839110.362@arrowhead.galois.com>

On Wed, 28 Jun 2006, Lancashire, Pete wrote:

> or ..
> 
> % cd /source; tar cf - . | (cd /destination && tar xBpf -)

Assuming GNU tar, it can be a bit shorter than that:

  tar cC /source . | tar xC /destination

The lacking a -f switch, the default is to pipe to stdin and from 
stdout; the -C switch removes the need to cd to a directory.

I think -p is the default, though it assumes that root is performing 
the process.

I don't know what the advantage to -B is. Clues, anyone?

a few more cents of thought ..

  i don't really have any grips about java, never done
  much in it, the grip is more with the religious fever
  that promoted it not only on technical merits, but
  from the suits, brings back memories of PL/1, or Ada.
  then add the (in my opinion) the myth of code reuse.
  I wrote a string parser in C about 20 yrs ago, I
  cut/pasted 80% of it last winter, is that any less
  reusable ?

  and don't get me going on those drag and drop
  code/program generators. "You CIO don't have to
  hire expensive programmers, your secretary can
  be a enterprise programmer" ..

  over my 0.5 century, i have become very skeptical
  with anything that gets a cult following. i was
  thinking of going back to college and finally get
  my CS degree, so i sat in on some 3xx class,
  and unless it was 'you the programmer should not
  be concerned with the demands your work places
  on the hardware, that is someone else's problem',
  and in the same class later in the week, 'java
  is the only truth ..'

From scratchcomputing at gmail.com  Wed Jun 28 09:23:43 2006
From: scratchcomputing at gmail.com (Eric Wilhelm)
Date: Wed, 28 Jun 2006 09:23:43 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] How do I backup the permissions and ownership settings for
	a file hierarchy?
In-Reply-To: <200606280036.15839.bobby_miesen@yahoo.com>
References: <200606280036.15839.bobby_miesen@yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <200606280923.44247.ewilhelm@cpan.org>

# from Robert Jeffrey Miesen
# on Wednesday 28 June 2006 12:36 am:

>I want to backup the permission and ownership
>settings for this directory structure before I harden everything so
> that way, if I blow something up badly, I don't have to reinstall
> everything to fix the problem.

So, you want something like a tar archive without any file contents and 
then some way to re-apply that metadata?

rsync could do the trick, but can't be lightweight because hardlinks 
share ownership and permissions, so you would have to duplicate all of 
the files.  I'm assuming that you already have a backup and/or have 
other reasons (you mention reinstalling) to not backup the contents.

Sounds like you might have to roll your own with find/stat to do the 
info gathering and chmod, etc to re-apply.  Probably some tricky bits 
with hardlinks and symlinks too, so you might want to use device/inode 
numbers instead of (or as an additional check to) filenames.

A quick googling (snapshot file permissions) results in something like:
  http://www.cpan.org/authors/id/J/JO/JOHNKOEN/NAfixperms-v1.6.pl

Of course, you'll need 2 programs.  Maybe dump a YAML file between them.

--Eric

Java is great for code reuse, whether you're building libraries as JARs or
simply compiling against shared code, it's straitforward and elegant.  If
code reuse is a myth, it's because of the bureaucracy of many software
shops, impeding the code's evolution across multiple projects--or simply
because programmers don't know to think in terms of reuse.  Maybe they don't
trust their colleagues' work, or maybe they're lazy in the wrong way.  ;)

But this, like bad programming in general, is not endemic to Java.

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Wed Jun 28 11:02:48 2006
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Wed, 28 Jun 2006 11:02:48 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] How do I backup the permissions and ownership settings for
	a file hierarchy?
In-Reply-To: <200606280036.15839.bobby_miesen@yahoo.com>
References: <200606280036.15839.bobby_miesen@yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20060628180248.GA10110@gate.kl-ic.com>

On Wed, Jun 28, 2006 at 12:36:14AM -0700, Robert Jeffrey Miesen wrote:
> 
>   Here is my problem: I have a rather involved directory structure and I am 
> going to be securing the server that this directory structure is on. One of 
> the steps of establishing a security baseline is called "limiting", which is 
> basically where you give everyone the least amount of privileges they need in 
> order to do their work. I want to backup the permission and ownership 
> settings for this directory structure before I harden everything so that way, 
> if I blow something up badly, I don't have to reinstall everything to fix the 
> problem. 
> 	I could tar it, but where's the fun in that if there is some command or 
> utility that I could use to do this job so that way I can attack similar 
> problems where tarring the directory structure to preserve permissions and 
> ownership settings is impractical (a good example is the directory structure 
> for the full gcc source code). 
> 
>   Does anyone know of such a tool? If not, who would be willing to join me in 
> making such a tool someday (such as, say, next week)?

Assuming you want just the permissions and owners, and not the data itself,
you probably don't want to use the word "backup", which usually is defined
to include the data itself.

While it would be nice to have a magic utility that would allow you to
restore permissions in some undefined easy manner, you can capture the
information you want with a simple "ls -lR > ls_out".  If you need to
put the files back, you can do it by hand, or else build a perl script
(perhaps called "permrestore") that can read the ls_out file and put
things back.  Editing the list with a text editor would probably be
easier than adding some fancy selection process to permrestore. 
Chances are, the only way to design permrestore would be to go through
the manual process at least once, to learn what needs to be done.  And
once you have done it manually, you may not need the tool anymore.
Now you know why nobody has written one.

However, you probably should use tar or rsync or some other means
of backing up the whole thing, data and all.  Disk space is cheap,
and your futzing around with permissions will have a non-zero
possibility of losing data.  Rsync to another filesystem is
preferred, as it is easier to move individual files back.  

Keith

Keith Lofstrom          keithl at keithl.com         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Wed Jun 28 15:17:44 2006

	<1151533350.8547.21.camel@willow.odshp.com>

On Jun 28, 2006, at 5:22 PM, Wil Cooley wrote:

> On Wed, 2006-06-28 at 00:36 -0700, Robert Jeffrey Miesen wrote:
>
>> Does anyone know of such a tool? If not, who would be willing to  
>> join me in
>> making such a tool someday (such as, say, next week)?
>
> I needed to do this at some point in the past and wrote a couple quick
> little scripts.  They're not perfect; they'll fail if your files or
> directories have a comma in the name (RCS files?):
>
> http://haus.nakedape.cc/svn/public/trunk/small-projects/sys-utils/ 
> dump-perms
> http://haus.nakedape.cc/svn/public/trunk/small-projects/sys-utils/ 
> restore-perms

An example that is a variation on dump-perm.  It uses tabs as the  
field separator and numbers for the uid and gid:

$ find /bin/ -printf "%p\t%m\t%U\t%G\n" | tee file.list.txt | head
/bin/   755     0       0
/bin/cat        755     0       0
/bin/stty       755     0       0
/bin/fgrep      777     0       0
/bin/uname      755     0       0
/bin/df 755     0       0
/bin/date       755     0       0
/bin/tcsh       755     0       0
/bin/ed 755     0       0
/bin/mv 755     0       0

... and a variation on restore-perms using tab as the field  
separator.  It also handles symlinks:

cat file.list.txt | while IFS=$'\t' read file mode uid gid ; do
   echo chown $uid:$gid $file
   [ -L $file ] && continue
   echo chmod $mode $file
done

Remove the echo to make it live, or pipe it into a shell.

Regards,
- Robert
http://www.cwelug.org/downloads
Help others get OpenSource software.  Distribute FLOSS
for Windows, Linux, *BSD, and MacOS X with BitTorrent

Hmmm...what version of Nautilus is Dapper using?

On my install (Debian Etch) of Nautilus 2.14.1:

1)  The first item in the File drop down menu is "Create Folder" 
(Shift+Ctrl+N), in spatial mode.  In browser mode, it's the second item.
2)  The first item that appears in the menu that pops-up when I 
right-click on any empty space in a Nautilus window is "Create Folder".

Note that if an existing folder or file is highlighted, the right-click 
menu is different and does not contain an option to create a folder.  
Nautilus assumes, if you have a file or folder highlighted, you want to 
perform an operation on that file or folder, not make a new one.

I can't imagine why Dapper would've removed these options.

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Thu Jun 29 00:19:54 2006
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Thu, 29 Jun 2006 00:19:54 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] Sourcelabs
Message-ID: <20060629071954.GA17139@gate.kl-ic.com>


These folks were mentioned on Slashdot:

http://www.sourcelabs.com/

They have a new system for automated Linux support, the Continuous
Support System.  It does things like running automated diagnostic
probes on client machines, pattern matching errors to a large
database, automated pre-emptive maintenance, and other things that
should greatly enhance the reliability of Linux for their customers.  

If they pull this off, it will be the Next Big Thing.  Because it
is rooted in open source, it will be impossible for M$ to counter.

SourceLabs is located in Seattle.  This is good, because when they
put M$ out of business, there will be local jobs for those M$ 
software engineers who are adaptable and mostly undamaged.

Perhaps we can get SourceLabs to give a presentation down here.

Keith

PS: with Ward Cunningham leaving M$ for Eclipse, Vista delays, SCO
getting whipped in court ( most Linux-related claims were thrown
out today, see www.groklaw.org ), the Portland Project for desktop
Linux,  and Scott Kveton working on OpenID, a lot of very cool
things are happening.  Smile, dammit!
