On Jun 28, 2006, at 5:43 PM, Michael M. wrote:
> Lancashire, Pete wrote:
>> quoted ..
>> http://www.theregister.co.uk/2006/06/27/portland_linux_distributions/
> Am I the only one who doesn't get how or where the Portland Project 
> fits in with LSB, Freedesktop.org, the Free Standards Group, and Gnome 
> and KDE?  I can't figure out if it is superfluous, competing, 
> complementary, or just confusing.  Well, it confuses me, anyway.

Problem:
I want to install an application. I do not care what desktop 
environment a user has, I just want the user to be able to launch it 
from a desktop menu. How do I populate the menu for fvwm, kde, gnome, 
fvwm95, (blah blah) menu with one programming statement?

Problem:
I want to enable a user to click on a URI, and launch their web browser 
(email client, preferred RSS reader etc.). I do not care, or want to 
care, what desktop environment a user has, or what they have open. 
Thus, if a user has a pine session open to another machine, and the 
user has a URI, how do I make the user's preferred web page viewer 
*open* and load that URI when that user clicks on a URI in pine?

As I understand their code, they are a "glue" project. If a user wants 
a Konqueror browser window to launch when they click on a URL in an 
gnome session email(!)... make that happen, by adding "glue" code to 
the app that reads the email. If an app wants to bring up a "print" 
window, it shouldn't have to care what UI it has.

Sounds ambitious.

-Bop

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Thu Jun 29 10:05:40 2006
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Thu, 29 Jun 2006 10:05:40 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] new guy with questions
In-Reply-To: <200606290530.k5T5U4Op065782@m5p.com>

On Wed, 2006-06-28 at 22:30 -0700, Elliott Mitchell wrote:

> Take a look at http://www.debian.org/, those were rough estimates based
> on a longish term of observation. I wasn't being precise, merely
> estimating.

In other words, it was based on vague impressions rather than facts.
How about reviewing it yourself and working with facts?  There have been
2 Debian security advisories for Postfix in the past decade; the first
happened only in what seems to me to be obscure configuration and the
latter is somewhat nasty.  That hardly qualifies as once every 9 months.
Exim has had more, and one as recent as last year potentially allowed
remote code execution.

> >From: Wil Cooley <wcooley at nakedape.cc>
> > It doesn't help that QMail hasn't seen a release in nearly a decade.
> > (IPv6?  64-bit?  Updated standards?)
> 
> Does one's MTA really need more than 2GB of memory? There is an actively
> maintained patch for IPv6 functionality.

No, you probably don't need more than 2GB of memory, but you might want
to compile 64-bit because everything else does and you don't want to
make special exceptions or to gain whatever performance improves it
might bring.  Yes, "actively maintained patches" are the mainstay of
QMail, aren't they?  Since DJB seems to have abandoned it and his nutty
license isn't free software, that's about the best anyone can do.  And
those two were just two examples...  It's not as if the mail handling
world has stood still since 1998.
  o RFCs 821 and 822 have been replaced by updated RFCs 2821 and 2822
(2001).
  o RFC 1891 replaced by 3461 and updated by a couple more.
  o Unicode, i18n and l10n have become widespread and standardized.  
  o SSL/TLS (SSL is easy to wrap, but TLS is another story)
  o SMTP AUTH
  o Directory and database-based routing (yet another patch?)

There's probably a lot of other stuff I'm neglecting to mention.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley <wcooley at nakedape.cc>
Naked Ape Consulting, Ltd

From charlie at schluting.com  Thu Jun 29 22:26:12 2006

>   I'm looking for the most efficient way to backup the /home directory of a
> user from a laptop to the desktop -- automagically via a cron job.
> 
>   I could export the ~/ on the laptop, then mount it on the desktop so that
> it's included in the daily incremental and weekly full backups. Is this the
> most parsimonious solution?

> 

Rich:

Incrementals help in the case of accidental deletions, but other than
that, I don't see much use for them. A full dump in multiple places
should be fine. If you're trying to save space, I guess bzip'd
incrementals makes some sense. And restores are a lot easier if you're
only dealing with full dumps :)

I have an rsync script in my laptop's homedir, and I just run it every
once in a while. I have it detect where I am, so I can backup to
different desktops (work and home). It normally runs in just a few
seconds, since most of the data rarely changes.

That works for me, anyway.

-Charlie

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Fri Jun 30 11:54:48 2006
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 30 Jun 2006 11:54:48 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] rsync syntax
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.63.0606301120550.23890@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.63.0606301120550.23890@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <863bdmzd6v.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Rich" == Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> writes:

Rich>    I've read the rsync man page but cannot get the syntax
Rich> correct for backing up a remote laptop's ~/ to the equivalent
Rich> directory on the desktop.

Rich>    I su'd to that username, then cd'd to ~/<user>. At the
Rich> command line I tried

Rich> rsync -avz pachy:home/<user>/ .

Rich> but that did not copy anything. I'm trying to recursively copy
Rich> all directories and files in the remote system to the pwd on the
Rich> desktop system.
>> From the man page, adding the trailing slash copies the contents of
>> the
Rich> source directory to the destination directory without creating
Rich> another copy of that top-level directory locally.

Rich>    What have I missed in my understanding?

The default directory on a remote machine is your home, so you are
missing a / after the ':'.  As in:

  $ rsync -avz pachy:/home/<user>/ .
                     
The command you used was trying to copy the remote
/home/<user>/home/<user> to your cwd.

Or, if the user running the command is <user>, then just:

  $ rsync -avz pachy:. . 

should work.


-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com

   Ah, that makes a lot of sense. Thanks for the clarification, Russell.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Fri Jun 30 11:54:48 2006
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 30 Jun 2006 11:54:48 -0700
Subject: [PLUG] rsync syntax
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.63.0606301120550.23890@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.63.0606301120550.23890@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <863bdmzd6v.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Rich" == Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> writes:

Rich>    I've read the rsync man page but cannot get the syntax
Rich> correct for backing up a remote laptop's ~/ to the equivalent
Rich> directory on the desktop.

Rich>    I su'd to that username, then cd'd to ~/<user>. At the
Rich> command line I tried

Rich> rsync -avz pachy:home/<user>/ .

Rich> but that did not copy anything. I'm trying to recursively copy
Rich> all directories and files in the remote system to the pwd on the
Rich> desktop system.
>> From the man page, adding the trailing slash copies the contents of
>> the
Rich> source directory to the destination directory without creating
Rich> another copy of that top-level directory locally.

Rich>    What have I missed in my understanding?

The default directory on a remote machine is your home, so you are
missing a / after the ':'.  As in:

  $ rsync -avz pachy:/home/<user>/ .
                     
The command you used was trying to copy the remote
/home/<user>/home/<user> to your cwd.

Or, if the user running the command is <user>, then just:

  $ rsync -avz pachy:. . 

should work.

sub getpassdb
{
    # Read password file creating usernames and
    # passwords hash.

    local $file_passwd="/root/firewall/var/cgi_password" ;

   open (INPASS,"$file_passwd") or die "Error--unable to open $file_passwd $!" ;

    $passline=<INPASS>;
    @temp_array=split(/[=\n]/,$passline);

    close(INPASS) ;

    %passworddb=@temp_array ;

    return %passworddb;
}


The latter is a subroutine I'm trying to write in perl that isn't doing what
I want it to.  I want to read a file with lines that are formatted:

username=password

and create a hash from those pairs.

I understand that a hash can be created from an array according to A Little
Book On Perl.  I'll try hard coding experiments to see if I can't narrow
the problem down further.
